This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Maria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Run

texts.en: Mrs. Run T., 31, lives in the rural area of Battambang Province. She earns a living as a farmer by planting rice and vegetable crops. Her husband helps to alleviate her hard labor in her business. The couple has been married for many years but they don’t have any children yet. Recently, Run T. has been lacking some farm supplies for her business. Therefore, she is applying for a loan of $300 USD to purchase crop seeds and lots of sacks of fertilizer for her field.

loans.use: To purchase crop seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Saing

texts.en:
Mrs. Saing R., 40, is a farmer who grows rice and vegetables in her village in the province of Battambang. She has been a farmer since 1989. She is married and lives with her husband and three children. All three of her children go to school and they also help in their parent’s business when they are not studying. Mrs. R.'s husband assists her in her farming activities. Every year, Saing R. depends on farming as her main source of income. Recently, she has been lacking farming supplies. As she does not have the necessary money, she decided to ask for a loan through Kiva to purchase a large amount of fertilizer, crop seed, insecticide and a watering pump for her farm.
Mrs. Saing R. was busy when the photograph was taken so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of fertilizer, crop seed, insecticide and a watering pump

loans.name: Cecilia's Group

texts.en:
Cecilia S. is from the village of Brgy. Baretbet, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 47 years old. Cecilia is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Cecilia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Cecilia owns & operates a restaurant serving local foods to customers in the local community. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cecilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Cecilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food & drinks for the restaurant

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
Gloria V. is from the village of Brgy. Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Gloria is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Gloria is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a general store selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Shamila

texts.en:
Shamila is a married woman who lives with her husband in Kekanadura, part of the Matara area of Sri Lanka. She is a hard-working woman.

Shamila has managed a poultry farming business for one year.

She has requested a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her business and to purchases needed materials. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy needed materials

loans.name: Chanidrika

texts.en:
Chandrika is a 35-year-old married woman who lives with her husband and two daughters in Kekanadura, Matara. Her husband is a businessman and the children are still in school. Chandrika has a very friendly personality and gets along well with others.

Chandrika has managed a spice grinding businessfor six months. She has requested a 40,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to purchase spices for her business.

Thank you for taking time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy spices

loans.name: Sujatha

texts.en:
Sujatha is a married woman who lives with her husband in Kekanadura, a town in the area of Matara. Her husband works as a welder. 

Sujatha manages a jewelry-making business with the help of her husband.  She has asked for a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to buy tools to help her business.

Thank you for taking time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy tools

loans.name: Ariunaa

texts.en:
Ariunaa is 42 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house on their own land. Her two daughters are 8 and 16 years old and attend a local secondary school. Her husband is taxi driver. 

Currently, Ariunaa operates a clothing-sales business at Narantuul market, the largest and most crowded market in the city. She operates a retail business and purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. She started her business in 2003 with working capital of 600,000 tugrug (about $146) and has expanded her business with a loyal customer base. Recently, in 2007-2009, Ariunaa and her husband purchased their own plot of land and built a house. Ariunaa is a very hardworking person. She is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Mangalika

texts.en:
Mangalika is a 45-year-old married woman who lives in Kekanadura, a town in the area of Matara. Her husband is a businessman and she has four daughters. They are all married.

Mangalika has managed a clothing business for two years. She has requested a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to buy clothes to help her business.

She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides to her. Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Dorathi

texts.en:
Dorathi is a 35-year-old married woman living with her husband and three children. She has one son and two daughters. Her husband is a mason, and her children are still in school.

Dorathi has managed a business for a year selling clothes. She is hardworking and enthusiastic. She has requested a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her business by purchasing more clothes to sell. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Roger's Group

texts.en:
Roger A. is from the village of Casalatan, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Roger is 38 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Roger owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Roger has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2006, Roger joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be his fifth from ASKI. Roger plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's tuition fees.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Lubele South Abanyo Nighty Group

texts.en:
A. Nighty is a hardworking businesswoman of 37. She is married with six children in school. She has dealt in the business of selling silver fish since the year 2000. 

She is using the loan to purchase silver fish and increase her stock. She is a courageous businesswoman who managed to struggle throughout the war period and now her dreams are to educate her children and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase silver fish to increase stock

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en:
Erdenetsetseg is a 39-year-old widow who lives with her two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son, Erdenebileg, is 19 years old and he attends university. Her daughter, Undarmaa, is 11 years old and attends a local secondary school. 

She operates a coal and firewood trading business. Erdenetsetseg started her businesses in 2000 and made quick progress. Erdenetsetseg is a very hard-working person. However, in 2002, her husband passed away and she was left to raise her two children. At that time, it was hard for her to continue her work, but she has since worked diligently to grow her businesses to their current successful position. She is requesting a loan to purchase construction material to build house.

loans.use: To purchase construction material to build a house

loans.name: Emelita's Group

texts.en:
Emelita B. is from the village of San Luis, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is the leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Emelita is 42 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Emelita has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Emelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Lubele North Amito Este Group

texts.en: A. Este is a hard-working business woman. She is 33 years old, married and has 5 children, 4 of whom go to school. She has been operating a charcoal selling business for two months so far. She is using the loan to purchase charcoal from villages to take to Pader trading center for sale. She is an encouraging business woman whose dreams are to build a home and to have a stable life with no displacements because of rebels.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Zucima

texts.en:
Zucima A. is from the village of Orang Cabgan, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 52 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Zucima owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. The main source of income for the business comes from raising fish for sale in her fishpond. Zucima has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Zucima joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Zucima is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her seventh from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag B., 48, lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her husband have their own plot of land with a house and yard where they are currently living. They have five sons who are grown up and live separately from them. Her husband, Munhtur, operates a transportation business with a micro-bus which belongs to someone else.  He earns 15,000 MNT per day. 


Tungalag runs a women's clothing business at Narantuul, the biggest market in Mongolia. She purchases a variety of women's clothing once or twice a month. In addition, she purchases high quality clothing twice a year from Beijing.  She has been planning to expand her business and to operate in a big trading center. Tungalag has gained valuable experience in previous years and she would like to purchase her own car in the future. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase women's clothing, especially shirts, from Beijing.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Acela

texts.en:
Acela C. is from the village of Oranga Cabgan, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 41 years old. Acela is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Acela owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising fish for sale. Acela has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Acela joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Acela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Acela is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Acela from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Altangerel

texts.en:
Altangerel T. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Tuv province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). They have been living together in their current home for 15 years. 


Altangerel operates a transportation business. He transports his customers from Tuv province to Ulaanbaatar city with a microbus which he owns. He has been operating his business since 2000 and has built a stable operation. Altangerel is a very hardworking person. His business is very important to him and he says, “I would like to operate my business with my current microbus without any problems. For the future, I think I will change my microbus into a smaller one because of the government policy of decreasing the number of microbuses.” 


He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to repair and maintain his microbus in order to provide a more convenient service to his customers.

loans.use: To repair his microbus

loans.name: Battogtoh

texts.en:
Battogtoh B., 28, lives with his parents in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family have been living together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent.) They have been living together in their current home for three years since moving from Hairhandulaan soum of Uvurhangai. His father is a herder and his mother is a cook in a local restaurant. 


Battogtoh operates a cell phone repair and trade business. He graduated in 2007 as computer repairman from a vocational training center, an affiliate of The Mongolian University of Science and Technology. After he graduated from university, he did a cell phone repair course and started to repair cell phones at a rented counter that belonged to one of his friends in Ulaanbaatar.  Since 2008, he has been operating his own repair service with his friend, at a rented counter in a trading center called Emt in Uvurhangai province. 


In the beginning, he did not have not enough equipment and  there were many competitors running similar businesses which meant that it was difficult to earn high profits. Therefore, he received a 500,000 MNT loan in his father's name which made it possible for him to purchase the necessary equipment and spare cell phone parts for his business. 


He is an industrious, knowledgeable person who has good communication skills. He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase more cell phone repair equipment to provide a larger range of services to his customers.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is married and the mother of three.  She has been selling charcoal for eleven years.  She also operates a motorbike transport business to earn extra income. 

She is in a group with Faulu Kenya whose members guarantee one another's loans.  She appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping her improve her business, which improved her standard of living.  Her group has guaranteed her a loan of 60,000 KES to buy one hundred bags of charcoal.  

She hopes to increase her supply so that she can sell her goods wholesale in the future.  In five years, she wants to become the main charcoal supplier in her area.

loans.use: To buy one hundred bags of charcoal

loans.name: Nandani

texts.en:
Nandani is a 43-year-old married woman living with her husband and three children; she has two sons and one daughter. One of them is married while the others currently do not have jobs.

Nandani has managed a business sewing clothes for three years. She has requested a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help develop her business.

Thank you for taking time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To improve her sewing business

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a 38-year-old man who is married to a businesswoman.  He has five children who are of school age.  

He has been operating a retail shop for two years.  He is also employed in a security firm.  Francis works hard in his business so that he can educate his children and provide other basic needs for the family.  

He has requested a loan of 30,000 KES to add to his stock of head phones, extension cables and mobile phone chargers in his shop.  He has been guaranteed this loan by his group members called Kindiria Faulu in Faulu Kenya.  

Francis hopes to expand his business for better sales in the future.

loans.use: To buy head phones, extension cables and mobile phone chargers

loans.name: Kamesh

texts.en:
Kamesh H., 41, is married and the mother of four children. She and her family live together in a house which they own. Kamesh operates a meat trading business in her town which she has operated with her husband since 1993 and has steadily expanded. She sells the meat at a rented counter at a market called Tirlik. She purchases her meats from Uvs province and resells them for a profit. This is her third loan from XacBank and she has used those loans well in the past. Kamesh is one of our reliable clients who has successfully repaid all her loans on time. Since she started to receive loans from XacBank, her family's quality of life has noticeably improved.

Kamesh has been in the meat trading business for many years and has gained valuable experience as a businesswoman. Her monthly net profit is 200,000 – 340,000 MNT. She purchases horse meat for 250,000 MNT and sells it for 400,000 MNT, camel for 400,000 MNT and sells it for 600,000 MNT, and sheep for 60,000 MNT and sells it for 80,000 MNT. The whole family supports her business. Her oldest son attends a secondary school and her other three children are primary school students. Kamesh has a good personality and her family is very important for her. She says, “My children are the source of my happiness. I will do my best to provide a better life for them. I am happy that I can show my children that people can make profits even with a small amount of money which is an important thing to understand.” She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of meat at wholesale prices for her business.

loans.use: To purchase meat for her meat trading business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is from the village of Solinog, Calamba, Misamis Occcidental. She is 33 years old. Agnes is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Agnes owns and operates a retail store, selling products such as canned goods, candies, sugar, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Agnes has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $68 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Agnes joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agnes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Agnes is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy R. is 44 years old and is married to Eddie R.. The couple has two children, both of whom are college students. She and her husband have worked hard but they had a very small income, and they didn't have enough capital to start up a business. 

In 1997, Nancy heard about the Kiva field partner, ASHI, and began dreaming of having a stable life, a stable home and of starting a business. When she received her first and succeeding loans from ASHI, Nancy started her own business of selling fish in the local community. She has had this business for many years. Fish selling has been a great help to her family. As a busy entrepreneur, Nancy also embarked on a tricycle transport business (motorcycle with sidecar). Her husband, Eddie, manages this business.

However, the demands of her family grow as years go by. She wants to have more businesses that can add to her present income so she will have bigger profits and savings. She had the idea of operating a sari-sari (variety) store. It has been great! Nancy is earning a good income and she wants to make a larger investment in it. On her 11th loan, she is proposing a new loan amounting 45,000 PHP to expand her growing variety store business.

With this kind of business, Nancy can still manage her previous business of fish selling, because either her children or her husband can operate their sari-sari (variety) store at home when she's away selling fish. Someday, as her income increases, she dreams of funding her children’s education until they complete college degrees and have professional jobs. Her greatest dreams are to get out from the downward spiral of poverty and to have a happy life.

loans.use: To expand her variety store by purchasing more groceries.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina A., 30, is married and the mother of two children. She and her family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent) in Bayn-Ulgii province. Her son, Jolaman, is a first grade student in a local primary school. Her 6-year-old daughter, Janerke, attends kindergarten. Marina operates a raw material trading business at a local market called Ah-Dam. She has been operating her business since 1999, and has steadily expanded it over the past 11 years. She collects sheep skins as well as sheep intestines and earns a profit of 300 MNT for each sheep skin and set of sheep intestines. In addition, she purchases cashmere for 44,000 MNT and sells it for 44,300 MNT. Her monthly profit is 300,000 MNT.  

Marina has been in this business for many years and has gained significant experience as a raw material trader. Furthermore, she has particular places where she collects leather and sheep skins. Her husband operates a mobile raw material trading business, the same as his wife's, but in another market called Tirlik. Generally, Marina's family's standard of living is good. She is an enthusiastic person and focused on the future. She says, “The raw material trading business is not easy work to do because working conditions are not that good. However, since I started this business, my family's quality of life has been noticeably improving.” She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase sheep skins and intestines for her business.

loans.use: To purchase sheep skins and intestines for her raw material trading business

loans.name: Yet

texts.en: Mr. Yet S., 43, is a divorced father blessed with three children who all attend school.  He is currently a professional language teacher in a private school. He started his job in 2000 and is able to generate a daily income of $9 to help control his family's financial problems. S. is taking out this loan to repair his existing motorcycle, which often breaks down when he rides it to class and other places. With any remaining cash from the loan, S. will buy furniture for his house.

loans.use: To repair his existing motorcycle

loans.name: Ochir

texts.en:
Ochir N. is 69 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Tuv province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in an apartment. Ochir operates a wood and iron products manufacturing business in his town. His wife, Tsegmid, helps his business and also runs her own manufacturing business where she makes beads. They have a 26-year-old daughter who helps her mother's business, selling the beads her mother makes and other clothing that she has purchased from Beijing, China.

Ochir has been operating his business since 1999 and has built a stable operation. At the beginning, he used to sell the wood and iron products that he manufactured at a local market but now he has become well-known among his customers. Currently, customers come to his home in order to buy his products and to order products that they want. Ochir is an honest and hard-working person. The most important thing to him now is to create his own workplace in order to provide his products to more customers. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT in order to build his own workplace.

loans.use: To build his own workplace

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine A. is a 57-year-old married mother of one child, Sharen. She and her husband work together in operating her food-vending business and sari-sari (variety) store. The couple has been engaged in these businesses for more than ten years now. Her husband also works as a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) driver to earn an extra income to support and sustain the needs of their family.
Josephine joined Kiva partner, ASHI, in 1997, with the aim of getting out of the spiral of poverty and consistently acquiring working capital for her business. She will use this new loan of 45,000 PHP to buy additional inventory for her sari-sari (variety) store and supplies for her food-vending venture. Josephine is grateful to ASHI for their good hearts towards the poor, like her family, and for helping her reach her dreams. That is why the couple has grown to love the institution very much and all lenders who are sponsoring this loan.
Josephine hopes that one day she will be able to have her own produce stall in the market for her food-vending business instead of just in her house. She also hopes to make enough money to pay for her family's needs, and dreams of the best of life for her family.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory for sari-sari store and supplies for her food-vending ventures

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben B. is 54 years old and lives in Tsovagyugh village, Sevan area, with his wife. He has two sons who live in Yerevan. Ruben is an economist, and now works as an accountant in the Tsovagyugh village administration. At the same time, he is engaged in animal husbandry and land cultivation. On his farm, Ruben has cows and calves, pigs and piglets. His wife helps him on the farm and they use their farming income to provide for their family's needs and increase the number of their farm animals.
Ruben is asking for a loan of 1,100,000 AMD to buy fodder for his farm animals, seeds and fertilizer. He intends to spend his future income on reconstructing and repairing his house.

loans.use: To buy fodder for his farm animals, seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Bayarkhuu

texts.en:
Bayarkhuu is 45 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. She operates a carpentry business with her husband in their home province. Her husband and oldest son manufacture wooden furniture and Bayarkhuu helps with the business. They produce a variety of wooden furniture products including chairs, tables, sofas and wardrobes.

Bayarkhuu also operates a retail business and purchases a variety of furniture from Ereen (Erenhot), a Chinese border city, and resells it for a profit. Bayarkhuu and her husband have gained valuable experience in previous years and have a loyal customer base. She and her husband have been planning to expand their production line and increase their sales. She likes to say, “Nothing is impossible.” She is requesting a loan to purchase furniture from Ereen.

loans.use: To buy furniture to increase her inventory

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana P. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 31 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ana owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Ana has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Ana joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ana is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Narangerel

texts.en:
Narangerel T. is 34 years old and lives with her husband in an apartment in Dornogobi province, Mongolia. Her husband, Mongolhuu, operates a transportation business in Zamiin-Uud, south of Dornogobi province. They purchased their current apartment with a mortgage loan from the Golomt bank, and they have been using their profits to repay the loan.

Narangerel operates a knitting business in her town. She provides services that change the design or repair the wool and cashmere products for her customers besides knitting her own products. She started her business in November 2009 with another employee whom she hired at the rented workplace. Even though her business is seasonal, orders for her summer clothes are increasing. Therefore, she has recently taken out a contract to rent a larger workplace in order to expand her business and operate it during the whole year.

Narangerel is an open and industrious person who has good communication skills. She says, “Currently, my business operation is based on my customers' orders. I have been planning to hire two more employees and train them in order to sell goods at the counter. We are ready to operate the business continuously if we can buy thread for summer clothes from Beijing, China.” She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more wool and cashmere as well as thread for summer clothes which is currently the most important thing to her.

loans.use: To purchase wool, cashmere and thread for summer clothes

loans.name: Cecilia's Group

texts.en:
Cecilia R. is from the village of Villa Luna, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Cecilia is 24 years old and single. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for fattening and sale. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Cecilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia F. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Delia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for fattening and sale. Delia has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Delia joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Delia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her eighth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Mrs. Hem P., a 27-year-old resident of a rural commune in Phnom Penh City, works as a sewing laborer in a garment factory, a job she started when she was single. Now married to Vong Chantha, 29 years old and a temporary laborer, the couple has a young child who is already enrolled in school. Hem P. will be using her loan to buy a piece of a neighbor's village land. She is hopeful that this loan will provide her with additional income. 

Hem P. was busy when the photo taken, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a piece of a neighbor's village land.

loans.name: Adora

texts.en: Adora C. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 31 years old. Adora is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Adora owns and operates a business providing recycling services. The main source of income for the business comes from hauling junk and other waste material for local businesses and community members. Adora has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Adora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase scrap wood to sell. Adora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional waste and junk material to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Adora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional waste and junk material to sell

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en: Marlene H. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Marlene is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Marlene owns and operates a business providing transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a motorcycle-transport service. Marlene has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Marlene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Marlene is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the second loan taken out by Marlene from ASKI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en: Jerry G. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 22 years old. Jerry is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Jerry owns and operates a business providing transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a motorcycle-transport service. Jerry has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Jerry joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jerry has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Jerry is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the second loan taken out by Jerry from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Veang

texts.en:
T., a 31-year-old mother of four children, all young, is married to Hung, 34, who sells meatballs and other foods. T. has operated a door-to-door nail decoration service for the surrounding neighbors since 2005, earning a good income. Because her husband's business is doing so well, and in order to meet the growing financial needs of her family, T. is requesting a loan of $300 to buy more meatballs for Hung's enterprise.

T.'s husband is in the photo

loans.use: To buy more meatballs.

loans.name: Delgertuya

texts.en:
Delgertuya is 39 years old and a widow who lives with her two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. She operates a grocery store in her yard. Delgertuya has been operating this business since 2006 and has built a stable operation over the past four years.

However, her husband passed away and she was left to raise her two children. At that time it was hard for her to continue her work, but she has since worked diligently to grow her business to its current successful position. Her grocery store is in a good location and her business is stable. Delgertuya has been planning to purchase large amounts of products for her store to increase her sales. She is a very hard-working person and says, “I would like to expand my grocery store and to open a supermarket in future.” She is requesting a loan to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Isiwat

texts.en:
Isiwat is married with 2 children and they are both in primary school. She is 33 years old and lives with her husband in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells groceries, foodstuffs and drinks at retail price. She has been in the business for the past 15 years. She is very happy doing the business because with it she could support her husband in taking care of the family. 
She needs extra capital that will enable her expand her business and profitability. She is requesting for the loan amount of NGN50, 000 to purchase more groceries, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks you to all lenders

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, drinks and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Loh

texts.en:
M. sells fish door to door around her community. Everyday she gets up in the early dawn and hurries to the riverside to wait for the arrival of the fishing boats. She then makes haste to the market, where she sells her wares at suitable retail prices.

M., age 50, is the mother of four children. Her husband is 56 years old and works as a motor taxi driver, making approximately $4 per day. Three of their children are still young and living with them, and one is married. M. is very busy at her business activity due to there being many clients who require her fish.

To satisfy the needs of her customers and to generate more income, M. is looking for a $600 loan to accumulate more business capital.

loans.use: To accumulate business capital.

loans.name: Kototala Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kototala, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne  39 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Glofia, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce de bétail, des articles de boutique, de  poissons  etc.                                                                    
Ces femmes du groupe Kototala sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe), et le premier prêt fut correctement remboursé.
 Djeneba M. qui est un des membres du groupa Kototala compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des petits ruminants (chèvres, moutons).                                                                     
Elle s’approvisionne en bétail dans le village et  environnants et effectue sa vente au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement d’hommes revendeurs et bouchers venant des grands centres urbains.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
NB : Filly F. est absente de la photo pour raison de santé.
texts.en:
The women of the group Kototala are all married and average 39 years of age and six children each living in traditional extended families in Glofia City, Prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of kinship and community. And they do commerce in livestock, boutique items, fish, etc. They are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The first loan was properly repaid. Djeneba M., who is a member of the group, intends to use her loan for buying young ruminants (goats, sheep). She supplies herself with livestock in and around the village. Accepting cash and credit, she sells to a customer base composed essentially of men, retailers and butchers from large urban centers. She plans on making an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to cover day-to-day family expenses, and the rest will be reinvested in the businesses. Note: Filly F. is absent in the photo for health reasons.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying livestock

loans.name: 10.1.2 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Quế N. Thị (8) is a 44-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hóa. She is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 10.1.2 Nam Ngạn Group.

Quế is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Quế owns and operates a food stall.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling herbs and spices in the local community. Quế has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 5.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, Quế joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. As with her previous loan of 1.963.500 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women which was successfully repaid, her new loan of 4.248.000 VND will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan that Quế has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  Đỗ Thị Lửa (6) is a 65-year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

2.  B. Thị Đắc (7) is a 52-year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mas

texts.en:
Mas T. is 35 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than seven years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier or at the river, which is full of fishermen.

She married but then divorced her husband when her two children were very young. Mas T. uses her old motorcycle that has often broken down when she delivers her fish. She wants to replace her old motor but she doesn't have money to do that. This is why Mas T. decided to request a loan of $800 from Kiva's field partner, HKL.

loans.use: To replace her old motor.

loans.name: Chérifatou

texts.fr: Cette femme est une dame très sérieuse et dynamique, elle est veuve et a à sa charge ses 2 enfants. Pour subvenir aux charges de sa famille elle s’est lancée en 2008 dans le commerce de sacs de charbons de bois. Elle souhaite augmenter  ses recettes, pour cela elle doit augmenter son stock de marchandises raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 20 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This woman is very responsible and dynamic; she is a widow and is responsible for her two children. In order to provide for her family expenses, in 2008, she launched into the business of selling bags of charcoal. She hopes to increase her profits, and to do so she must increase her stock of merchandise. This is the reason she is asking WAGES for a loan to purchase 20 bags of charcoal.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bags of charcoal

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tièssiri de l’association Siguidialé, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 37 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Dioïla  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de tissus, des fruits et beaucoup d’autres articles divers.
Ces femmes du groupe Tièssiri sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. Minata Traoré qui est du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des pagnes wax et d’autres tissus à la mode.
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Dioïla et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Tièssiri group (part of the Siguidialé association) are all married. On average, they are 37 year-old and have three children; they all live in traditional extended families in the city of Dioïla of Dioïla prefecture, in the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through their families or as neighbors. They sell condiments, cloth, fruits and many other miscellaneous items. This is the first solidarity loan for these women from the Tièssiri group. Minata Traoré, one of the group members, intends to use her loan to purchase "pagnes wax" (bright West-African cloth) and other fashionable textiles. She purchases her inventory from Bamako and retails locally on the Dioïla market and in neighboring fairs, accepting cash or credit from a clientele made of both women and men. She expects to make an average monthly benefit of 35,000 CFA francs, which will mainly be used for the daily expenses of her family, the remainder being reinvested in her trade activities.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing purchase

loans.name: Marilou's Group

texts.en:
Marilou S. is from the village of Marabulig, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is the leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Marilou is 55 years old, married, and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2006, Marilou joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 36,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her ninth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lassissi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un homme marié et est père d’un enfant, il vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d’agoè zongo qui est un quartier périphérique et très animé de la ville de Lomé. Pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille, elle s’est lancée en 2008 dans le commerce des articles de quincaillerie, il a ouvert à cet effet sa propre boutique qu’il a appelé « Ets SALBAK & fils ». Le stock de marchandises dont il dispose actuellement ne lui permet pas de subvenir aux charges de sa famille raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 10 boîtes de faume, 4 cartons d’ampoules et de réglettes, 20 paquets de pointes d’acier, 10 boîtes de col à bois, 10 boîtes de peintures  et divers.
texts.en:
This gentleman is married and the father of one child. He lives with his family in the Agoè Zongo neighborhood, one of the very busy outlying areas surrounding the city of Lomé. To meet his family's needs, he began selling hardware in 2008. He opened his own shop which he calls « Ets SALBAK & fils » (Salbak and Son Enterprises). With his current stock of merchandise, he is unable pay his family's expenses. For this reason, he is seeking a loan from WAGES to buy ten boxes of « faume », four cartons of bulbs and lighting strips, twenty packets of steel nails, ten boxes of wood glue, ten boxes of paint, and other items.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hardware items

loans.name: Oluremi

texts.en: Oluremi sells text books at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 35 old, married with 4 children. Her eldest child is 11 years old and her children are excelling. She is requesting for a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more text books to sell .She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more text books to sell

loans.name: Margareth

texts.en: Margareth A. sells local gin to make a living in Ibadan, Oyo state. She loves this business because of the profits that she makes in the business. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is 44 years old, married with 6 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more local gin to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Mrs. Sen T. is a 46 year old married woman. She works very hard as a fresh fish seller inside the local market and typically earns around $3 per day. She currently has another financial earner in her husband, who is a building foreman. This couple is married without any children.

Recently, Sen T.’s husband received orders from some people to build their houses, but he cannot satisfy the needs of his customers because he lacks material to use for his building work. Because of that, Sen T. decided to pursue a loan for her husband to buy any accessory he requires.

loans.use: To buy materials for building.

loans.name: Odontuya

texts.en:
Odontuya is 25 years old, single and lives with her parents and sister in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house. Her younger sister attends a college. Odontuya operates a grocery store in her yard which is in an excellent location. She is a very hard-working person who has been operating her business since 2008 and has built a stable operation.

She started her business with working capital of 400,000 tugrugs (~293 USD). After years of successful operations, she has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 2,165,000 tugrugs (~1,583 USD) today. Odontuya has been planning to purchase large amounts of products for her store to increase her sales. She is requesting a loan to increase her inventory and to build storage.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and build storage

loans.name: Nenita's Group

texts.en: Nenita S. is from the village of Brgy. Bone South, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Nenita is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Nenita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Nenita raises crops. The main source of income for her business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Nenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the first loan taken out by Nenita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva G. is a happily married woman with four children who are in school. She is 46 years old and lives in Tombo, a rural area of Freetown, the capital city of Sierra Leone, where she sells medicines. Eva has been in this business for 10 years and loves this trade more than any other type of trade.

She joined LAPOSL in 2008 and has taken out three previous loans which she used to expand her business. Eva needs a new loan of 1,500,000 Leones to enable her to buy more medicines in the hope that she will earn a reasonable profit that will improve her life forever.

loans.use: To buy medicines to sell

loans.name: Fausate

texts.en:
Fausate sells foodstuffs like garri, rice and more for a living in Lagos. She is 40 years old, a widow with 4 children. She lost her husband some years back and since then she takes care of her children alone. She is very hard working and hopes to give the children the best in life. She has been in the business for over 10 years.
Fausate wants more stock in her shop in order to make more sales and profit. She is requesting for the loan amount of NGN50, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Olukayode

texts.en: Olukayode is a commercial motor cyclist and he loves his business dearly. He hopes to own a transport company in the future. He is 35 years old, married with 3 children. His wife sells medicines to also support their home. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase a motor cycle to boost his business. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a motor cycle to boost his business

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en:
Kehinde is a well-known business woman in her community due to her long time in the business: 23 years. She sells sarongs and drinks in her shop to earn a living. 

42-year-old Kehinde lives in Lagos, is married and has been blessed with three children. She hopes to expand her business by buying more sarongs and drinks to sell. She needs the loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more sarongs and drinks to sell. She promises to pay back her loan promptly and says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Spencer's Group

texts.en:
Spencer G., from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela, is the 24-year-old leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Spencer, who is single, owns and operates a motorcycle transport business providing transportation services to local community members. He is just starting this business. In 2010, he joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Spencer is now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Wassa Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Wassa, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 32 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Missiritou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de gâteaux, de macaroni, de céréales  et de pâte d’arachide.
Ces femmes du groupe Wassa sont à leur premier prêt solidaire  et Sadio C. du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter quelques sacs d’arachide afin de les transformation en pâte d’arachide.
Elle s’approvisionne généralement à Dioïla et environnants auprès des paysans  producteurs et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Dioïla et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée surtout de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Wassa group, all married, are on average 32 years old, have 3 children and all live in traditional extended families in Missiritou, in the subprefecture of Fana, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative district in the Republic of Mali). They met through family connections and sell cakes, macaroni, grains and peanut butter. This is the first group loan for the women of the Wassa group and Sadio C., of the group, plans to use her loan to buy several sacks of peanuts in order to make peanut butter. Sadio usually gets her supplies in Dioïla and the surrounding area, from small country farmers, and conducts her sales there as well, wholesale, retail and credit, in the Dioïla market and in nearby markets, to a customer base made up mostly of women. Sadio believes she will see an average monthly profit of 20,000 CFA francs, which will be used for the daily expenses of her family and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying peanuts

loans.name: C5256 Good Line Group

texts.en:
Wilson is 26 years old and is married with three children. He is the president of a group called “Good Line” and this group is commonly known in the business of selling a variety of goods such as clothes, foodstuffs, gasoline, etc. They have been in this business for about three years.

Wilson and his team are now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to satisfy the demand of their customers which keeps increasing beyond their financial capacity. With the use of this loan, Wilson and his team expect to earn more profits which, in turn, will be used for more reinvestment in their business.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods such as clothes, foodstuffs, gasoline, etc.

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguisseme, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 37  ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de la région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce de savon local, des produits cosmétique, des condiments alimentaires et des céréales.                                                                    
Ces femmes du groupe Djiguisseme sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire  et Kadiatou Diakité, la présidente du groupe, qui fait la fabrication de savon local compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une grande quantité de beurre de karité, de concombres et de papayes destinées pour la fabrication du savon local très apprécié par les clients. 
Kadiatou a bénéficié d’une formation par rapport à cette activité qui lui réussie bien et dans laquelle elle est très sollicitée et appréciée.                                                   
Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières sur place et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Dioïla et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguisseme group are all married. They are on average 37 year-old with four children. They all live in traditional extended families in the city of Dioïla, the prefecture of the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through their families and as neighbors and sell local soap, cosmetics, condiments and cereals. This is the third solidarity loan for these women of the Djiguisseme group. Kadiatou Diakité, the group's president, is active in the production of local soap. She intends to use her loan to purchase a large stock of shea butter, cucumbers and papayas for the production of her highly-appreciated local soap. Kadiatou has been trained in this activity, in which she has experienced a lot of success. She is in high demand and very well-regarded for it. She procures her raw material and retails locally on the Dioïla market and in neighboring fairs, offering cash or credit to a clientele comprising women and men. She expects to make an average monthly benefit of 40,000 CFA francs, which will be used against the everyday expenses of her family, with the remainder reinvested in her trade activities.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for the production of local soap

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognontala, composé de femmes mariées et d’une célibataire,  a une moyenne  d’âge de 34 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de la région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de commerce et de voisinage et font la restauration, le commerce des habillements, la location des robes de mariés et le maquillage des nouvelles mariées.                                          
Ces femmes du groupe Kotognontala sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire  et Fatoumata D. qui excelle dans la restauration compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, deux sacs de 100kg de riz, quelques kilos de tubercules (pomme de terre et igname) et des paquets de condiments alimentaires pour la restauration.
Elle s’approvisionne en produits sur place et  souvent à Bamako pour les produits rares. Elle effectue sa vente sur place dans le restaurant à Dioïla, au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The Kotognontala group is mostly composed of married woman, with one single. The women are on average 34 year-old, with an average of 2 children. They all live in traditional extended families in the city of Dioïla, the prefecture of the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through business and neighborhood proximities and work in food service, clothing retail, bridal dress rental and bridal makeup services. This is the fourth solidarity loan requested by these women of the Kotognontala group. Fatouamata D., who excels in food service, intends to use her loan to purchase two 100-kilo (220 lb) bags of rice, several kilos of tubers (potatoes and yam) and condiments packets for restaurants. She procures her stock locally and often in Bamako as well, for rarer products. She retails locally in her Dioïla restaurant, selling cash to a clientele of women and men. She plans on an average monthly benefit of 30,000 CFA francs to be used for her family everyday expenses, with the remainder being reinvested in her trade activities.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for a restaurant

loans.name: B. Adiatou

texts.fr: K. B. Adiatou est née en 1982 à Kétou au Bénin et est mariée à YOUSSOUF Idrissou, un comptable. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés et qui vivent ensemble avec leurs parents au quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a une dizaine d'année que la famille s'est installée dans ce quartier. Adiatou vient en aide à son mari grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Adiatou n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Adiatou mène comme activité, la vente de tissus, de bijoux, des sacs pour dames et des chaussures dans sa boutique située à Dandji.
