Adiatou s'approvisionne au Nigéria et à Lomé au Togo, deux États voisins du Bénin. Adiatou a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. La clientèle de Adiatou ne cesse d'augmenter, et Adiatou désire élever davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre aux multiples demandes de sa clientèle. C'est pour cette raison que Adiatou sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un autre crédit qui lui permettra d'accroître son pouvoir d'achat.
texts.en:
B. Adiatou K. was born in 1982 in Kétou in Bénin and is married to Idrissou Youssouf, an accountant. The couple has two children, who attend school and who live with their parents in the Dandji area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. The family moved to this area about ten years ago. Adiatou helps her husband thanks to the revenue she gets from her business. Adiatou only attended elementary school. In order to pay her bills, Adiatou sells fabric, jewelry, purses and shoes in her shop in Dandji. Adiatou stocks up in Nigeria and in Lomé in Togo, two neighboring states of Bénin. Adiatou has already benefited from two loans from ALIDé, and has repaid them both. Adiatou’s clientele continues to grow, and Adiatou wants to increase her level of business and better respond to the needs of her clientele. This is why Adiatou seeks another loan from ALIDé, which would allow her to increase her buying power.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, jewelry, and shoes

loans.name: Modinatu

texts.en:
Modinatu is a hard working woman and she sells for long hours to support her home. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She is happy in her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She is 32 years old, married with two children. Her children are doing well at school. Her husband also works to support their home.

Modinatu is requesting for a loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary sells spiritual items and drinks in her shop and she has been in this business for the past 15 years. She likes the business and she wants to increase and improve her business's profitability. She is 47 years of age and she has three children. Her husband is a pastor and they live in Lagos.

Mary hopes for a loan of NGN100,000 to purchase more spiritual items and drinks to sell. She thanks all lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more spiritual items and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Hilaria's Group

texts.en: Hilaria B. is from the village of Guayabal, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 47 years old. Hilaria is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Hilaria is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Hilaria runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Hilaria has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,600 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2007, Hilaria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hilaria is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Hilaria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Benjamin's Group

texts.en: Benjamin V. is from the village of Brgy. Manamtam, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 43 years old. Benjamin is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Benjamin is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Benjamin raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Benjamin has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Benjamin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benjamin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Benjamin is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan taken out by Benjamin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en: Leonora D., 47 years old, is a rice grower. She has two children with the eldest one aged 13. She currently tills a ½ hectare farm. She started farming in 1995. The reason she would like to apply for a loan is for business expansion. She is requesting a loan amount of 15,000 Philippine Pesos which she will use to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers. Leonora says that she likes CEVI services so much because they also offer micro-insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Joel

texts.en: Joel S., 39 years old and living in Sto. Nino South Cotabato, grows and sells rice so that he will be able to provide for his family’s needs. He has two children, the eldest aged 13, and wants them to be able to finish their studies. Joel hopes to expand his harvest and is therefore requesting a loan of Php15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy farm supplies. He likes CEVI’s program, especially the benefits he can get through its microinsurance program.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Herminio

texts.en: Herminio Y., 45 years old, is a farmer. He has a 1-hectare farm, which he has tilled for quite a long time now. He has six children. His eldest child is aged 21. As a father, he wants to provide his family with everything they need. He also dreams of growing his harvest to increase their income. He is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies. He said, “What I could say about CEVI is that they have a very good program because it really helps the poor in their livelihood”.

loans.use: To buy farm Supplies

loans.name: M. Germaine

texts.fr: B. M. Germaine est née le 29 Mai 1975 à Adjohoun, dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin. Germaine est une veuve vivant depuis une dizaine d’année à la zone des Ambassades à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Germaine a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Germaine vit seule avec ses enfants et assure donc seule, leurs différentes charges. Germaine n’a jamais été à l’école. Il y une dizaine d’année que Germaine mène comme activité la vente de boissons de SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie) et des vins de palme à son domicile. Germaine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et dans les dépôts de boissons. C’est une ancienne cliente deALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre prêts qui ont tous été bien remboursés.  Cependant, Germaine a été malade lors de son dernier crédit, mais ce problème ne l’a pas empêché de  bien rembourser son prêt. Germaine voudrait rehausser son activité et faire face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter auprès de ALIDé, un autre prêt.
texts.en:
M. Germaine B. was born May 29, 1975 in Adjohoun, in Benin's Ouémé department. Germaine is a widow, living for the past decade in the embassy zone in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Germaine has four children who are all in school. She lives alone with her children and thus must provide alone for their various expenses. Germaine never went to school. For ten years, Germaine has run a business out of her home in the sale of drinks from SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie [Beninese Brewery Society]) and palm wines. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Benin's international market, and from beverage warehouses. Germaine is a previous Alidé client, having already received four loans that have all been completely repaid. Though she was ill at the time of her last loan, this challenge didn't prevent her from fully repaying her loan. Germaine would like to build up her business and keep up with the increasing demand of her customers. That is what brings her to approach Alidé for another loan.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cases of alcoholic beverages and sweets

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Agricultural work

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en:
Iyabo is a single mother and lives in Lagos. She is 50 years old with 2 children and they are in primary school. She sells shoes, stocking and bags. She gets her goods through her sister who lives in abroad to buy and sell. She has a lot of costumers that patronize her due to good quality stuff which she sells. She also makes native caps which she exports for sales in overseas too. 
Iyabo is very kin about the growth of her business and that of her family. She hopes for the loan of NGN90, 000 to purchase more bags, shoes and stockings to sell in order meet the demand of her numerous customers. She expresses her joy to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags, shoes and stockings to sell

loans.name: Gemma's Group

texts.en:
Gemma Y. is from the village of Tandul, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is the leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Gemma is 37 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store inside the school campus. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food products inside the elementary school. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Awaou

texts.fr: Née en 1965 à Djougou au Nord du Bénin, B. Awaou est mariée à ADAM Maboudou et est mère de cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Awaou vit avec ses enfants et son mari à PK10, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis une dizaine d'année. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Awaou n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de sa famille, Awaou vend depuis environs dix sept ans, divers savons de lessive et de toilette à son domicile, et quelquefois de façon ambulante. Awaou s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits qui tous été bien remboursés. Awaou désire renforcer son activité et la diversifier également par la vente d'autres produits divers, ce qui lui permettra de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle et d'assurer un meilleur avenir à ses enfants. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter un autre crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1965 in Djougou in the north of Bénin, Awaou B. is married to Maboudou Adam and is a mother of five, some of whom attend school. Awaou has been living with her children and her husband in PK10, in the Sèmè-Podji commune, for about ten years. The couple shares the family’s financial responsibility. Awaou did not attend school. In order to meet her needs and those of her family, Awaou has been selling laundry detergent and soaps at home and elsewhere for about seventeen years. Awaou stocks up at Dantokpa, an international market in Bénin. She is a former client of ALIDé, having already taken advantage of five loans, which have all been repaid. Awaou wants to build up and diversify her business by selling other types of products, which will allow her to better meet the needs of her clientele and ensure a better future for her children. This is what brings her back to ALIDé.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of soaps, laundry detergent, sugar, and sardines

loans.name: Nilo

texts.en:
Nilo S. is 45 years old and lives in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. He has three children, the eldest of whom is 20. Nilo is a farmer whose main crop is rice. He owns the land he farms, and grows and sells rice to be able to provide whatever his family needs. He wants to be the best possible father to all his children and he hopes that they will be able to finish their studies.

Nilo would like to increase his harvest. He is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 from KIVA partner, Community Econonomic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm Supplies

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr:
A 40 cette femme reste une dame très dynamique, elle exerce depuis 2000 le commerce de détail de riz, d’haricots et d’huile.elle maîtrise bien la gestion de son commerce  grâce à son  expérience. Le stock dont elle dispose actuellement ne  lui permet de  satisfaire la demande de ses clients. Elle souhaite se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour achat de sacs d’haricots et de bidons d’huile.
Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants.
texts.en:
At 40 years old, this woman remains very dynamic. Since 2000, she has practiced the selling of rice, beans, and oil. She has mastered the management of her business due to her experience. Her available merchandise does not allow her to satisfy the demands of her clients. She would like to re-stock and is asking WAGES for her first loan to buy bags of beans and drums of oil. She is married and the mother of four children.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bags of rice, beans and oil

loans.name: Bisi

texts.en:
Bisi sells drinks and pepper soup in her shop and she has been in the business for the past 8 years. She does this to make a living in Lagos. She manages the business with the support of her children who assist her after school hours. 
She is married with 4 children and she is 43 years of age. She wishes to increase her business by having a better space where he can attend to her numerous costumers and sell drinks in wholesale in future. She is asking for the loan for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more drinks and pepper soup items to sell. She says thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and pepper soup items to sell.

loans.name: Didace

texts.en:
Didace is 51 years old and is married with four children. He owns a public secretariat shop where he operates the business of photocopying, typing via the use of a computer, etc. He has been operating this business for about four years and the hours of his business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Didace needs to request a Kiva loan with the purpose of purchasing some additional equipment like a scanner, one more computer, and a new, modern photocopying machine. With this additional equipment, he hopes to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow him to increase the size of his business through attracting a larger number of customers.

If the number of his customers keeps increasing, Didace hopes to create some other sources of income as well as creating jobs for the people in his community.

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment like a scanner, one more computer, and a new, modern photocopying machine

loans.name: Haminou

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un jeune homme célibataire, afin de subvenir à ses besoins quotidiens, il s’est lancé dans la vente de CD audio et vidéos. Il a commencé ce commerce en 2008 et s’approvisionne au Niger et en chine.  Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. La demande actuelle de sa clientèle est élevée, pour les satisfaire il sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour l’achat de divers CD audios et vidéos
texts.en:
This is a young single man who decided to go into selling audio CDs and videos in order to take care of his everyday expenses. He launched this business in 2008 and buys his stock in Niger and in China. He has a very broad customer base. As the current customer demand is growing, and he would like to be able to satisfy it, he is seeking his first loan from WAGES to buy various CDs and videos.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing CDs and videos for resale

loans.name: Delphine

texts.fr: B. Delphine est née en 1981 à Dangbo, dans le département de l'Ouémé au Bénin. Mariée à HINNOUHO Olivier, un menuisier, Delphine est mère de quatre enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Delphine vit avec sa famille au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis cinq ans environs. Delphine n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Il y a près de quatre ans que Delphine exerce comme activité, la vente d'ustensiles de cuisine, de façon ambulante. De façon secondaire, Delphine vend des tissus. Ces deux activités génèrent à Delphine des revenus qui l'aident à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants et à apporter ainsi une aide à son mari. Delphine achète ses articles à Lomé au Togo, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Delphine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Dans l'optique d'agrandir davantage son activité et d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire, Delphine sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Delphine B. was born in 1981 in Dangbo, in the Ouémé province of Benin. She is married to Olivier Hinnhouho, a carpenter, and is the mother of four children, some of whom are in school. Delphine has been living with her family in the Ayotrou district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for about five years. Delphine never went to school. Since about four years ago she has been selling kitchen supplies as a street vendor. In addition, she also sells fabrics. The income from these business activities allow Delphine to help provide for her children and be a support for her husband. Delphine purchases her sotck in Lomé in Toga and also in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Delphine is an old client of ALIDé and had three earlier loans, all of which were properly repaid. With the view towards enlarging her business and increasing her profits, Delphine is seeking a new loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing kitchen supplies and fabrics [for resale]

loans.name: Edueyovi

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de divers articles. Elle fait ce commerce depuis 2005. Elle est veuve et c’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’elle subvient aux charges de ses 3 enfants et aussi à  ses propres charges. Voulant gonfler son stock en baisse, elle sollicite  son premier crédit pour l’achat de fourneaux, houe, coupe-coupe, tisane et divers.
texts.en:
This woman makes her living retailing various articles. She has been doing this since 2005. She is a widow, and it is thanks to the income from her business that she is able to support her three children and herself. In order to replenish her diminishing stock of goods, she is seeking her first loan in order to purchase stoves, drag hoes, cutters, teapots and various others items.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing stoves, drag hoes, cutters, teapots etc for resale

loans.name: Ayobami

texts.en: Ayobami is a hard working woman and she sells for long hours to support her home. She sells pop corn at retail prices to her customers. She is happy in her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She is 42 years old, married with 2 children. Her children are doing well at school. Her husband also works to support their home. She is requesting for a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more pop corn to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pop corn to sell

loans.name: Mawulawoe

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est lancée en 2008 dans le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, elle est très dynamique ce qui fait qu’elle gagne tous les jours de nouveaux clients, actuellement elle fait face à une baisse de son stock, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de divers produits d’alimentation générale. Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. C’est avec ce qu’elle gagne de son commerce qu’elle contribue financièrement aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This lady began selling food products in 2008. She is very dynamic, which wins her new customers every day. Currently, her inventory is low, and for that reason she would like a loan from WAGES to build up her stock of food products. She is married with four children. With the earnings from her business, she helps to pay household expenses..

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products

loans.name: C2490 Abahujumugambi Group

texts.en:
Devotha is 40 years old. She is the president of this group called “Abahujumugambi” which is commonly known in the business of selling various styles of clothes. This is their 4th successful year in this business and their hours of operation are from 7 a.m. until late in the evening hours.

Devotha and her team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their business through adding different styles of clothes, mainly men’s jeans. She and her team hope that, with the use of this loan, they will earn more profits which, in turn, will allow each member of the group to start saving for his or her future.

loans.use: To buy different styles of clothes, mainly men’s jeans

loans.name: Aïchatou

texts.fr: Née en 1980 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Aïchatou est mariée à MIWAKOUNOU Frédéric, un commerçant. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Aïchatou vit avec ses enfants et son mari à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis sept ans environs. Aïchatou vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Aïchatou a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Aïchatou vend divers produits (savons, pâtes alimentaires, bombons, biscuits, galettes d'arachide, sachets, etc.) à son domicile. Aïchatou achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Aïchatou exerce cette activité depuis quatre ans et est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Aïchatou sollicite un nouveau crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui lui permettra de renforcer son activité et d'augmenter sa part de marché.
texts.en:
Born in 1980 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. A. Aïchatou is married to Mr. MIWAKOUNOU Frédéric, a merchant.  The couple has three children, some of whom are in school.  Aïchatou has been living with her children and husband in Agblangandan, in the town of Sèmè-Podji, for about seven years.  She helps out her husband and, along with him, ensures that the various family expenses are covered.  Aïchatou dropped out of middle school. To meet her needs, she sells various goods (soaps, pasta, candy, cookies, peanut cakes, little bags, etc.) out of her home.  She purchases her goods at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has been in this business for four years and is a former ALIDé client who indeed repays her loans.  Aïchatou is requesting a new loan from ALIDé that will enable her to bolster her business and to increase her market share. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods (soaps, pasta, cookies, matches, etc.)

loans.name: Kikelomo

texts.en:
Kikelomo own a shop where she sells drinks, sachet water and pepper soup to costumers and she has been in the business for the past 9 years. She is a member in LAPO micro finance with good repayment history. 
She is married with 4 children and she is 31 years old. Her husband works with a construction company and they reside in Lagos. She hopes for increase her business and profit. She is requesting for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more drinks, sachet water and pepper soup items to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders and LAPO micro finance for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, sachet water and pepper soup items to sell.

loans.name: Epimaque

texts.en:
Epimaque is 40 years old and is married with four children who are 2, 4, 6 and 11 years old. He is a self-employed businessman in the business of selling clothes, mainly jeans trousers. He has been in this business for about eight years and the hours of his business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m., every day except Sunday.

Epimaque is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing different styles of jeans as well as shirts. With the use of this loan, he hopes that his profits will increase. These additional profits will be used in paying school fees for his children and in renovating his house.

loans.use: To purchase different styles of jeans as well as shirts

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 29 years old and is married with one child who is two years old. Emmanuel is a hardworking businessman selling a variety of goods in his shop, mainly cosmetic goods like body lotion and soaps. This is his 3rd successful year in this business. Emmanuel opens his shop from early in the morning until late in the evening hours.

Emmanuel needs to request a Kiva loan with a purpose of expanding his shop to the extent that he can start wholesaling to the retailers. With this business expansion, he expects to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow him to start reinvesting in his business as well saving for the future.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods for his shop, mainly cosmetic goods like body lotion, soaps etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells drinks and pepper soup to earn her living and she has been in the business for the past 10 years. She is married with 6 children and she is 49 years of age. Her husband is a business man and they lives in Lagos. With the proceeds from the business she could assist her family financially. She wants to make more sales as this will boost her profit margin. She hopes for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more drinks and pepper soup items to sell. She thanks all lenders for their huge support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and pepper soup items to sell.

loans.name: Burayla Murzabekova Group

texts.ru:
Бурайла, является лидером этой группы. Ей 47 лет. Ее супруг работает водителем в кирпичном заводе. Ее сын на заработках в России, старшая дочь студентка, вторая дочь на заработках в России, младшая школьница. Она на данный момент готовит земли для посева, в основном выращивание и перепродажа картофеля и кукурузы. Бизнес был начат 25 лет назад, ранее выращивали табак. Кредит запрашивается для закупа минеральных удобрений.

Рахматилла, 41, лет. Его супруга домохозяйка. Сам клиент занимается строительными работами. Кроме этого у его семьи есть земельный надел, где они выращивают овощи. Кредит нужен для закупа минеральных удобрений.

Сооранай 42 года. Супруг в данное время находится на заработках в РФ. В данный момент она ведет бизнес самостоятельно (супруг и сын сейчас в России): занимается внутренне-отделочными работами. Она самостоятельно принимает заказы, за аккуратность в работе имеет большой спрос. На кредит она планирует купить скот.

Дилбар, замужем. Супруг, Кожомкул, зарабатывает на жизнь работая трактористом. Клиент готовит земля, к весеннему посеву. Кредит запрашивается для финансирования полевых работ.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Burayla is the leader of this group. She is 47 years old. Her husband works as a driver at a brick factory. Her son is a migrant worker in Russia; the oldest daughter is a college student; the second daughter is also a migrant worker in Russia; and the youngest attends school. At this time, Burayla is preparing the soil for planting. Her business mainly consists in growing and selling potatoes and corn now. This business was launched 25 years ago; previously they were growing tobacco. The loan is being requested for purchasing mineral fertilizers. Rahmatilla is 41 years old. His wife is a homemaker. He works in construction. In addition, the family has a land plot which they use for growing vegetables. The loan is being requested for purchasing mineral fertilizers. Sooranay is 42 years old. The husband is a migrant worker in Russia. At the moment she keeps the business by herself (as her husband and son are in Russia): she does interior home renovation. She herself accepts orders from clients and her business is popular because she is very thorough in her work. She plans to use her loan to buy cattle. Dilbar is married. Her husband, Kozhomkul, makes a living as a tractor driver. She is now preparing the soil for the spring planting. The loan is being requested in order to finance farming work.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Claire

texts.fr: D. Claire est née en 1986 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Claire est une célibataire qui n'a pas encore d'enfant. Claire vit donc seule et assure seule ses charges. Il y a près de seize ans que Claire s'est installée au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou. Claire n'a pas féquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Claire mène comme activité la vente de condiments de sauce et divers autres produits (pâtes alimentaires, conserves de tomate et de sardine, œufs, couscous, petits pois, etc.) au marché de Avotrou à Cotonou. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Claire achète ses différents produits. Claire exerce cette activité depuis trois ans et a déjà bénéficié de deux prêts qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Claire sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième prêt, qui lui permettra d'élever un peu plus le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
D. Claire was born in 1986 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is unmarried and has no children yet.  She therefore lives by herself and covers her own expenses by herself.  Nearly sixteen years ago, she settled in the Avotrou district in Cotonou.  Claire did not attend school.  To meet her needs, she has a business selling sauce condiments and a variety of other goods (pasta, canned tomatoes and sardines, eggs, couscous, peas, etc.) at the Avotrou market in Cotonou.  Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she purchases her different supplies.  She has been in this business for three years and has already benefited from two loans that she has repaid.  To cope with the more and more numerous demands of her customers, Claire is requesting a third loan that will enable her to raise her business level a bit more and to satisfy her customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a variety of goods (sauce condiments, pasta, canned foods, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, mulches and staking poles for his plantation

loans.name: Edelyn

texts.en:
Edelyn M., from the town of Surallah, is 36 years old and married to Dominador. To make a living, Edelyn plants and harvests corn for sale and also tends a retail shop. Engaged in her businesess for over 10 years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP a month. In 2010, Edelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting her first loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure, and plans to use any additional revenue generated to improve/expand her businesses and supplement family income.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Koffi Basile

texts.fr: Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce en détail des télévisions. Il s’approvisionne au marché  local du port autonome de Lomé où les articles sont moins coûteux, comme cela il réalise de meilleurs bénéfices sur ses ventes. Actuellement il n’a pas beaucoup de télévisions en stock raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 6 télévisions afin d’augmenter son stock. il est marié et père d’un enfant. C’est avec le revenu de ce commerce qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who operates an income-generating retail business selling televisions.  He stocks up at the local market at the Autonomous Port of Lomé where goods are less costly.  Thus, he makes a better profit on his sales.  Currently, he does not have many televisions in stock.  This is why he is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying six televisions in order to increase his inventory. He is married and the father of one child.  With the income from this commerce, he provides for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying TV's

loans.name: Erna

texts.en:
Erna G., from the town of Surallah, is 26 years old, married, and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Erna plants and harvests rice for sale. Engaged in her business for over six years, she earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Erna joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure, she plans to use any additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business and supplement family income.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Fields Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 38 years old and is married with four children who are 6, 10, 11 and 14 years old. She is commonly known in the business of selling different styles of clothes and this is her second successful year in this business, which she operates from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Catherine is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through adding different modern styles to her business. With these additional styles for sale, she hopes to earn more profits than previously which, in turn, will allow her to continue taking care of her family and keep reinvesting in her business for better progress. In addition, she will buy a cow for rearing at home.

loans.use: To add different modern styles of clothes to her store and a cow to raise at home

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma S., from the town of Surallah, is 38 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, for the past 12 years she has been raising pigs for fattening and sale, earning approximately 8000 PHP a month. In 2010, Thelma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 6000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies, she plans to use any additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Anne Marie

texts.fr: Née en 1952, O. Anne Marie vit depuis une vingtaine d'année au quartier Sainte Rita à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Anne Marie est une veuve qui est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Anne Marie vit donc seule avec ses enfants. Pour assurer ses charges, Anne Marie mène comme activité, la vente de maïs et de farine de manioc à son domicile. Anne Marie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, mais aussi à Sèhouè, un marché de vente de produits vivriers au Bénin. Anne Marie exerce cette activité depuis douze ans environs, et a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Dans l'optique de renforcer et d'augmenter la volume de son activité, Anne Marie sollicite un autre crédit de ALIDé, en vue de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1952, O. Anne Marie has been living for about twenty years in the Sainte Rita neighborhood of Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Anne Marie is a widow and the mother of two children, both in school. She lives alone with her children. To pay her expenses, Anne Marie sells corn and manioc flour from her home. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin, and also in Sèhouè, a Benin market selling food products. Anne Marie has been in business for about twelve years, and has already received three loans, all of which are fully repaid. In order to build up and increase the volume of her business, she is seeking another loan through ALIDé to better serve her customers' needs.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sacks of corn and of manioc flour

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth B., from the town of Surallah, is 47 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, for the past 10 years she has been planting and harvesting rice for sale, earning approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Lilibeth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure, she plans to use any additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Burombe Twimukye, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
N. Francis, aged 55 years, has been selling cows and goats to earn a living from Kakoma in Rukungiri area in western Uganda. In this case Francis deals with farmers directly to purchase their livestock and then finds ready markets for them.

Francis’s main drawback in the course of doing this business has been the unstable prices of cattle and low capital input. With determination and efficient customer care skills, he has managed to keep his business going for over ten years. In a month, he makes profits to the tune of 200,000 Ugandan shillings.

Francis’s future plans are to fully expand his transactions which will earn him more revenue to pay for his children’s education requirements. With this loan, he anticipates making great strides in achieving this dream.

loans.use: To restock the animals on his farm

loans.name: Sope Dabakh Group

texts.fr:
SOPE DABAKH est un groupement de 5 femmes commerçantes. Il est dirigé par Madame Ndondy B. âgée de 35 ans. Et il a été créé, il y’a tout juste 5 mois. Ces femmes se sont regroupées pour développer leur relation et s’entraider.
La présidente Ndondy B. est mère de deux enfants. Elle est commerçante de légumes au marché et gère également une table de légumes chez elle depuis 10 ans. En fait c’est un métier qu’elle a copie de sa maman qui vend jusqu’à présent des légumes au marché central de Thiès. Pour Madame Ndondy B. cette vente est prise pour aider son mari à la charge de la maison régler ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants.
Les autres membres du groupement sont :
-Madame Seynabou W. la trésorière vend des tissus Wax, Basin, Khartoum…… Elle est marchande ambulante depuis 10 ans.
-Madame Awa N. née en 1967 vend de l’huile, pâte d’arachide, poudre d’arachide (naflay) depuis 12 ans. Elle fait également la marchande ambulante.
-Madame Maguette W. est marchande ambulante de produits cosmétiques, parfums, sacs, chaussures depuis 4 ans 
-Madame Salimata L. âgée de 39 ans vend des produits cosmétiques et chaussures chez elle depuis 5 ans.
texts.en:
SOPE DABAKH is a group of 5 businesswomen. Its leader is Mme Ndondy B., 35 years old, and it was formed just five months ago. The women formed the group to develop their relationship and to help each other. Ndondy B. is the mother of two children. She sells vegetables in the market, and has also been selling them for ten years from a table at her home. She learned the trade from her mother, who still sells vegetables in the central market at Thiès. She engages in this business to help her husband manage their household and to take care of her famiL.'s needs. The other group members are: - Mme Seynabou W., the treasurer, who has been selling cloth (Wax, Basin, Khartoum……) door-to-door for ten years. - Mme Awa N., born in 1967,has been selling oil, peanut butter and ground peanuts naflay) for 12 years, also door-to-door. - Mme Maguette W. has been selling cosmetics, perfumes, bags and stockings door-to-door for four years. - Mme Salimata L., 39 years old, has been selling cosmetics and stockings from her home for five years.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is a trader, she sells foodstuffs, drinks and snacks in order to make earns meet. She opens her shop everyday from morning to late in the evening. She started the business 17 years ago and is doing well. She lives with her family in Lagos and she is married with 3 children. 
37 years old Ann hopes for the loan of NGN70, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs, drinks and snacks to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, drinks and snacks to sell.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia R. is from the town of Banga. She is 57 years old. Cecilia is married and has 10 adult-aged children. To make a living, Cecilia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over 27 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cecilia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Cecilia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Badenciana

texts.en:
Badenciana S. is a 59-year-old separated woman who supports her family by selling ready-to-wear clothes. She lives in Brgy. Banilad, Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental, with her two children, aged 34 and 39, who also have their own families.
Badenciana has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 2000. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her ready-to-wear business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 60,000 PHP.
Badenciana is now borrowing 19,500 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital for her business. This will be her 23rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 22,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Badenciana aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure its future wellbeing by following the 'Dungganon' way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Catherine

texts.fr: Née en 1958 à Calavi au Bénin, H. Catherine est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Catherine ne vit plus avec son mari. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Catherine  s'est installée au quartier Aïbatin à Cotonou,capitale économique du Bénin. Catherine vit seule avec son enfant et assure seule ses différentes charges. Catherine n'a jamais été à l'école. Depuis vingt ans environs, Catherine mène comme activité, la vente de maïs à son domicile. C'est à Banikoara, dans le Nord du Bénin, que Catherine achète ses produits. Catherine a bénéficié une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Catherine désire rehausser le niveau de son activité et accroître sa part de marché. Mais Catherine ne dispose pas d'assez de moyens pouvant lui permettre de réaliser son projet. C'est pour cette raison que Catherine sollicite pour une deuxième fois, le concours financier de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1958 in Calavi, Benin, Ms. H. Catherine is the mother of a child, who has attended school.  Catherine no longer lives with her husband.  About ten years ago, she settled in the Aïbatin district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She lives alone with her child and is covering her various expenses by herself.  Catherine never attended school. For about twenty years, she has been running a business selling corn out of her home.  She purchases her supplies in Banikoara, in northern Benin.  Catherine once benefited from a loan from ALIDé that she repaid.  She would like to enhance her business and to increase her market share.  But she doesn't have enough funds enabling her to carry out her plans.  For this reason, Catherine is requesting financial assistance from ALIDé for a second time.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn

loans.name: C1186 Ituze Group

texts.en:
Ladislas is 45 years old and is married with eight children who are between 7 and 23 years old. He is the president of a group called “Ituze” and this group is commonly known in the business of selling a variety of goods in their shop since 2000. Their shop is open from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Ladislas and his team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company with the purpose of expanding their business. They hope that the use of this loan will allow them to start wholesaling to the retailers. With this wholesaling, they will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow them to keep reinvesting in the business for better progress.

loans.use: To purchase of a large quantity of goods for their store

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina P., 47 years-old, is a married woman who supports her family by engaging in a general store and food vending businesses. She lives in Barangay Culipapa Hinobaan, Negros Occidental with her husband Morillo and their 6 children (14 to 27 years of age). One child is married already and has 2 children.

Avelina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000.

Avelina is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can continue her general store and food vending businesses. This will be her 10th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Avelina aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Ilisaeva's Group

texts.en:
Ilisaeva A. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Balykchi, A.. She is 36 years-old and married with seven children: four sons and three daughters. Three sons and two daughters study at school and the others are preschool age. A. does not work outside the home and looks after the children. Her husband works in a furniture store. Nine years ago he began to take orders for making furniture and the initial amount of this business activity was 15,000 soms (aprx. $325.8). Due to this profit, they opened their own store, bought a computer and their monthly income is now 30,000 soms (aprx. $651.60). With money received from this loan, A. plans to pay for her elder son's school graduation.   In the future they plan to expand the business and to educate their children.

Muzakanova M. is 38 and married with three children: two daughters and a son. All the children study at school. M. works as an implementer in a store, she earns 3,000 soms (aprx. $65.15) per month. Her husband works an architect and his salary is 5,000 soms (aprx. $108.57). In 2005, with an initial sum of 5,000 soms (aprx. $108.57) they opened a photo salon. Thanks to this activity they earn an addition 5,000 soms (aprx. $108.57) and they have been able to buy a computer and furniture for their home. With money received from this loan, they plan to purchase a printer. In the future, they would like to buy a flat in Bishkek.

Zhumaeva A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 42 and married.  She has two sons and a daughter. The older son is a student and the others study at school. A.'s husband works on the railway, so he earns 6,000 soms (aprx. $130.30) per month. A. works at the railway station too and her salary is 4,000 soms (aprx. $86.90). 10 years ago, with an initial amount of 10,000 soms (aprx. $217.15) they bought five heads of small cattle, fattened them and they were resold.  As a result, they increased their number of livestock and they now have 15 heads of small cattle. Thanks to this activity they make an addition 3,000 soms (aprx. $65.15) per month. A. would like a loan to buy three heads of small cattle for an amount of 9,000 soms ($195.44).

Rysalieva G. is 63.  She is married and has raised two sons. The older one is 33 and works a painter. The other one is unemployed. G. does not work outside the home but takes orders for sewing national products. Two years ago with an  initial amount of 1,000 soms ($21.72) she began to take orders from neighbours and was able to make home repairs. Now she wants a loan to purchase fabrics. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Kiva partner Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan which delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/about Partner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To pay for graduation at school.

loans.name: Lucie

texts.en:
Lucie is 47 years old and is married with seven children with ages 7, 11, 13, 15, 17, 19 and 23 years old. She has been a self-employed businesswoman selling sorghum for about three years and the hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Lucie needs to request a Kiva loan with the purpose of having a large stock of sorghum and, in addition, she plans to start selling a variety of drinks, mainly those made from sorghum as well as soda, Primus (a variety of commercial beer), etc.

With these additional drinks for sale, Lucie will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow her to continue taking care of her children and keep reinvesting for a strong business.

loans.use: To buy a large stock of sorghum and drinks to sell

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia G. is a 43 year-old woman living in the village of Hda. Ester, Barangay Rizal, Sagay City. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns & operates a restaurant serving local foods to customers in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in this business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2002, Virginia joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from NWTF. Virginia is now requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 13th loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF.  Virginia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional inventory and working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa G. is a 44 year old year-old woman living in the town of Libertad, Escalante, Negros Occidental.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To make a living, Elsa owns & operates a sari sari store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste and other basic commodities in the local community.  Elsa has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In December 13, 2005, Elsa joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from NWTF. Elsa is now requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 10th loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF.  Elsa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: M. Ebiyi

texts.fr: A. M. Ebiyi est née le 08 Janvier 1956 à Adjohoun, dans le département de l'Ouémé au Bénin. Mariée à KOUHOUMBO Abdou, un menuisier, Ebiyi est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Seulement, deux des enfants restent encore à la charge du couple. Il y a près de dix huit ans que Ebiyi réside au quartier Abattoir à Cotonou. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Ebiyi n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Ebiyi  vend des produits vivriers et des céréales à son domicile. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à subvenir à ses besoins. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Ebiyi achète ses produits. Ebiyi a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué le remboursement. La clientèle de Ebiyi s'accroît de plus en plus et Ebiyi voudrait renforcer son activité pour mieux les satisfaire ; raison pour laquelle Ebiyi sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
ADIDJEDAM M. Ebiyi was born on January 8, 1956 in Adjohoun, in the Ouémé department of Benin. Married to KOUHOUMBO Abdou, a carpenter, Ebiyi is the mother of six children, all in school. However, only two of the children are still in the care of the couple. For almost eight years Ebiyi has lived in the Abattoir neighborhood of Cotonou. The couple pays the various family expenses jointly. Ebiyi only attended elementary school. For about ten years she has been selling food products and grains from her home. This business generates income which helps her to meet her needs. Ebiyi gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin. Ebiyi has received one loan through ALIDé and has repaid it fully. Her clientele grows ever larger, and Ebiyi would like to build up her business to better satisfy her customers. This is why Ebiyi is seeking a second loan.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grain

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: D. Julienne est née en 1983 à Dogbo au Bénin. Mariée à AGBOGBONON Edouard, Julienne est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Julienne vit avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis près de trois ans. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Julienne n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis sept ans environs, Julienne vend des condiments de sauce (tomate fraîche, oignons, piments, etc.), mais aussi des produits vivriers (maïs, haricot, etc.) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Julienne s'approvisionne. Julienne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Julienne désire rehausser le niveau de son activité et se faire plus de profits. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Julienne D. was born in 1983 in Dogbo, Benin. Married to Edouard AGBOGBONON, she is the mother of three children who are all attending (or have attended) school. For the past three years, Julienne has been living with her husband and children in the Djeffa borough of the Sèmè-Podji commune. The couple shares responsibility for family expenses. Julienne has not attended school. For the past seven years she has sold sauce condiments (fresh tomatoes, onions, hot peppers, etc.) from her home, as well as fresh produce (corn, beans, etc.). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Julienne is a regular client of ALIDé, having already been granted three previous loans, all fully reimbursed. Faced with increasing customer requests, she wishes to increase the level of her activity and make more profit. This is why she is requesting a fourth loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy condiments, corn and beans

loans.name: Seelawathi

texts.en:
Seelawathi is a 41-year-old married woman living in the town of Telijjawila, part of the Matara area of Sri Lanka.  She has five children: two sons and three daughters ranging from age five to sixteen.

Seelawathi has requested a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to assist in her husband's business. He sells vegetables and fruits, such as coconuts.  She helps her husband, and they have been doing this business for twenty years.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To support the vegetable business

loans.name: Laxmi Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi Kumari T. is the grocery storekeeper in the town of Chetrapati, Kathmandu. She opens her grocery store three years ago to uplift the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of goods such as rice, maize, biscuits, noodles, snacks, etc. in her shop. Due to the increasing demand for grocery goods, she is requesting a Rs 25,000.00 loan to buy different varieties of grocery goods for her shop.

Mrs. Laxmi Kumari T. lives in a single family with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Prem T., is a house painter. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade six and her daughter is studying in grade nine.

loans.use: To buy goods.

loans.name: Siriyawathi

texts.en:
Siriyawathi is a 52-year-old  woman living in Telijjawila, part of the Matara district of Sri Lanka, with her husband and three children.  She has one son and two daughters, and they are ages 31, 28, and 26 years old.

Siriyawathi has managed her tea leaf business for three years.  She buys tea leaves from a tea factory, then packages and sells them to her customers. 

She has requested a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her business by purchasing more tea leaves.

Thank you for taking time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy tea leaves

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses opened his retail business seven months ago.  He sells dry foods in small quantities in an open air shed.  They include cereals such as beans, sugar, flour and salt.  He also sells a small amount of fruit.  He is 25 years-old, married to Faith Odhiambo and they have three school going children.

Moses was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to buy more products in bulk which he will sell in small quantities to his customers. The products include maize, beans, flour and sugar.

In the near future, he plans to move into a more permanent structure.

loans.use: To buy food to resell.

loans.name: Georgette

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, F. Georgette est mariée à FAGNIHOUN Sébastien, un chauffeur. Le couple a huit enfants, tous scolarisés, mais aucun d'eux ne vit encore avec leurs parents. Il y a près de trente deux ans que Georgette habite le quartier Dandji à Cotonou, avec son mari. Georgette vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges familiales. Georgette n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis trente ans environs, Georgette commercialise divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, savons, lait, mayonnaises, conserves, insecticides, condiments de sauce, etc.) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Georgette achète ses produits. Georgette a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé auprès de ALIDé. Georgette sollicite un deuxième prêt afin de renforcer son activité et d'accroître sa part de marché.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Georgette F. is married to Sébastien FAGNIHOUN, a driver. The couple have eight children, all attending (or having attended) school, but none still live with their parents. About 32 years ago Georgette and her husband settled in the Dandji borough of Cotonou. She helps her husband and shares family expenses with him. Georgette has only attended primary school. For thirty years she has retailed from her home a variety of products (pasta, soap, milk, mayonnaise, canned goods, insecticides, sauce condiments, etc.). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Georgette has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which she repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan to boost her commercial activity and increase her market share.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products (sardines, milk, pasta, flatbread, etc.)

loans.name: Euphrasie

texts.fr: Née en 1953 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, T. Euphrasie vit depuis 39 ans environs au quartier Dandji à Cotonou. C'est une veuve qui est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés et qui ne sont plus à sa charge. Euphrasie n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins, Euphrasie prépare et vend de l'akassa (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Euphrasie achète ses matières premières. Euphrasie avait obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué les remboursements du crédit.Euphrasie voudrait préparer plus d'akassa par jour, pour mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. C'est pour cette raison que Euphrasie sollicite un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1953 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. T. Euphrasie has been living for 39 years in the Dandji district in Cotonou.  She is a widow and the mother of six children, who have all had schooling and are no longer in her care.  Euphrasie never attended school.  To meet her needs, she makes and sells akassa (a local food made from corn starch) out of her home.  Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she purchases her ingredients.  Euphrasie had once obtained a loan from ALIDé and has accomplished the repayment of the loan.  She would like to make more akassa each day in order to cope with the customer demand and to increase her sales.  For these reasons, Euphrasie is requesting a second loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn for making akassa

loans.name: God Do It For Me Group

texts.en:
Annie K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Do It For Me. She is 53 years old, married, and has eight children who range in age from 12 to 34 years old. She was not privileged to attend school, due to poverty.

For six years, she has been selling charcoal in Congo Town on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more charcoal. Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Annie is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Marcelline

texts.fr: T. Marcelline est née le 10 Mars 1979 et est mariée à BALOGOUN Christophe, un instituteur. Marcelline a deux enfants dont un est scolarisé. Marcelline vit avec sa famille au quartier Tokplégbé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a environs sept ans que Marcelline s'est installée dans ce quartier. Marcelline vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges familiales. Marcelline n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Marcelline vend de la farine de blé et de l'huile d'arachide à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Marcelline vend du charbon de bois en détail. Marcelline s'approvisionne à Savè, dans le département des Collines au Bénin. Marcelline a déjà obtenu une fois de prêt à ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Marcelline sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Ms. T. Marcelline was born on March 10, 1979 and is married to Mr. BALOGOUN Christophe, a grade school teacher.  She has two children, of whom one is in school.  Marcelline lives with her family in the Tokplégbé district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She settled in this district about seven years ago.  She helps out her husband and, along with him, ensures that the various family expenses are covered. Marcelline attended primary school only.  To provide for herself, she sells wheat flour and peanut oil out of her home.  Secondarily, she sells charcoal retail.  She gets her supplies in Savè, in Collines County, Benin.  Marcelline once obtained a loan from ALIDé and has repaid it.  With the goal of bolstering her business and coping better with customer demand, she is requesting a second loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of wheat flour, oil, and charcoal

loans.name: Laban

texts.en:
Laban has been a farmer in Naivasha for the last three years.  He is 21 years-old and married to Grace Sangaile.  They have a year old baby.

Laban was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan to buy seedlings, plough his land and plant crops such as potatoes and maize during this rainy season.

He plans to increase his yield by cross cropping in future.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, prepare the land and plant.

loans.name: Belthilde

texts.en:
Belthilde is 32 years old, married with 6 children who are 3, 6, 8, 11, 13, and 15 years old.  Belthilde is widely known in the business of selling different styles of clothes as well as women's shoes.  Belthilde has been in this business for about 1 year and the hours of her business are from 7 am to 6 pm every day except Sunday.

Belthilde is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing some additional styles of clothes and shoes for sale to her customers.  With this additional business, Belthilde hopes that she will earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting and start saving for her future.

loans.use: The purchase of different styles of clothes as well as shoes for women

loans.name: Kagongi Bakyara Twimukye, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
They say that hard work pays, and a very determined M. Mable has gained from the fruits of her hard work. Having started up her hotel (restaurant), bar and lodging enterprise six years ago in Rubaare, a common stopover for long-route drivers from Rwanda, Mable has no regrets.

Due to Mable’s good management and esteemed customer care, her business has maintained customers for a long time, thus creating the hotel a good market. With this loan, she wants to put in place a pool table, as it is a favorite game for many, and also make repairs to broken beds in the lodge. This will enable her to earn more profit and be able to cater for her four fatherless children’s requirements.

loans.use: To purchase a pool table and repair broken beds

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David has been using his motorbike as a means of transport in Naivasha town for the last seven years, ferrying people and goods from one place to another.  He is 27- years old.

He was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend and this will be his first loan from them.  Earlier, he borrowed Kshs 15,000 which he paid well and on time.  He wants to open a retail shop with the proceeds from this current loan and he will operate it on the side to increase his income.

In the future, he plans to buy a pick-up which he will use to transport farm products to the market.

loans.use: To open a retail shop.

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine is 46 years old, married with 5 children who are 8, 16, 19, 22, and 23 years old.  Seraphine has been working hard selling drinks made out of sorghum and this is her 14th successful year in this business.  The hours of her business are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.  

Seraphine is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to satisfy her customers.  With this loan, she will also buy some food supplies mainly cakes, breads and some other pastries.  In addition, she will start also selling some milk.  With this, she hopes that her customers will eat and drink well.
