If successful, Seraphine will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to continue providing more food for her family and paying school fees for her children.

loans.use: The purchase of food supplies mainly cakes, breads and some other pastries for resale

loans.name: Help To Help Group

texts.en:
Moses B. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Help To Help. He is 42 years old, married, and has five children who range in age from 1 to 13 years old. He also cares for a sibling. He is presently a college student.

For 10 years, Moses has been selling provisional goods like sugar, milk, coffee, tea, tissue, etc. at Pipeline Road in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells the goods that his clients demand, which keeps them returning. Moses started by selling for other business people but later decided to do his own business.   
He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more milk, sugar, coffee and other provisions. His goal is to grow his business and to educate his children so as to have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Moses is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more milk, sugar, coffee and other provisions.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farming tools and expand her banana plantations

loans.name: Leposo

texts.en:
Leposo has been in farming for the last 16 years.  He plants potatoes and wheat depending on the season throughout the year.  He is 36 years old, married to Alina Maletu, and they have three school-going children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to buy pesticides and also cultivate his other piece of land to plant wheat.

In the future, he plans to buy another piece of land and be a large scale farmer.

loans.use: To buy pesticides and cultivate an adjacent piece of land to plant wheat

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: Aminat sells bottles of wine, canned drinks and juice at retail prices to make a living. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is 38 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She hopes to excel in her business and family life. She is requesting for a loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more bottles of wine to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bottles of wine to sell

loans.name: Petronille

texts.en:
Petronille is 44 years old, married with 7 children.  Petronille works hard at selling a variety of goods in her shop.  Those goods include soaps, body lotion, cooking oil, toilet paper, etc.  Petronille has been in this business for about 6 years, and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 8 pm every day except Sunday.

Petronille needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company, which hopefully will allow her to expand her shop through purchasing a variety of goods such as sugar, rice, beans, different types of flour, etc… She will also sell some drinks like sodas, juice.  With this expansion, Petronille will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will be used for the further reinvestment in her business and saving for the future.

loans.use: The purchase of a variety of goods such as sugar, rice, beans, etc.

loans.name: Llegando Lejos 1 Group

texts.en:
Ana, 21, is the coordinator of her group Llegando Lejos (Going Far), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding El Seibo, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their children.

Ana is excited to be taking her sixth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling Empanadas (a fried treat usuallly involving meat or cheese encased in fried dough). She will be purchasing cooking oil, flour, meat, cheese and a freezer to store it in. She will use the profits to buy school supplies for her children and for saving towards, one day, owning her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase meat, cheese, cooking oil, flour and a freezer.

loans.name: Saidi

texts.en: Saidi O. sells shoes to make a living. He hopes to own a shoe factory in the future. He is a hard working man and he sells for long hours to support his home.  He is 29 years old, married with a child. He hopes to give his child quality education. He is requesting for a loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more shoes to sell.  He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Monique

texts.en:
Monique is 29 years old, married with two children.  Monique has been and still is working hard at the business of selling clothes.  This is third successful year and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Monique is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing some other attractive clothing styles for sale as well as additional sizes.  With this loan, Monique hopes to attract more customers in her business and hopefully earn more profits in the process.  This, in turn, will allow her and her devoted husband to buy a house they have long dreamed of owning as well as allowing her to provide more and better food for her family and dependents.

loans.use: purchasing some other attractive clothing styles for sale as well as additional sizes

loans.name: Seun

texts.en: To make a living in Ibadan, Seun sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because she has the opportunity to be self employed and also to be able to support her home from the profits she makes in the business. She is 42 years old, married with a child 5 years. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She is requesting for a loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more medicines to sell.  She say thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 56 years old, married with three children who are 24, 26, and 35 years old.  Marie is widely known as a self-employed businesswoman selling a variety of goods in her shop mainly tomatoes, juice, soda, biscuits, etc.   She has been working hard at this business for about 5 years and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

After realizing that a large number of her customers were suggesting to her to sell foodstuffs, mainly rice, Irish potatoes, and beans, Marie decided to request a Kiva loan so that she can satisfy the demand of her customers through selling the above-mentioned goods.  With this additional business, Marie will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business as well as taking care of her family.

loans.use: The purchase of foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Funmilayo

texts.en: Funmilayo is 39 years old, married with 3 children. Her eldest child is 10 years old while the youngest child is 3 years old. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. She sells frozen foods like chicken and turkey to earn a living. She is requesting for a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Nyamishamba Twetungure A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Operating a retail shop alongside tea growing is a formidable business venture that has seen B. Ezra manage life to this day in Nyamishambya, Kihihi.

It is always difficult for many youth here in Uganda to settle for farming rather than spending time drinking alcohol and gambling, but Ezra is now different in economic terms. Having gotten a little capital to start up his retail business that fetches him 240,000 monthly, he is seeking a loan to expand his business into a wholesale operation and to purchase enough stock since there is a ready market from customers.

loans.use: To  purchase more stock and transform his business into a wholesale operation

loans.name: Ayinla

texts.en: Ayinla sells smoked fish and ice fish, this serve as her means of livelihood and she has been in the business for the past 7 years. Ayinla is very happy with the growth of her business but she still want to increase it. She is married with 6 children and she is 40 years. Her husband sells vehicle tyre and lives together in Lagos. She asking for the loan amount of NGN70, 000 to purchase more smoked fish and ice fish to sell. She thank all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more smoked fish and ice fish to sell.

loans.name: We Are One Group

texts.en:
Mae-Mae N. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called We Are One. She is 42 years old, single, and has two children who are 15 and 21 years old. She was only able to attend school through the 12th grade.

For five years, she has been selling soap and drinks on Mechlin Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 43,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more soap and drinks. Her goal is to grow her business and to continue supporting her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mae-Mae is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more soap and drinks.

loans.name: Dasola

texts.en: Dasola sells kerosene and VCDs at retail prices to her customers. With these combined businesses, she hopes to make her business more sustainable. She is 40 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is a teacher and he also supports their home.  Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy as a mother. She is requesting for a loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Ubumwe Group

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is 33 years old, married with two children of 2 and 10 years old.  Jean Bosco is the president of a group called UBUMWE and this group is widely known for selling food in their small restaurant.  This restaurant is open from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Jean Bosco and his team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company with the purpose of renovating as well as increasing the size of their business site. In addition, they will buy some needed equipment such as plates, saucepans, chairs for customers, etc.  With the use of this loan, Jean Bosco and his team hope to earn more profits, which in turn will allow them individually to build a secure future for their families and buy some domestic animals for rearing.

loans.use: The purchase of equipment such as plates, saucepans, chairs, etc.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia K. is 46 years old and married to Haron Kipsomet. They live in Kabarnet and have four children.

Julia makes cakes which she later sells at a profit. She started this business three years ago and every month the business yields a profit of 15,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). Her husband’s salary brings in an additional income of 8,000 KES every month. Her business is in the Kasoyo Women’s Building and her clients are supportive and faithful.

Julia had borrowed another loan from another bank before she joined KADET. She came to know of KADET through one of our clients. She has borrowed a loan of 80,000 KES which she plans to use to buy ingredients for her cake baking business. If this loan boosts her business, she will use the extra profit to add stock and expand her business further.

She has hopes to enlarge the business and open a bakery. She also dreams of owning a car of her own.

Julia describes herself as hardworking, polite, faithful, and God fearing.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for cake production

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort describes herself as lovely and caring woman. She has been trading in groceries for the past 7 years, selling assorted groceries like candies, rice, biscuits, bottled water, toiletries, etc. Currently, Comfort operates her business in a rented metal container in her community. She is excited to be taking out this loan so that she can purchase large quantities of groceries that will help her meet customers demand at all times. Comfort dreams of generating enough profits to build a bigger store and sell groceries wholesale.
 
In addition to being a vibrant entrepreneur, Comfort is also the mother of four children of ages 27-40 years old. She is a widow and through hard work, she has been able to support all her children through tertiary institution.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries in bulk

loans.name: God Fearing People Group

texts.en:
Delvina K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Fearing People. She is 33 years old, married, and has three children who range in age from 3 to 10 years old. She was only able to attend school through the 11th grade but has decided to continue to the adult education program soon.

For 5 years, Delvina has been involved in hairdressing and sales of ladies handbags at the Jacob’s Town Market, Chicken Farm community in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells goods that customers demand, which keep them returning.

Delvina started by working in a beauty salon. She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more handbags and hairdressing products. Her goal is to grow her business and to import hairdressing products to Liberia.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Delvina is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more ladies' handbags and hairdressing products.

loans.name: Fe Y Amor 6,7 Group

texts.en:
Yanira is the coordinator of her group, Fe y Amor (Faith and Love), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the economy is based around the sugar cane harvest and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, rented structure with her long term partner and two children.

Yanira is excited to be taking her sixth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a general store by purchasing flour, cooking oil, charcoal and clothes to stock her store. She will use the profits to save towards her dream of owning her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase flour, oil, charcoal, clothes to sell.

loans.name: Jotham

texts.en:
Jotham is 40 years old and he is still single.  Jotham is widely known for his business of ICT; he has been in this business for a long time ago and the hours of his business are from 6 am to 7 pm every day.

Jotham is now requesting a Kiva loan with the purpose of expanding his business through purchasing more computers, which in turn will allow him to increase the number of his customers as well as the profits earned.  With the use of this loan, Jotham will also create more jobs for the people from his community and if his profits keep increasing, he will create many sources of income.

loans.use: The purchase of more computers

loans.name: Olubola

texts.en: To make a living in Ibadan, Olubola sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because she has the opportunity to be self employed and also to be able to support her home from the profits she makes in the business. She is 40 years old, married with a child 4 years. Her husband is a teacher and he also supports their home. She is requesting for a loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She say thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Andre

texts.en:
Andre is 42 years old, married with 2 children.  Andre is widely known in the business of selling foodstuffs mainly beans, peas, wheat, etc.  He has been in this business for about two years and the hours of his business are from 7 am to 5 pm every day.

Andre is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company, which will allow him to increase the quantity of foodstuffs for sale as well as the number of his customers.  With this additional quantity of foodstuffs, Andre will earn more profits which in turn will hopefully be used in taking care of his family and reinvesting in his business for better financial stability.

loans.use: increasing the quantity of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke sells foodstuffs and groceries at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a shopping mall in the future. She is 50 years old, married with 5 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and groceries to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and groceries to sell

loans.name: Olapade

texts.en: Olapade sells mouth watery Nigerian cooked foods. She has been in this business for long and she is popularly known as ‘mama put’ in her community. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to see her business and family life make progress. She has been in this business for long. She is 43 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She is requesting for a loan amount of N50, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Nyamishamba Twetunjgure B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
As they say that determination is the key to success, T. Ketty, happily married with five children, ventured into tea growing in Nyamishamba, Kihihi, six years ago.

It was after working in a tea factory that Ketty developed an interest in growing and selling tea leaves. Her main hindrance is having few seedlings. Therefore, with this loan, she looks at expanding her tea plantation through buying more seedlings and doing it on a large scale. This will improve her sales and enable her to take care of her family needs.

loans.use: to purchase more tea seedlings to expand her plantation

loans.name: Mariah Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Rose is a 36-year-old widow who takes care of four children. Because of the minimal capital she makes out of her seven-year-old boutique business in Mukono, she has not been able to fully educate her children. She has been hardworking, however, as she currently makes close to 70,000 shillings.

Rose’s strong customer care skills have really played into her hands as customers keep on patronizing her boutique. With this loan, she is upbeat that she will be able to buy more stock for her business. She wants to buy new clothes for her boutique.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for her boutique

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace sells groceries, foodstuffs and electrical materials at retail prices. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. With these combined businesses, she hopes to make her business more sustainable. She is 38 years old, married with 2 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 33 years old, married with two children who are 7 and 18 years old.  Beatrice is a self-employed businesswoman wholesaling sacks of Irish potatoes, and she has been in this business for a long time.  The hours of her business are from early morning until late in the evening hours.

With the problem of not being able to satisfy the demand of her customers, Beatrice is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company which will allow her to increase the quantity of Irish potatoes she can sell.  With this additional quantity, Beatrice expects to earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to be financially stable and continue taking good care of her family.

loans.use: A large quantity of Irish potatoes

loans.name: Umaja Ni Nguvu Group

texts.fr:
Bubenga A. est présidente du groupe de crédit  Umoja ni nguvu, elle lève sa main sur la photo, avec son contrat de crédit à main au fond derrière, cliente au 4e cycle de crédit, âgée de 46 ans, veuve, mère de 2 enfants filles, toutes ont déjà leurs propres foyers, elles poursuivent convenablement leurs études bien avec l’appui de leurs époux.  Son mari est décédé en 1994 par ignorance et imprudence de la famille. La veuve Bubenga A. dit-elle au lieu d’aller se faire soigner dans un hôpital formel, sa belle famille avait préféré amener son défunt mari auprès d’un féticheur  marabout (tradi- praticien), chose qui a compliqué sa santé et lui fut conduit à la mort précocement. 
La veuve Bubenga A. vend des  légumes (sombe (feuilles de manioc), épinards, amarantes, tomates, aubergine, etc. Elle expose ses produits dans le petit marché du quartier Mapendo-Birere et parfois devant des dépôts de corporation. Elle a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre. Son capital initial était 70$, puis elle fut informée de l’IMF Hekima qui donne des crédits aux pauvres sans aucune garantie, delà, elle a trouvé son 1er crédit de renforcement.
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Bubenga A. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant des légumes qu’elle pourra revendre.
Le grand défi de la veuve Bubenga A. est relatif c'est-à-dire le contraste est que pendant la période de pluie,  les légumes chutent les prix, étant donné qu’ils sont en quantités suffisantes sur le marché. Lors de sécheresse, il y a pénurie des légumes. Malgré tout cela, les consommateurs (clients, population) achètent et la veuve Bubenga A. y tire son maximum de bénéfice.
La veuve Bubenga A.  s’est décidée  de faire la garde de  sa mère biologique (grand-mère de ses filles) qui est devenue trop vielle. Elle reste à ses cotes pour l’assister et prendre à charge d’autres orphelins de sa famille élargie en situation difficile. Aussitôt que son chiffre d’affaire augmente, elle préférerait changer son activité et aller s’approvisionner  des pagnes (habits femmes congolaises) dans la ville de Bukavu, chef lieu de la province du Sud Kivu.
En outre la veuve Bubenga A. souhaiterait dans le futur, construire une maison dans sa parcelle qui est située dans le quartier  périphérique  de la ville de Goma, à Ndosho (Kiziba II) et y mettre de locataire qui pourrait lui payer de l’argent
La veuve Bubenga A. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille  et son business prospère bien. Dit-elle, que Dieu bénisse l’IMF Hekima. 
Ce groupe Umoja ni nguvu  est  composé de 15 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Ms. Bubenga A. is the president of the loan group Umoja ni Nguvu. (She is the one in the photo with her hand raised and her loan contract in hand, in the background). She is a 4th loan cycle client, aged 46, widowed, and the mother of two daughters, both of whom have their own homes already. The daughters are appropriately pursuing their education with the support of their husbands. Widow Bubenga's husband died in 1994 due to his family's ignorance and carelessness. Bubenga says that, instead of going to get care at a regular hospital, her husband's family had favored taking her now deceased husband to a féticheur marabout (traditional practitioner), which complicated his health situation, leading to an early death. Widow Bubenga sells vegetables: sombe (cassava leaves), spinach, amaranth, tomatoes, eggplant, etc. She displays her produce at the small market of the Mapendo-Birere district and sometimes in front of warehouses or outlets. She started her small business with her own funds. Her initial capital was $70. Then, she was informed about the micro-finance institution Hekima, which lends to the poor without collateral. From that, she got her first boost loan. With the loan from the MFI Hekima, she would like to increase her sales by buying vegetables she will be able to resell. The big challenge she faces is variability; that is, there is a big difference in prices, such that, during the rainy season, prices plunge, given that vegetables are plentiful on the market. During droughts, there is a shortage of vegetables. Despite this, consumers (customers, people) will still buy, and Bubenga will derive as much profit as she can. Widow Bubenga came to the decision to watch over her biological mother (her daughters' grandmother), who is now very old. She remains at her side to attend to her and to care for more struggling orphans in her extended family. As much as her sales are increasing, she would prefer switching her work to supplying pagnes (clothing of Congolese women) in the city of Bukavu, the capital of the province of Sud Kivu. Moreover, Bubenga would like to build a house in the future on her parcel of land located in the outer district of Goma City, in Ndosho (Kiziba II), and then rent it out. This would bring in money. Widow Bubenga thanks the MFI Hekima for the loans she receives with no collateral at all. Because of these loans, she is managing to provide for her family, and her business is really prospering. She says, "May God bless the MFI Hekima." This group, Umoja ni Nguvu, is composed of fifteen members, mostly women.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vegetables (tomatoes, cassava leaves, spinach, peppers)

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Biola

texts.en: Biola sells electronics at retail prices to his customers.  He hopes to own an electronic company in the future. He has been in this business for a long time.  He is 32 years old, married with 2 children. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. His wife sells clothes to also support their home. He is requesting for a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more electronics to sell.  He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Mujeres Bendecidas 3 Group

texts.en:
Altagracia is the coordinator of her group, Mujeres Bendecidas (Blessed Women), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their three children.

Altagracia is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and she believes that working with Esperanza will improve her sales. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business of making and selling underwear, by purchasing panties, bras and materials such as sequins and beads for making lingerie. She will use the profits to invest in her dreams of owning a car, improving her home and seeing her children through to the university. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy bras, panties and material for making lingerie.

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en:
Ngozi is a very hard working. She sells cooked food with the business she could sustain her and family in area of feeding, clothing, and more. She started the business in 2003. She hopes to have a better shop in future, she asking for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more sachet water and foodstuffs to cook and sell. 

She is 32 years old and she has 4 children. They are age 2, 6, 8 and 10 years and are doing well in school except the youngest child who is still at home. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more sachet water and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Concern Women Group

texts.en:
Watta S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Concern Women. She is 42 years old, married, and has a 10 year old child. She also cares for 2 siblings. She did not have the opportunity to go school because her parents did not have the opportunity.

For 4 years, Watta has been selling building materials at Redlight Market in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells her materials at a low price which keeps her customers returning. Watta started selling with 5,000.00 Liberian Dollars as working capital. She plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 50,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more building materials. Her goal is to grow her business and expand to every part of Liberia.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Watta is the one holding the sign. Inset at the lower right is Fanta F..

loans.use: To buy more building materials.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin sells sarongs and laces at retail prices. She hopes to own an African boutique in the future. She is 45 years old, married with 3 children.  Her husband sells electronics spare parts to support their home. She loves the business because of the profits that she makes from her business. She is requesting for a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more sarongs and lace to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and laces to sell

loans.name: Alamo

texts.en: Alamo is happy man. He sells engine oil in a tank to his customers. He has been in this business for long and his only challenge in his business is funds and he hopes to overcome this challenge.  He is 38 years old, married with 2 children and his children attend school.  He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell

loans.name: Nuevo Progreso 1 Group

texts.en:
Felicia, 56, is the coordinator of her group, Nuevo Progreso (New Progress), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums north of the Capitol Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband.

Felicia is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a small food stand by purchasing more vegetables, rice, salad and beans to sell to her clients. She will use the profits to invest in her home by changing the walls from wood to concrete block, a huge improvement in the Hurricane prone, termite ridden Dominican Republic. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy vegetables, rice, salad and beans to sell.

loans.name: Assumpta

texts.en:
Assumpta is 51 years old, married with three children who are 2, 16, and 19 years old.  Assumpta also takes care of 3 dependents of 5, 10, and 15 years old.  Assumpta works hard at selling many sacks of charcoal.  Assumpta has been in this business for about three years.

Assumpta needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to have a large stock of charcoal.  With this business expansion, Assumpta, apart from retailing, will hopefully start wholesaling to the retailers operating the same business around her area.  Through the access to this loan, Assumpta hopes to continue taking good care of her family as well as saving for a better future for her business.

loans.use: The purchase of many sacks of charcoal

loans.name: With God All Things Are Possible Group

texts.en:
Sonnie J. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called With God All Things Are Possible. She is 37 years old, married, and has four children. She could not complete high school due to lack of financial support.

For 2 years, Sonnie has been selling hardware on a table at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. She usually sells her goods, to customers, at a discount which keeps them returning. Sonnie started selling with 9,000.00 Liberian Dollars as working capital and now has more than 25,000.00 Liberian as working capital. She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 52,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more hardware. Her goal is to grow her business and to take care of her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sonnie is the one holding the sign. Inset at the lower right is Mamie M..

loans.use: To buy more hardware.

loans.name: Marie Jeanne

texts.en:
Marie Jeanne is 27 years old, married with two children who are 1 and 3 years old.  Marie Jeanne is widely known in the business of selling different styles of clothes and this is her fifth successful year in this business, which she works at from 7 am to 8 pm every day.

Marie Jeanne is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand expand her business through adding different modern styles of clothing.  With these additional styles for sale, Marie Jeanne hopes to earn more profits than her previous business has, which in turn will allow her to continue taking good care of her family and keep reinvesting in her business for better progress.

loans.use: The purchase of different styles of clothes for sale

loans.name: Mirembe Katenga, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Hardworking M. Lawrence started up his motorcycle transport business four years ago. As motorcycles are a very common means of conveyance in timely situations like traffic jams and bad road systems in Uganda, he has made good profit out of it, earning 200,000 Ugandan shillings.

Lawrence’s main setback is that he needs to expand the business through buying additional motorcycles to allocate them in different stages so as to increase his revenue. With this loan he hopes to achieve that and thus will be able to take care of his family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke is a friendly woman. She sells plastics to make a living. She sells for long hours to enable her meet the basic needs of her family and also supports her husband. She is 40 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is a contractor and he also supports their home. She is requesting for a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more plastics to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics to sell

loans.name: Ahadi Group

texts.fr:
Tabu E. est présidente du groupe de crédit  Ahadi, elle lève sa main sur la photo, âgée de 55 ans, Mariée, mère de 8 enfants parmi lesquels 4 étudient convenablement et d’autres sont déjà adultes.  Son mari est chômeur (sans emploi) depuis 1996, c'est-à-dire depuis le début des événements des guerres en RD Congo.   
Tabu E. est entrepreneur d’un cafeteria (mini restaurant) installé dans le quartier Virunga, avenue coin du marché. Elle a commencé son entreprise de mini Restaurant  avec  son fonds propre reçu de son mari après l’éruption du 16-17 février 2002 du volcan Nyiragongo qui a complètement détruit la ville de Goma.  Madame Tabu E. s’est retrouvée aussi  victime de cette éruption volcanique, sinistrée, sans abris. Son capital initial était 100$ et un peu plus tard, elle fut informée de l’IMF Hekima qui donne des crédits aux pauvres sans aucune garantie a travers les groupes de crédit, delà, elle bénéficie son 1er crédit de renforcement.
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Tabu E. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant des aliments : 1 sacs de haricots, 25 kilos de riz, 2 caisses de sucrés Fanta, 2 bidons d’huile végétale Rina, 20 kilos de pommes de terre, 3 régimes de bananes, 10 kilos de viandes, des poissons, legumes, etc.
Le grand défi de madame Tabu E. c’est que les gens n’achètent pas lors qu’il n’y a pas d’argent en circulation. Malgré tout cela Tabu E. y tire son maximum de bénéfice, car la nourriture est la priorité des priorités de tout homme. Madame Tabu E. est confortable avec son business.
Dans ses projets, elle souhaite construire une maison dans son ancienne parcelle où la coulée de lave de l’éruption du volcan nyiragongo ait traversé. En outre, elle tient à payer régulièrement les frais scolaires de ses enfants.
Madame Tabu E. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits permanents qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille dit- elle.  
Ce groupe Ahadi est  composé de 17 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Ms. Tabu E. is the president of the loan group Adhadi.  (In the photo, she is the one raising her hand).  She is 55 years old and has eight children, among whom four are appropriately studying and some are already adults.  Her husband has been unemployed since 1996, that is, since the start of hostilities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.  Tabu is the entrepreneur of a cafeteria (mini-restaurant) set up in the Virunga district at a neighborhood market.  She started this mini-restaurant enterprise with her own funds received from her husband after the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano February 16 and 17, 2002 which completely destroyed the city of Goma.  Stricken and homeless, she too found herself a victim of this volcanic eruption. Her initial capital was $100.  A little later, she was informed of the micro-finance institution Hekima, which lends to the poor, without any collateral, through loan groups.  From that, she is benefiting from her first reinforcement loan. With the loan from MFI Hekima, Tabu wishes to increase her sales by buying:  a sack of beans, 25 kilos of rice, two cases of Fanta soda, two containers of Rina vegetable oil, 20 kilos of potatoes, three bunches of bananas, 10 kilos of meat, some fish, vegetables, etc.  The big challenge of hers is that people do not buy when there is no money in circulation.  Despite all this, she is deriving as much profit as she can, since food is the priority of all priorities of anyone.  She is comfortable with her business. In her plans, she wishes to build a house on her former parcel of land where the flow of lava of the erupting Nyiragongo volcano crossed.  In addition, she is determined to cover the costs of her children's schooling on a regular basis.  Tabu thanks the MFI Hekima for the repeated loans she receives without any collateral at all because, given these loans, she says she is managing to provide for her family. The group Adhadi is composed of seventeen members, most of whom are women. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: A sack of beans, 25 kilos of rice, two cases of Fanta soda, two containers of Rina vegetable oil, 20 kilos of potatoes, three bunches of bananas, 10 kilos of meat, some fish, vegetables, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Adolphe

texts.en:
Adolphe is 35 years old, married with 6 children aged between 1 and 13. Adolphe’s wife is a farmer and they both work hard for the development of their family. Adolphe owns a small shop which sells spare parts. This is his 5th year of successful operation in business! The hours of his shop are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

Even though Adolphe has a lot of experience, his monthly profit is too low to expand meaningfully and he believes that a small amount of additional capital would change that for him. For that reason, Adolphe is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase other products for his shop such as: beans; soap; cooking oil, and so on. With this loan Adolphe will be able to serve more customers from his community which will allow him to obtain more profits. With the profit, Adolphe expects to be able to save money for the school fees of his children.

loans.use: products for his shop such as: beans; soap; cooking oil, and so on

loans.name: Si Se Puede! 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Carolina is the coordinator of her group Si se pueD.! (Yes We Can!) and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally — many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the slums north of Santo Domingo where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She lives in a simple structure as a single mother with her child.

Carlonia is excited to be taking out her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in purchasing more rice, sugar, coffee, yuca, bananas and plantains. She will use the profits to invest in a computer for her child to learn on. Her dream is save towards turning her small stand into a large grocery store and have a vehicle to move merchandise with. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: too buy Rice, sugar, coffee, yuca, bananas and plantains

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort sells groceries and drinks at retail prices. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. With these combined businesses, she hopes to make her business more sustainable. She is 50 years old, married with 2 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of 40,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Fatima Narcisa

texts.es:
San Vicente es un hermoso cantón de la provincia de Manabí, en el habitan muchas personas dedicadas a la pesca y a otras actividades derivadas de esta, y demás actividades que fortalecen su economía, por su parte la señora Fátima de 48 años de edad, esta desde hace  27 años casada y tiene 3 hijos, Fátima se dedica al comercio ambulante  vende blusas, pantalones, ropa interior, pantalonetas, lleva 20 años con su negocio, y como en muchas familias que a base de trabajo salen adelante su esposo se dedica también a lo mismo,  el recorre cada quince días en San Lorenzo,  un recinto de San Vicente, para su negocio ella invierte cada 15 o 30 días 600 o 1000 dólares depende de la demanda que tenga, sus compras las realiza en la ciudad de Guayaquil, a más de la ropa Fátima también vende sabanas,  ella trabaja también recorriendo por otras sectores donde las prendas que vende son muy apetecibles.

Fátima está solicitando un crédito que de darse, lo piensa invertir en su negocio, ella habla con mucho orgullo que siempre le gusto su trabajo,  ella empezó con 500 sucres dice que le ha ido super bien en su trabajo, y que lo ha hecho gracias  a la Fundación Espoir, por eso está solicitando el nuevo crédito, que le servirá para seguir adelante.
texts.en:
San Vicente is a beautiful county in the Manabí province, where many of the residents dedicate themselves to fishing and other derivatives of this activity, as well as other tasks that strengthen their economy. Fátima is 48 years old, married for 27 years, and has 3 children. Fátima works as a street vendor selling blouses, pants, under garments. She has been in this business for 20 years and, like in many families, they get ahead financially through this endeavor. Her husband is in the same line of business and, every fifteen days, he visits San Lorenzo, a suburb of San Vicente. For her business, she invests $600 or $1000 every 15 or 30 days, depending on demand. She purchases the clothing in the city of Guayaquil. In addition to clothing, Fátima also sells bed sheets and also travels to other areas where her products are well received. Fátima is requesting a loan to invest in her business. She speaks very proudly about how much she enjoys her work, having started it with 500 sucres. She states that business has gone very well, and she has been able to manage thanks to the Fundación Espoir. She is seeking this new loan to continue moving forward with her enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase blouses, pants, shorts, under garments.

loans.name: Dorothe

texts.en:
Dorothe is 29 years old, married with 3 children aged between 2 and 6. Dorothe sells only Irish potatoes because that is profitable in her region. This is her 2nd year of success in her business operation. The hours of her business are from 8 in the morning to 3 in the evening every day except on Sunday.

Dorothe is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business through purchasing more Irish potatoes and other foodstuffs which can help her to attract more customers and satisfy them.  With this loan Dorothe hopes to earn more profits which will allow her to save money and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: The purchase of Irish potatoes and other foodstuffs

loans.name: Virtue Women Group

texts.en:
Claresa F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Virtue Women. She is 58 years old, widowed, and has two children, 32 and 37 years old. She was only able to attend school through high school.

For 13 years, Claresa has been selling charcoal at the Somalia Drive in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells good quality charcoal, which keeps customers returning.

Claresa started selling with 1,000 LRD as working capital and now has about 12,000 LRD. She plans to use her 4,000 LRD portion of this 20,000 LRD group loan to buy more charcoal for the rainy season. Her goal is to get a warehouse that has the capacity to store about 200 bags of charcoal, develop her business and educate her children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Claresa is holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Carmen Anabel

texts.es:
Carmen es oriunda de la provincia de los Ríos  a los 15 años se fue a radicar a la parroquia Picoaza, se esfuerza día a día en seguir adelante con su negocio, y es que para ella es muy grato vivir en un cantón tan hermoso como San Vicente, pero sabe que no todo es fantasía, sabe a ciencia cierta que tiene que trabajar duro para seguir sacando adelante a sus niños, aun están pequeños y necesitan del esfuerzo y protección de sus padres, ella vende zapatillas, y su esposo vende ollas, y cuchillos en otros lugares del país, como en  el oriente y Esmeraldas , la señora Carmen compra las zapatillas para el negocio y las deja a crédito, de alguna manera esta forma de trabajar le deja sus ingresos,  recorre puerta a puerta a sus clientes,  y por semana cobra, hay zapatillas desde 10 dólares, tiene pocos meses trabajando.

Están casados desde hace 5 años, y por la edad de los niños muchas veces se le hace complicado cumplir con su trabajo, pero opta por dejar a los pequeños con su madre quien es de gran ayuda para ella,  viven en la casa de su suegra y el sueño de ella es tener su propia casa, con el crédito se divide para comprar su mercadería y la otra parte a su esposo, por pedido hace las compras, hay diferentes modelos de zapatos la hermana es la que le ayuda a seleccionar la mercadería,  al mes compra tres docenas de zapatos, un distribuidor le lleva a entregar directamente a su casa, solo por pedido ella se encarga de hacer el pedido según lo que las clientas le solicitan, sale a vender en la mañana, los domingos cobra, no ha tenido problema con los clientes son puntuales para cancelar y una vez que reúne el dinero invertido hace otro , el amor hizo que Carmen desde que se comprometiera se radicara a vivir en la provincia.
texts.en:
Carmen is a native of the Los Ríos province and, at 15 years of age, she relocated to the Picoaza district. She works each and every day to get ahead in her business since, for her, it is very gratifying to live in a county as beautiful as San Vicente. However, she knows everything isn’t fantasy and that it’s a scientific fact that she has to work hard to help her children get ahead. They are young, and still need the strength and support of their parents. She sells shoes and her husband sells pans and knives in other areas of the country. Carmen buys shoes for the business and sells them on credit. Somehow, this way of working generates income. She travels door to door to visit customers, and charges on a weekly basis. Her shoes start at $10; she has been working only a few months. Carmen has been married for 5 years and, given how young her children still are, it has often been difficult to carry out her work. However, her mother has been a great help by caring for the kids while she works. They live with her in-laws, and she hopes to have her own house one day. She hopes to use part of the loan to buy merchandise, and share the other part with her husband. She buys different styles of shoes, which her sister helps her choose from the merchandise available. Carmen buys three-dozen pairs of shoes each month, which the distributor delivers directly to her home. She places her order based on customer demand, selling her shoes each morning and charging customers on Sundays. She has not had any problems with customers, as they all are punctual with their payments. Once she collects the funds, she places another order. Falling in love is what led Carmen to relocate until she got engaged.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes for resale.

loans.name: Yobannis Vicente

texts.es:
San Vicente basa gran parte de su economí¬a en la agricultura, ganadería, pesca, comercio y turismo. Es un hermoso cantón con gente muy honesta y trabajadora digno de todos los cantones manabitas.

Geovanni es un manabita mas, dedicado a su trabajo y familia,  es vendedor ambulante de diferente tipo de ropa, depende de la temporada, como en esta ocasión por motivo de clases ha vendido los uniformes escolares, y sin dudar  en el mes de mayo pensando en las madres hará sus compras, como batas, blusas ropa interior sabanas, etc, prendas que sabe que tendrán mucha demanda por la fecha, Geovanni siempre trata de  invertir en la mercadería que es más vendida.

22 años vivió en Esmeraldas y 3 años tiene radicado  en Picoaza,  Geovanni compra la mercadería cuando hay la oportunidad, antes viajaba a Guayaquil, ahora viaja a Santo Domingo afirma que es mejor el comercio ahora allá, compra por semana invierte 400 0 500 dólares según lo que va recaudando, tiene laborando 20 años,  es de Picoaza pero se fue a radicar a Esmeraldas a la actividad del negocio y regreso a su pueblo natal a los 22 años, vende en la provincia verde Esmeraldas y regresa cada quincena a su casa, la familia se queda en Picoaza, con lo del crédito piensa  invertir  todo en la mercadería.

 El sueño de Geovanni  es estar unido a  la familia y tener un buen porvenir junto a su esposa y sus tres hijas. Sabe que con más esfuerzo y la gran ayuda de la Fundación Espoir lo lograra.
texts.en:
San Vicente’s economy is based primarily on agriculture, livestock, fishing, commerce and tourism. It is a beautiful area with honest and hard-working residents, one of the most dignified in Manabi. Geovanni lives in this area, and is dedicated to his work and family. He works as a street vendor, selling different types of clothing depending on the season. Now, for example, he is selling school uniforms since classes have started. Likewise, with Mother’s Day near, he will focus on buying robes, blouses, under garments, bed sheets, etc., products he knows will be in high demand for this celebration. Geovanni always tries to invest in the products he knows will be in greatest demand. He lived in the Esmeraldas area for 22 years, and relocated to Picoaza 3 years ago. He buys merchandise whenever he has the opportunity, previously traveling to Guayaquil for his purchases. Now, he goes to Santo Domingo where he comments business is currently better. He buys on a weekly basis, investing $400 or $500 based on what he’s collecting. He has been working for 20 years, and is originally from Picoaza but relocated to Esmeraldas and returned to his native town at 22 years of age. He sells in Esmeraldas, and returns every fifteen days to his family in Picoaza. He plans to invest the entire loan into merchandise. Geovanni’s dream is to be with his family, and to earn a good living along with his wife and three daughters. He knows that with great effort and the help from Fundación Espoir he will achieve this.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Para comprar ropa interior, blusas, batas, sabanas.

loans.name: Rosario Cecibel

texts.es:
Rosario L. es otra de esas mujeres trabajadoras y esforzadas  que habita en San Vicente, un pequeño paraíso manabita,  la señora Rosario está  casada y tiene 4 hijos se dedica al comercio, Rosario  vende ropa interior, su esposo también se dedica al comercio de ropa, negocio que ya es como tradición en esta familia,  el viaja constantemente para vender su mercadería, y  ella sale a recorrer en su propio cantón.

Cada 15 o 30 días viaja  a comprar sus mercadearías en la ciudad de Guayaquil, siempre y cuando tenga una demanda aceptable, y el suficiente dinero para abastecerse de mercadería, Rosario lleva a 1 año en su negocio, para ella no hay nada mejor que trabajar y conseguir las cosas a base de esfuerzo,  sabe que sus inversiones son seguras por eso trabaja en base a créditos, mismos que deja a sus clientes fijos y estos cada semana  pagan las prendas que han dejado, ella se da tiempo para trabajar mucho , pero también el suficiente como para no descuidar su hogar, su sueño es seguir trabajando para seguir dando a su familia la estabilidad que se merecen.
texts.en:
Rosario L. is another one of those hardworking, striving women who live in San Vicente, a small paradise in Manabi. Rosario is married and has 4 children. She is a sales woman. She sells underwear. Her husband also sells clothes; the business is like a family tradition. He travels constantly to sell his merchandise and she goes out in her own canton. Every two weeks to a month she travels to buy her merchandise in the city of Guayaquil. This depends on whether there is an acceptable demand and enough money to get the merchandise. Rosario has been in the business for one year. For her, there is nothing better than working and getting things based on effort. She knows that her investments are safe and that is why she works on credit. She drops the clothes off with her regular customers and every week they pay for them. She takes the time to work a lot, but she also takes the time to not neglect her home. Her dream is to keep working to continue giving her family the stability they deserve.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase underwear

loans.name: Primavera Group

texts.es:
LA SRA. BERTHA, TIENE TIENE 39 AÑOS DE EDAD, TIENE 2 HIJOS PEQUEÑOS, Y FORMA PARTE DEL GRUPO "PRIMAVERA" FORMADO POR 8 SOCIOS MÁS, TODOS ELLOS RESIDENTES DE LA 5TA. ZONA DE COLLIQUE. EN RECONOCIMIENTO A SU TRABAJO Y HONESTIDAD, SUS COMPAÑEROS LA ELIGIERON COMO TESORERA DE LA JUNTA DIRECTIVA DEL GRUPO.
HACE 9 AÑOS, LA SRA. BERTHA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE EXTINTORES Y BRINDA SERVICIO DE FUMIGACIÓN, SU NEGOCIO SE ENCUENTRA UBICADO EN SU DOMICILIO. SUS PRIMERAS EXPERIENCIAS LAS OBTUVO  TRABAHANDO PARA UNA EMPRESA, DONDE APRENDIÓ EL MANEJO, POCO A POCO TOMÓ CONFIANZA Y SE ANIMÓ A INDEPENDIZARSE, DESDE EL COMIENZO LE FUÉ BIEN GRACIAS AL ESFUERZO Y ENTUSIASMO QUE LE PUSOS DESDE UN INICIO.
CON SU TRABAJO PUEDE PAGAR LOS ESTUDIOS DE SUS HIJAS, HA ARREGLADO Y CONTINUADO CON LA CONSTRUCCIÓN DE SU CASA.
UNA DE SUS METAS, ES APERTURAR UNA BODEGA, LA CUAL FUNCIONARÍA EN SU CASA, SOLO LE FALTA JUNTAR UN POCO MAS DE DINERO Y FORMAR SU CAPITAL.
EL PRESTAMO SOLICITADO LO INVERTIRÁ EN COMPRA DE EXTINTORES PARA SU NEGOCIO.
About EDAPROSPO: EDAPROSPO seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty.
texts.en:
Bertha is 39 years old and has two small children. She is part of the nine-member "Primavera" group, all of whom live in the same area of Collique, Peru. Because of her honesty and dedication, her colleagues have made her the treasurer of the group's board of directors. Nine years ago, Bertha began selling fire extinguishers and offering a fumigation service, working from her home. Initially, she worked for another company, where she honed her management skills. Little by little, she gained confidence and decided to become independent. Everything went well from the start, thanks to her effort and enthusiasm. She has been using her earnings to pay pay for her daughters' education, as well as to build and improve her house. One of her current goals is to run a store out of her home. She needs a little more capital for this project. The requested loan will be used to buy extinguishers for her business. About EDAPROSPO: EDAPROSPO seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty.

Translated from Spanish by Ross Forman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fire extinguishers for her business

loans.name: Umoja Kibabi Group

texts.fr:
Baseme B. Apoline est présidente du groupe de crédit  Umoja Kibabi, en blouse blanche, elle lève sa main sur la photo, cliente au 14e cycle de crédit, âgée de 36 ans, Mariée, mère de 5 enfants tous étudient convenablement.  Son mari est chômeur (sans emploi). En dehors de ses enfants légitimes, elle héberge également  4 autres enfants de sa famille élargie (cousin, neuve, voisin du village).   
Baseme B. Apoline vend des  boissons (bière Primus, Mutzing et sucrés Fanta, etc.). Elle expose ses produits devant des boutiques des amis et connaissances (sur la voie publique, rond point Signers) pour la vente en gros et parfois à son domicile c’est la vente en détails . Elle a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre reçu de son beau père sous forme d’un don. Son capital initial était 20$ équivalent aux deux caisses de la bière Primus. Il y a 16 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. 
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Baseme B. Apoline souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant des 36 caisses de sucrés Fanta.
Le grand défi de Baseme B. Apoline est que les gens consomment parfois à crédit avec risque de lui payer avec retard. Et d’autres achètent mais ne lui restituent pas les bouteilles vides. Malgré tout cela Baseme B. Apoline y tire son maximum de bénéfice, elle est confortable avec son business.
Baseme B. Apoline remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits permanents qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille dit - elle.  
Ce groupe Umoja Kibabi est  composé de 20 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Baseme B. Apoline is president of the loan group Umoja Kibabi. In the white blouse, raising her hand in the photo, she is a client on her 14th loan cycle; she is 36 years old, married and the mother of five children, all studying well. Her husband is unemployed. In addition to her own children, four other children are also living with her from her extended family (cousin, nephew, neighbor in the village). Baseme B. Apoline sells drinks (Primus and Mutzig beer, Fanta sodas, etc.). She displays her products in front of friends' and acquaintances' shops (on the street, the Signers roundabout) and sells wholesale; she occasionally sells retail from her home. She began her small business with her own money, which she received from her father-in-law as a gift. Her initial capital investment was twenty dollars, which is equivalent to two cases of Primus beer. She has been in business for sixteen years. With the loan from the microfinance institution Hekima, Baseme B. Apoline would like to increase her sales by buying 36 cases of Fanta. Baseme B. Apoline's greatest challenge is that people sometimes drink on credit, with the risk of paying her back late. Others buy, but do not return the empty bottles. Despite all this, Baseme B. Apoline makes her maximum profit; she is comfortable with her business. Baseme B. Apoline thanks the microfinance institution Hekima for the permanent loans which she is receiving with no material collateral. Thanks to these loans, she is able to meet her family's needs, she says. The Umoja Kibabi group is comprised of twenty members, the majority of which are women.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 36 cases of Fanta and Primus

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: C2146 Twitezimbere Group

texts.en:
Janvier is 25 years old and single. Janvier is still lives with his parents. He is a young entrepreneur in the business of selling various products. Janvier owns a small shop which sells sugar, salt, cosmetic products and so on.  He is also group representative; this group contains five members: one man and four women, all of them with different businesses. Some of them sell various foodstuffs and the remainder sell green bananas. 

Janvier is organized in his business and well known in the region where his business is located. He has an experience of 4 years; during this period he has been employing one person from his community.

Janvier and his group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business which will help them to get ahead in their business.  With this loan, especially Janvier hopes to save money from his business which will allow him to build his own house so that he can get married.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes sells mouth watery Nigerian cooked foods. She has been in this business for long in her community. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to see her business and family life make progress. She has been in this business for long. She is 39 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is a tailor and he also supports their home. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: God Is Love Group

texts.en: Golwin M., holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God is Love. He is 53 years old, married with five children between six and 24. He was only able to attend school up to college sophomore level. For three years, he has sold charcoal on McDonald Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. His friendly manner keeps customers returning. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 26,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more charcoal. His goal is to grow his business and continue to support his children so they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Anathalie

texts.en:
Anathalie is 42 years old, married with three children; the first born is 13 years old; the following is 8 years old, and the last one is 6 years old. All of them are in school. Anathalie owns a small shop which sells various products such as: biscuits, Highland milk, cosmetic products, bread and so on.  Anathalie has an experience of three years selling these kinds of products as a retailer. She employs one person in her business. She sells to locals and passersby every day from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening.

Anathalie is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business through purchasing more products for resale. If her goals are reached, Anathalie will be able to satisfy her customers by offering good qualities. With this satisfaction for her customers, Anathalie hopes to earn more profits which will help her to pay school fees for her children and to provide all that is necessary for them. With extra money Anathalie expects to buy her own business place.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose is into the printing of documents and text books. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She is a hard working woman. She hopes to grow and expand her business. She is 26 years old, Single without children. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more printing materials to boost her printing business.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more printing materials to boost her printing business

loans.name: Ebenerzer #6 Group

texts.en: Emmanuel W. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Ebenezer #6. He is 32 years old, single, with two children, 7 and 13. He was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to poverty. For 10 years, he has sold used shoes at Waterside Market downtown Monrovia, Liberia. His friendly manner keeps customers returning. He plans to use his 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 46,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more used shoes. His goal is to grow his business and continue to support his children so they can have a better future. In the photo, Emmanuel is the one holding the sign. Inset at the lower right is Rufus T.

loans.use: To buy more used shoes.

loans.name: Angela Mercedes

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal 8 de diciembre se reúne en la capital manabita este es un grupo de señoras bastante organizado y que están a gusto trabajando con la Fundación.

La señora Ángela de 57 año de edad, es viuda es oriunda de Portoviejo se dedica al comercio de ropa, zapatos, carteras tiene su negocio en su propia casa lleva 25 años en su trabajo también se dedica a la agricultura ella es jefa del grupo de trabajadores su negocio de la agricultura queda en Rio Chico ella viaja a diario, su negocio lo atienden personas que trabajan en oficina que regularmente la visitan de tarde y de noche, sus compras las realiza en la ciudad de Guayaquil, compra ropa colombiana y  nacional según lo que sus clientes le pidan, en cada compra que realiza gasta 4000 dólares en vitrinas, el dinero que esta solicitando es para invertir en las reconocidas marcas Lebel y Avon.
 
Su sueño es poder acabar de construir su casa, ella traba en una finca donde ella lo administra, y es la dueña lleva 18 años con esta finca antes se lo administraba su esposo, cultivan cacao, limos, yuca y arboles de mango, ahora sale sola adelante y lo hace con orgullo.
texts.en:
The communal bank 8 de Diciembre meets in the capital of Manabi. This is a group of women that is very organized and they are pleased to work with the Foundation. Ángela is 57 years old. She is a widow from Portoviejo and she sells clothes, shoes, and purses. She has her business in her own house. She has been doing this for 25 years. She also works in agriculture. She is the head of a group of workers. Her agricultural business is in Rio Chico. She travels every day. Her business is attended to by people who work in an office and they visit her in the afternnon and in the evening. She makes her purchases in the city of Guayaquil. She buys Colombian and domestic clothing according to what her customers order. For each purchase she makes she spends 4,000 dollars in inventory. The money she is asking for is to invest in the well known labels Lebel and Avon. Her dream is to finish building her house. She works on a farm that she manages and owns. She has been at this farm for 18 years. Her husband managed it before. They grow cacao, limes, yucca and mango trees. No she is getting ahead on her own and she does it with pride.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase Avon and Lebel clothing and cosmetics

loans.name: Bella Monserrate

texts.es:
Las señora Bella es comprometida, ella  elabora cortinas, Bella trabaja en un taller y ahí  aprendió el trabajo,  lleva 20 años en su negocio tiene dos personas que le ayudan, sus compras las realiza en la ciudades de Quito, Guayaquil  y  Portoviejo sus clientes le hacen los pedidos por catálogos entrega al mes 4 pedidos el tipo de telas que ella trabaja más es de nacionalidad colombiana y ciertas prendas son nacionales, ella tiene muchos pedidos, tanto que hasta  le hacen pedidos a nivel nacional, los acabados ella los hace y el planchado, una cortina de 2 metros las 3 capas el sencillo, pesada y cenefa cuesta 200 dólares depende que tipo de tela y modelo desea el cliente.

Bella tiene el titulo de profesora, pero aun así opto por seguir en este trabajo o negocio que le reporta muchas bendiciones, su sueño es hacer crecer su negocio en cada compra que realiza invierte 500 dólares, pero sabe que la inversión le trae ganancias, y eso se lo debe  a la Fundación Espoir y a la gran ayuda que ofrecen a los que más necesitan para seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
Bella is busy lady. She makes curtains and works in the shop where she learned the job. She has spent 20 years in the business and has two people helping her. She makes her fabric purchases in the cities of Quito, Guayaquil and Portoviejo. Her customers place catalog orders. Four times a month, she orders the fabrics with which she works most, which are from Colombia, although some of the items are from Ecuador. The finished, ironed curtains she makes can be 2 meters long, 3 layers, fine, heavy and with a valance can cost $200 depending on the type of fabric and pattern the client wants. Bella has a professor certificate, but still opted to stay in this profession which brings her many blessings. Her dream is to grow her business with every sale by investing $500. She knows that this investment will bring returns for that she is indebted to Espoir for the great help offered to those who need to keep working.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Kellogg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Bolanle

texts.en: Bolanle sells electronics retail prices. She hopes to own an electronic company in the future. She hopes to make her business more sustainable. She is 40 years old, married with 4 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more electronics to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to   sell

loans.name: C2828 Dufatanye Group

texts.en:
Marthe is 34 years old, married with 4 children aged between 3 and 10. Marthe’s husband is a driver and they both work for their family's well-being. Marthe is the leader of the group which is called DUFANYE in the local language. This group contains 3 members: two men and one woman.

Marthe who is the leader has an experience of 3 years in selling various styles of clothing. Her shop is open from 6 in the morning to 5 in the evening. 

Marthe and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing their business through purchasing more products for their shops. This loan will allow them to satisfy the demand of their customers. Marthe hopes to earn more profits which will allow her to save money for the future and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria es soltera tiene 29 años estudia en la universidad  la carrera de secretearía esta en  octavo semestre, el préstamo  que solicita es para que su mamá incremente el pequeño negocio de ropa de adultos y de niños, sus compras las realiza cuando le hacen el préstamo,  viaja a la ciudad de Guayaquil, su mamá y su papá trabajan en su negocio, las fechas que mas se venden es en los meses de carnaval, mayo y diciembre  su mayor sueño es seguir adelante.

Gloria es soltera pero eso no impide que ella sea una chica que piense mucho en el trabajo  y las responsabilidades, por eso piensan seguir estudiando y seguirá apoyando a sus padres.
texts.en:
Gloria is 29 years old and single. She is in her eighth semester of studying for a secretarial career in the university. The loan she is requesting is so that her mother can increase her small business selling clothes for adults and children. She will make the purchases when she receives the loan. She will travel to the city of Guayaquil. Her mother and father work in their business. The dates when they sell the most are the months of carnival, May and December. Her biggest dream is to get ahead. Gloria is single, but she does no let that stop her from being a girl who thinks a lot about work and responsibilities. Therefore, she plans to keep studying and to continue supporting her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes for women, men, and children

loans.name: Lucinda's Group

texts.es:
“Por primera vez me he prestado plata D. la Unidad D. Micro finanzas Asociación Arariwa”

Zoraida, tiene 27 años, es casada  y tiene una hija llamada Katherine D. cuatro años, es natural D. la Comunidad D. Huayocari del distrito D. Huallabamba D. la provincia D. Urubamba departamento del Cusco. 

Zoraida  nos cuenta. - En mi banco comunal “Virgen del Carmen”  somos 11 integrantes (9 mujeres y 2 varones) y me eligieron a mí como representante del banco comunal para dar mi testimonio D. mi actividad comercial.  
Zoraida  es empleada del restaurante en la “Hacienda D. Huayocari”. Ya son 5 años que trabaja en el restaurante y le va muy bien. Ella requiere el préstamo para alquilar un terreno en la comunidad D. Huayocari para sembrar  productos como por ejemplo cebollas, zanahorias, etc. 

Zoraida quiere aprender a ser responsable con el dinero y saber invertir bien el dinero en su negocio y por ese motivo ingreso a  formar parte del banco comunal. 

Las reuniones D. los socios son cada treinta días en la casa D. la socia Mary luz que muy amablemente les presta un espacio D. su tienda. 

La mayoría D. los socios son comerciantes por ejemplo venta D. abarrotes, venta D. tortas, venta D. chicha, venta D. verduras y venta D. carne y otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo empleada D. restaurante, cocinera, portador del camino Inca y chofer.

La ciudad D. Huayocari se encuentra a una hora y treinta minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco en carro.
texts.en:
“For the first time, I have been lent money from the Asociación Arariwa microfinance entity.” Zoraida, age 27, is married and has a four year old daughter named Katherine. She is from the Huayocari community in the Huallabamba district, Urubamba province, Cusco department. Zoraida tells us that there are 11 members (nine women and two men) in the Virgen del Carmen Communal Bank. They elected her to represent the communal bank, and to tell about her commercial activity. Zoraida is employed by the Hacienda D. Huayocari restaurant. She has worked in the restaurant for five years, and it is going very well for her. She needs the loan to rent a piece of land in the Huayocari community. She will plant products like onions and carrots, etc. Zoraida wants to learn to be responsible with money. She wants to know how to invest her money well in her business. That is why she joined and became part of the communal bank. The members meetings are every 30 days at Mary Luz’s house. She is a member who kindly lends them a space in her store. Most of the members are merchants who sell groceries, sell cakes, sell “chicha” (a drink maD. from corn), sell vegetables, or sell meat. Other members proviD. services like working in a restaurant, cooking, transportation along the Incan trail, or driving. The city of Huayocari is one hour and thirty minutes by car from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Zoraida needs the loan to rent a piece of land in the Huayocari community to plant products like onions and carrots, etc.

loans.name: Mariana Del Jesus

texts.es:
La señora mariana es casada, su esposo es maestro constructor y sus seis hijos ya son mayores de edad,  se dedica a la  venta de  tarjetas de celulares, el negocio lo tiene en su  propia casa.

Mariana antes se dedicaba a la venta de ropa, le gustaba mucho ese negocio, pero lo dejo porque  la gente le quedaba mal,  ella confiadamente les dejaba la mercadería y muchos no pagaban, eso le hizo desistir,  Mariana afirma  que le va muy bien en su nuevo negocio de ventas de tarjetas, tiene una producción de ventas considerables, y  eso también hace que sus ganancias sean buenas , vende tarjetas de 3, 6, y  10 dólares al mes gana 100 o 80 dólares, dependen lo que haya vendido ella compra sus tarjetas al contado a una hija que vende tarjetas su sueño es seguir con su negocio y seguir adelante, está orgullosa de su familia, y de ella misma, ella dice que se vale por ella, y que lucha por vivir, le encanta tener una vida tranquila, y saber que sus hijos también son felices.
texts.en:
Mariana is married, and her husband is a construction worker. Their six children are now grown. She sells cell phone cards, and she has this business in her house. Mariana previously sold clothes. She really liked this business, but she left it because the people did not behave well. She would confidently leave the merchandise, and many did not pay. This made her stop selling clothes. Mariana says that the new business of selling cards is going very well for her. Her sales are considerable. This, in turn, makes her earnings good. She sells cards for $3, $6, and $10. She earns between $80 and $100 a month, depending on how much she has sold. She buys her cards for cash from one of her daughters who sells cards. Her dream is to continue with her business and to get ahead. She is proud of her family and of herself. She manages, and she fights for a living. She loves having a peaceful life and knowing that her children are also happy.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy prepaid cell cards

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: C2145 Haguruka Group

texts.en:
Juvenal is 69 years old, married with five children aged between 5 and 29. Juvenal is an older man but in business terms he is so young simply because he has an experience of only two years selling green bananas. Juvenal is also group representative; this group composed of five people: four women and the one man who is group representative.

Juvenal and his group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing their business through purchasing more products for sale. The people who make up this group sell foodstuffs; some sell green bananas while others sell beans. This business is profitable in their region and that is the reason why it was chosen by them in order to earn more profit from their business. The purpose of Juvenal who is the leader is to save money which will help him to buy land for his family.

loans.use: Expanding their businesses

loans.name: Mercedes Gricelda

texts.es:
