María and her husband sell food at the open market, but she walks around the entire market since she does not have her own vending stall. Her family rents their home since they do not own a house.

María is in her second loan cycle and was invited to join the Communal Bank by a friend. With her new loan, she will buy a cart to repair so that she can perform her job better and provide improved service to her customers.

Her dream is to have a house of her own.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a food cart to use for her business

loans.name: Central Tinke Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios pertenecen al banco comunal “CENTRAL TINKE”; Nuestros socios viven en el distrito D. Ocongate, provincia D. Quispicanchis departamento del Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la  Sra. OCTAVIA,  ella tiene 27 años D. edad, es casada tiene 2 hijos D. 7 años el varoncito y la mujercita D. 5 años, Nuestra socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista, la socia tiene una pequeña tienda abarrotes en la cual venD. productos básicos, verduras, frutas y bebidas D. todo tipo; Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra D. más variedad D. productos.

Nuestros socios alternan sus diferentes actividades con el comercio minorista, en un 80 % se dedican a la agricultura y a la ganadería, el restante tiene diferentes actividades, restaurante y tienda abarrotes. Nuestros socios solicitan el préstamo para reinvertir en sus diferentes negocios.

Los  socios agradecen y valoran el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago D. sus deudas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our members belong to the communal bank “Central Tinke”. They live in the Ocongate district in the Quispicanchis province in Cusco department. Our member is Mrs. Octavia. She is 27, married and has 2 children: her son is 7 and her daughter is 5. She alternates her work at home with her retail business. Octavia has a small general store where she sells basic foodstuffs such as vegetables, fruit and all types of drinks. Our member is asking for a loan to purchase a larger variety of products. The members alternate their activities with retail businesses. 80% work in agriculture and animal husbandry. The rest have different types of businesses, restaurants and general stores. They are asking for a loan to reinvest in their different businesses. The members appreciate and value the support given them in this manner and promise to complete their loan payments in the established time period.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Our member is asking for a loan to purchase a greater variety of products.

loans.name: Diana Soledad

texts.es:
La señora  Diana S. tiene 29 años  es socia del banco Comunal Corazones Unidos  hace dos años, vive con su esposo que trabaja como chofer de un bus interprovincial y su niña de tres años y está en su sexto mes de gestación en una casa arrendada  en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca  considerada la más bella del país por sus calles empedradas, sus ríos serpenteados, agraciados balcones de hierro, y bellos jardines forman parte de la atmósfera afable de esta ciudad histórica.
 
Diana labora un centro educativo donde brindan cursos de belleza, corte y confección, música, computación  se encuentra en esta labor hace 5 años y  hace un año se hizo  cargo ya que su papá es el dueño, labora de 8 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m., trabajando de domingo a domingo, también vende cosméticos a sus alumnas.

Los créditos que le han ayudo para su  centro educativo ya que se encuentra dos  años en el bankito invitada por una amiga, con su nuevo crédito  comprará  cremas, labiales, tratamientos, maquillajes,  y más cosméticos. Su meta es tener dos centros más de capacitación y comprarse un taxi.
texts.en:
Diana S. is 29 years and has been a member of the Corazones Unidos [Hearts United] Communal Bank for two years. She lives with her husband who works as a long-distance bus driver and their three-year-old daughter. She is also six months pregnant. They live in a rented home in the city of Cuenca, which is considered the prettiest in the country. Its cobblestone streets, winding rivers, wrought-iron balconies and beautiful gardens are part of the charming atmosphere of this historic city. Diana works in an education center that offers classes in cosmetology, hairstyling, music, and computer skills. She's been working there for 5 years and one year ago she took over the management of the center from her father, who is the owner. She works from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day of the week, and also sells cosmetics to her students. Her previous loans have helped her run the education center. She's been a part of the bank for two years, since a friend invited her. With this new loan she will buy creams, lipstick, skin treatments, make-up and other cosmetics. Her goal is to open two more centers and to buy a taxi.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase creams, lipstick, skin treatments, make-up and other cosmetics

loans.name: Apolonio

texts.es: Apolonio tiene 50 años, vive en su casa propia al lado de su esposa Flora  de 48 años, que es agricultora y con el menor de sus 5  hijos,  ya que son mayores e independientes. Desde muy joven, aprendió de sus padres y hermanos las técnicas agrícolas necesarias para obtener una cosecha exitosa, hoy es un gran agricultor, sembrando papa de buena calidad. En tanto su esposa e hijo menor lo ayudan en la actividad, con tal de que se desarrolle sus campos de cultivo, es por eso que están siempre vigilándolos, brindándoles el cuidado necesario con los fertilizantes y abono, para que logren recoger una buena producción. Le gusta mucho este trabajo porque sabe como lograr tener una buena cosecha, pese que es tedioso el trabajo, pero le da mucha satisfacción, para ella la vida en el campo es su vida. Cuando es tiempo de cosecha, Apolonio en compañía de su familia deben trabajar el doble, puesto que se requiere de mucho esfuerzo para recoger todas las papas listas para luego ser vendidas a los comerciantes mayoristas de la ciudad, que le ofrecen regulares ganancias económicas, permitiéndole vivir cómodamente. En adelante,  no solo desea aumentar su producción, si no también empezar a sembrar alverja, ya que el precio de esta legumbre se mantiene estable en el mercado nacional. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP por tanto promete en ser bien cumplido con sus cuotas, manifiesta además que le gusta trabajar con su grupo comunal, pues todos los integrantes son puntuales y responsables. Apolonio tiene pensado invertir el crédito en la compra de abono, pesticida y fertilizante para proteger sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Apolonio is 50 years old and lives in his own home with his wife Flora, who is 48, and with the youngest of their 5 children. The rest are grown and living independently. From a young age, Apolonio learned from his parents and his siblings the farming techniques necessary to obtain a successful harvest. Today he is a successful farmer who grows high-quality potatoes. Both his wife and his youngest son help him in this work, in order for his fields to be productive. Apolonio is always watching over his fields, caring for them as necessary with fertilizers so that they yield a good harvest. He enjoys his work because he knows how to get a good harvest. Although it can be tedious, it is satisfying to him because he enjoys this rural way of life. At harvest time, Apolonio and his family must work twice as hard, because it takes a great deal of effort to harvest all the potatoes. He then sells these to wholesalers in the city who offer him a steady income, allowing him to live comfortably. In the future, Apolonio would like to increase production and start to plant peas, because the price of peas has been stable on the national level, This is his third loan with MFP [the Kiva field partner] and he promises to be on time with his repayments. He also reports that he enjoys working with his communal bank group because all of the members are responsible and on-time in their payments. Apolonio plans to use this loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides to protect his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides for his crops.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es: Elvira tiene 33 años, vive en su casa propia al lado de su esposo Juan de 43 años, quien es agricultor y de sus 3 hijos, que aún estudian en el colegio. Bajo el cielo azul de la sierra, esta trabajadora mujer se despierta cada mañana para vigilar sus cultivos, que en compañía de su esposo, siembran papas, alverjas, lechugas y flores de gladiolos. Sabe que el trabajo agrícola requiere de mucha dedicación, si desean obtener una buena cosecha. Una ve que la producción esta lista para la venta, es transportada al mercado mayorista de la ciudad, en donde los comerciantes le ofrecen buenos precios, esto le permite recibir regulares ganancias. Por esta razón, es que le gusta mucho trabajar en el campo, ya que sabe que todo sacrificio tiene su recompensa y  más aún cuando puede brindarles una buena calidad de vida a sus hijos. Elvira sueña que sus hijos lleguen a estudiar una profesión  en la ciudad y no descansara hasta cumplirlo; y como es una mujer muy emprendedora, para el futuro tiene planeado sembrar en mayor cantidad, además quiere instalar un negocio de venta de productos de primera necesidad. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, además esta muy satisfecha con el trabajo de su grupo porque esta integrado por damas muy responsables en el pago puntual de sus cuotas. Elvira tiene planeado invertir el crédito en la compra de semilla de alverjas y fertilizantes para asegurar sus tierras en la siguiente siembra y lograr una cosecha productiva.
texts.en:
Elvira is 33 years old and lives in her own home alongside her husband, Juan, who is a 43 year old farmer. They have three children who are still in school. Beneath the blue sky of the sierra, this hard working women wakes up every morning to tend to her crops. With the help of her husband, she plants potatoes, peas, lettuce, and gladioli flowers. She knows that agricultural work requires a lot of dedication in order to obtain a good harvest. Once the produce is ready for selling, it is transported to the city’s major market where the tradesmen offer them a good price. This allows them to receive a regular income. For this reason, she loves working in the countryside. She knows that all her sacrifice has its rewards and allows her to create a good quality of life for her children. Elvira’s dream is that her children will study a profession in the city and she won’t rest until this happens. As she is an enterprising woman, she is planning to plant more crops in the future. In addition, she would like to install a business selling basic necessities. This is her first loan with MFP. She is very satisfied with the work of her group because it is made up of women who are very responsible and make their repayments on time. Elvira plans to use the credit to buy pea seeds and fertilizers in order to enrich her soils for future crops and have a productive harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pea seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Sopheap Pang Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap P. is 57 years old and she lives in Preak Raing village in Kandal province. She has been selected by the members to be the leader of this group loan which consists of four people. Each member will use the loan to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Mrs Sopheap P. is a grocery seller and is able to earn a small income to support her family. For this business, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities.

Mrs. Mrs Sopheap P. is widow with two children who are both seamstresses in the garment factory.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Eva's Group

texts.en:
Eva G. is from the town of Rizaluna Cordon, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Eva is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Eva G.'s group.

Eva is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Eva owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Eva has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Eva joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Eva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. Eva is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Eva from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sok Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok Ny C. is a 31-year-old married woman who lives in Taok Ma village in Kandal province. She is a farmer but she does not have a piece of land on which to grow a crop, so she decided to ask for a loan to add her saving to buy a plot of land.

Mrs. Sok Ny C.’s husband, Mr. Sokha Kai, owns a motorbike that he uses to pull a trailer to transport passengers and goods. He is shown with her in the photo. The couple has three children: two are students in the local school and the youngest one is a year old.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a plot of land to farm

loans.name: Artemio's Group

texts.en:
Artemio N. is from the village of Masigun. He is 48 years old. Artemio is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Artemio N.'s Group.

Artemio is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Artemio owns & operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Artemio has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Artemio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Artemio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Artemio is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Artemio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
34-year-old Nenita P. enjoys the life she spends loving and taking care of her two children whose ages are 1 and 12 years old. Despite the limited opportunities she and her family have, which hampers them from rising above poverty, Nenita still feels blessed because of the love and support of her husband in all her endeavors, especially in business.

In 1999 Nenita and her husband agreed to request for a loan through ASHI to be able to put up a business for her husband to manage. Through its revenue, her family would have a source of cash flow to support their daily needs.

Nenita was able to purchase two motorcycles for a transportation business. One is a tricycle with a sidecar attached and is operated by her husband, and the other one is rented by someone in their village. Because this is one of the common means of transportation for people in the whole of the town, since jeepneys (small buses) and buses are rare and are not accessible in remote villages, Nenita’s business has grown fairly well.

Now, as a matter of fact, Nenita has able to start up her own small sari-sari (variety) store business using the profits from her prior business.

While Nenita’s children are still young, she wants to grow her own business through the loan she is now requesting. This loan will be used to increase the inventory of her store such as foodstuffs, beverages, and other basic commodities for people in their neighborhood to access rather than having to spend money on fares to go to market. 

Nenita is hoping to be able to put up a savings fund for the sustainability of her businesses as well as for the education of her children in the future. She is looking forward to the day when she would be marching on stage together with her children for them to receive their medal and diploma for their graduation from college.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Kim Ang

texts.en:
Kim Ang N. is 39 years old and lives in Preaek Ta Hang village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Khoy Heng Phorn, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they grow crops for a living. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

Aside from farming, Mrs. Kim Ang N. is a pig breeder at home from which she can earn a little income to improve her family living. For her pig breeding, she decided to ask for a loan to buy four piglets to raise.

This couple has four children who are all students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy four piglets to raise

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhom L. is 42 years old and lives in Trakiet village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Seoun Sok is a musician who is able to earn a small income to support his family. He is shown with her in the photo.

With both these businesses, they still earn less income than needed to improve their family living. Thus, Mrs. Sokhom L. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. With the new business, she hopes to increase her income to improve her family living conditions.

This couple has four children: two are workers in Malaysia while two other are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Sophoan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoan C. is a 30-year-old married woman and she lives in Roneam Tnaot village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Mean Parn, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

Aside from farming, Mr. Mean Parn is employed in a rice mill and Mrs. Sophoan C. is a pig breeder. In order to support her pig breeding, Mrs. Sophoan C. decided to ask for a loan to buy seven piglets to raise and pig feed.

Mrs. Sophoan C. is the mother of three children: two are students in the local school while the youngest one is a year old.

loans.use: To buy seven piglets to raise and pig feed

loans.name: Bou's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Bou H. is 54 years old and the village bank president who has been selected by the thirteen members located in Sla Village in Takeo province. In this village loan, the members will each use their loan to support their different purpose.

Mr. Bou H. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice for a living. For his farm, he decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and rice seed and to hire a laborer to plow his farm.

Mr. Bou H.’s wife, Mrs. Vov Phorn, is a congee (a type of rice porridge) seller who is able to earn a little income to support her family. This couple has four children: two are on the staff of a casino club and two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide and to hire a laborer to plow his farm

loans.name: Chenda

texts.en: Mrs. Chenda C., of Kampong village in Takeo Province, is a 33-year-old married woman with four children, two of whom attend the local school, while the other two are yet too young to study. Chenda is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice for a living. In order to increase income to improve the family's living standards, she is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding and rice seed for planting, as well as to hire a laborer to plow her farm. In addition to farming, Chenda sells vegetables in a local market, while her husband, Mr. Vong Ngoeu, shown in the photo with her, is a motorcycle taxi driver who can earn a small income to help support the family.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding and to purchase rice seed and to hire a laborer to plow her farm.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Wenifreda

texts.en:
Wenifreda J., from the village of Sulangon, is 46 years old, married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Wenifreda owns and operates a business venture providing motorcycle transport service to local community members. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Wenifreda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC used to to repair a transport vehicle, she is now requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP for additional repairs. This will be Wenifreda's sixth loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Loda

texts.en:
Poverty has inspired Loda to continue her studies in college until she graduates and earns her degree. She is 26 years of age now and married to a 40-year-old security guard at one of the offices in town. Loda’s marriage union has blessed her with two sweet and loving children, ages three and seven years old. Though Loda’s husband supports her and her children financially, the woman still wants to be productive in her own way to support her own education and the needs of her children. Her husband’s income is yet too small to support things her family needs to be able to experience life beyond poverty.

When Loda joined ASHI in 2003, she requested a loan to start a “sari-sari” (variety) store, selling inventories of foodstuffs, beverages and other basic commodities for people in their village to purchase conveniently. Frequently her business can't be sustained and she has had to periodically shut it down. The loans she has received have been a great help in restoring her business. Despite those circumstances, Loda makes sure that she maintains an excellent repayment record with ASHI and attends the weekly ASHI center meetings. Assisted by her husband in fulfilling her responsibilities to ASHI, Loda is now requesting a loan to improve her business and to fully achieve her dream of making it sustainable and profitable to be able to support her needs in her studies as well as the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase a larger volume of grocery items and other basic commodities for her store inventories.

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli O. is from the village of Tinago, Ozamis City. She is 52 years old, married, and has one adult child. To make a living, Arceli owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for almost five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In November 2006, Arceli joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her seventh from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Korb's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Korb S. is 39 years old and the leader of this group loan. She has been selected by the members, who are located in Kor village in Takeo province. Each member of this group loan will use their loan for a different purpose.
Mrs. Korb S. and her husband, Mr. Pharn Set, are farmers who own a 2.5 hectare field to cultivate rice. For this farm, Mrs. Korb S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide and hire a farm laborer. Aside from farming, Mr. Pharn Set also works as a construction worker for which he receives a small salary to support his family. The couple has four children; three attend the local school while the youngest is a year old. Mrs. Thyda Kem and Mrs. March Eam, who are group guarantors, are also presented in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and hire a farm laborer

loans.name: Janet's Group

texts.en:
Janet P. is from the village of Mocag, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 48 years old. Janet is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Janet is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living Janet provides rice processing for local community members. Janet has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Janet joined ASKI to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting her second loan, for 8000 PHP, which she will use to purchase equipment for her business. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business.

About ASKI

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to improve the business.

loans.name: Alan

texts.en:
Alan C., is from the village of Carangan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is 38 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Alan owns and operates a piggery. He has been engaged in this kind of business for over ten years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Alan joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is now requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock of feed. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

loans.name: Erlinda's Group

texts.en:
Erlinda C. is from the village of Makabbac, Iguig, Cagayan. She is 63 years old. Erlinda is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Erlinda is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living Erlinda plants and harvests a variety of vegetables for sale. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Erlinda joined ASKI to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. Erlinda is requesting her eighth loan, for 15000 PHP, which she will invest in her business. She plans to use the additional revenue to make improvements to her house.

About ASKI

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Northeastern and Central areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To invest in her vegetable business.

loans.name: Chhoeun's Group

texts.en: Mr. Chhoeun N. is 51 years old and the village bank president who has selected by the 19 members, who are located in Krang Sbaek village in Takeo province. Each member of this group loan will use their loan for different purposes. Mr. Chhoeun N. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare field to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Yorn Oung, is a tamarind seller who earns a small income to support her family. Mr. Chhoeun N. is requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle to provide transport for his child, who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his child

loans.name: Ofelia's Group

texts.en:
Ofelia S. is from the village of Brgy. Bitnong, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ofelia is 47 years old, married, and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living Ofelia raises pigs for fattening and sale. Ofelia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ofelia joined ASKI to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

Ofelia is requesting her third loan, for 12000 PHP, which she will use to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family’s general living conditions.

loans.name: Chhoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhoeun K. is 47 years old and the village bank president selected by the 20 members, who are located in Krang Sbaek village in TaK. province. Each member of this village loan will use their loan for a different purpose.
Mrs. Chhoeun K. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In addition to farming, she also sells big pots to earn a small income to support her family. For her big pot business, Mrs. Chhoeun K. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a horse to transport her big pots. Her husband, Mr. Han K., is a tamarind seller who can support his family with his small income. The couple has a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy a horse to transport her big pots to sell

loans.name: Jessica's Group

texts.en:
Jessica J. is from the village of San Pablo, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is the leader of an 11-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Jessica is 28 years old, married, and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store selling hog feed in the local community. Jessica has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Jessica joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.name: Rachel's Group

texts.en:
Rachel S. is from the village of Calaca-an. She is the leader of a three-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Rachel is 31 years old and single. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rachel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2004, Rachel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Rachel is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her ninth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.name: Helen's Group

texts.en:
Helen M. is from the town of Sto. Domingo, Alfonso Lista, Ifugao. She is the leader of a ten-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Helen M. group.
Helen is 30 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a fishing business, catching and selling freshwater fish to the market. Helen has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Helen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Khorn's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 17 people located in Trapeang village in Takeo province. Mrs. Khorn N. is 44 years old and the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Each member of this village loan will use it to support a different purpose.
Mrs. Khorn N. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare piece of land to cultivate rice. In addition to farming, she is also a pig breeder at home. In order to support her pig breeding business, Mrs. Khorn N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig food. Her husband, Mr. Vanna Chhil, is a village chief who receives a small salary to support his family. This couple has three children; one is a construction worker and two are students.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Nhey

texts.en: Mrs. Nhey T. is 44 years old. She is a villager who lives in Prey Ta Mau village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Mos Toun, are farmers who own a four-hectare piece of land to cultivate rice for a living. Mrs. Nhey T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to hire a laborer to plow her farm. Aside from farming, Mr. Mos Toun is a duck breeder who earns a small income to support his family. This couple has three children who all are students. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and to hire a laborer to plow her farm.

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en: Mrs. Sarin Y. is a 29-year-old married woman who lives in Roneam Tnaot village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns three hectares of land on which to cultivate rice. In order to support this farm, Mrs. Sarin Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide and to pay a laborer to plow her farm. Her husband, Mr. Vireak Sun, is a healer in a local village. Mrs. Sarin Y. is a mother of three children; two of the children attend the local school and the youngest one is five years old.

loans.use: To pay a laborer to plow her farm.

loans.name: Vy

texts.en: Mrs. Vy S. is 46 years old. She is a villager who lives in Smaong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns two hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming, she also breeds pigs at home. In order to support her pig business, Mrs. Vy S. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets and pig food for pig breeding. Her husband, Mr. Pharng Ros, is a construction worker who receives a small salary to support his family. This couple has four children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other three are students.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets and pig food

loans.name: Song

texts.en: Mr. Song S. is a 25-year-old married man with a child who is too young to study or work. They all live in Pun Phnum village in Takeo province. Mr. Song S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Sokha Nak, is a seamstress in a garment factory where she receives a small salary to support her family. In order to increase his income to improve his family's living conditions, Mr. Song S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Connie's Group

texts.en:
Connie M. is from the village of Brgy. Nangalisan, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Connie is 32 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Connie has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.
In 2008, Connie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 26,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Connie is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Lubele North Laker Lucy Group

texts.en: L. Lucy is a hardworking business lady who is 27 years old. She is a married lady with three children. Two of the children are schooling. She also has dependents and one of them is schooling. She deals in the charcoal business and she has been operating this business for a period of two months. She is using the loan to purchase charcoal to sell in Pader. Her future hope is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: Nilmini

texts.en:
Nilmini is a 42-year-old married woman who lives with her husband, daughter and son (ages 23 and 20).  She lives in the town of Hikkaduwa. She wants to earn some income, because she doesn't like to depend on others. She does not even like to depend on her husband for financial assistance.  Her son is an army officer and her daughter is helping with coir making.

Nilmini has a coir (coconut-shell fiber) business, in which she takes the fibers of local coconuts and weaves them into household items like string, rope, and floor mats. She has two years of experience in this field. 

Nilmini has requested a 55,000-rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC to buy some coir for the coir business. Currently she does not have the financial capital necessary to grow.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy coir

loans.name: Renuka

texts.en:
Renuka is a 48-year-old married woman and lives with her husband, one daughter, and two sons. 

Renuka's business involves making coir products, and she has a lot of experience with this type of business. She creates carpets, coir mats and so on with the coir, which consists of extracted coconut fibers.  There is strong competition in her area for selling coir products.   Renuka's husband helps her by delivering and selling them to customers, which greatly helps the business.

Renuka has requested a 55,000-rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka, which she will use to buy raw coir and develop the coir products.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy coir for weaving

loans.name: Darmalatha

texts.en:
Darmalatha is a 48-year-old married woman living in Hikkaduwa, Galle with her husband and two children.  Darmalatha and her husband have been managing the business (which consists of cultivating a cinnamon garden) by themselves.  She devotes her full efforts towards cultivating her cinnamon garden, step by step, and uses the income to help support herself.  

She has managed her business for five years now with her husband. In her business, she works hard and enjoys the benefits of favorable weather for cinnamon gardening and high quality land for cultivating.  

Darmalatha has asked for a 30,000-rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to buy fertilizer and chemicals for her cinnamon garden.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and chemicals for the cinnamon garden.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: 51-year-old Fe D. lives in the first Barangay (village) of the province of Antique along with her 56-year-old husband and six children who range in age from 15 to 24 years old. Despite being poor, Fe and her family have been able to enjoy their lives by maximizing the resources of their community. Her husband and her 23-year-old son are fishermen and have been earning money through fishing. Fe sells the fish they catch in their neighborhood. Someday Fe wishes that her husband and child would be able to go fishing more often and catch more fish by having their own fishing motorboat. Through this, Fe would be able to sell more fish in the market and in their neighborhood for bigger revenue. Aside from that, she also wants to have her own small “sari-sari” (variety) store where she sells a few varieties of foodstuffs, beverages and other basic commodities. To be able to do this, Fe is requesting a much larger loan through ASHI. Proceeds of her business will be used to support the education of her two children who are still in school and augment an improved the life for her family.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items and a motorboat for fishing.

loans.name: Rathnawathi

texts.en:
Rathnawathi is a 58-year-old married woman living in Hikkaduwa, Galle with her husband and youngest daughter, age 23. Her two sons are married.

Rathnawathi's husband has a small business producing cinnamon oil, which he sells to local and foreign customers. Every morning they wake up early to make the cinnamon oil, which they have been doing for four years now. During most of the day, Rathnawathi goes to collect cinnamon leaves from the cinnamon gardens.

Her daughter helps her as well when she has the time. She has a very good location for her business, because her area is situated near to Hikkaduwa. Hikkaduwa is a tourist destination. Their business has a good market and a good demand.

Rathnawathi has requested a 40,000-rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to purchase some cinnamon leaves to compress and make into oil.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy some cinnamon leaves

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a 34-year-old farmer.  He has had experience in dairy farming for four years.  He is a member of Githiruini B self-help group whose members are farmers.  He is dedicated to the group because he gets an opportunity to share ideas with fellow members and save money on weekly basis.  In addition, the group members also guarantee each other's loans.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 from Faulu Kenya. He wants to use this loan to buy a dairy cow.  He hopes to stabilize his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ederlina's Group

texts.en:
Ederlina D. is from the village of Brgy. Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Ederlina is 52 years old, married, and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Ederlina has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2006, Ederlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ederlina is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 47-year-old married man who has four children.  He has been selling poles for the past five years.  In addition, he rears dairy cattle and grows tea and vegetables to earn a living.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya in a group called Wendo, he has been able to start dairy farming and put electricity in his home.  This is because he was previously guaranteed a loan of Kes. 20,000 from Faulu Kenya by his group members. He has requested a loan of Kes. 30,000 to buy more poles for sale.  He hopes to educate his children to the university level.  He dreams of owning a lorry in the future for transporting his goods.

loans.use: To buy poles

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is 56 years old and married with eight children.  He has been selling shoes and clothes for 20 years. In addition, he does farming.  George works hard in his business so that he can provide for his family and educate his five children who are still in school.  He joined a group in Faulu Kenya called Forty in One to easily access financial support.  This is because when a member takes a loan he is guaranteed by the group members.  He wants to buy more clothes and shoes for sale. Hence, he has requested a loan of Kes. 80,000 from Faulu Kenya.  He believes that this loan will help him meet the needs of his different customers.  He dreams of opening other shops in other areas in the future. He wants to invest deeply into dairy farming in 10 years time.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes for sale

loans.name: Lagwai B Auma Doreen Group

texts.en: A. Doreen is a hardworking business lady, 29 years old and married with five children. She makes local brew and she has been in the business for over eight months. She is using the loan to purchase local brew ingredients such as millet, sorghum, maize, and yeast for making local brew for sale. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to build a home and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase local brew ingredients

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Mrs. Thorn P., 44 years old, is a villager who lives in Pun Phnum village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Tob Yem, is a police officer who receives a small salary to support his family. Even with both businesses, they still don't earn enough income to support the family. Thus, Mrs. Thorn P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. This couple has two children who are students in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Sok's Group

texts.en: Mr. S. K. is 57 years old and is the village bank president. He was selected by nine people who are located in Tramug Chrum village in Takeo province. Each member of this village group loan will use the loan for different purposes. Mr. S. K. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land on which he cultivates rice. In order to support this farm, Mr. S. K. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a water machine to support his crop. His wife, Mrs. Varn Mich, is banana seller who can support her family by her small income. This couple has three children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory and the other one is a student in a local school.

loans.use: To purchase a water machine

loans.name: Sokha's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Boeb N. is 39 years old and is the village bank president. She was selected by the eight-member group located in Sla village in Takeo province. Each member of this village loan will use it for a different purpose. Mrs. Boeb N. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice and she weaves mats. In order to increase her income to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Boeb N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. Mrs. Boeb N. is a widow with three children who are all students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Ny's Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of four people located in Prey Rumdeng village in Takeo province. Mrs. Ny N. is 35 years old. She is the village bank president, selected by all the members. Each member of this village loan will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Ny N. is a farmer who owns three hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. She is also a pig breeder at home. With both businesses, she can earn a small income to support her family. Mrs. Ny N. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding, to buy fertilizer and to hire a laborer to plow her farm. Mrs. Ny N. is a widow with two children who are students in the local school. They also help their mother's business.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig food and fertilizer and to hire a laborer to plow her farm.

loans.name: C2861 Niyomwungeli Group

texts.en:
Rehema was born in 1954 and is a widow without children. She is the representative of a group which is called Niyomwungeli in the local language.

Rehema owns a small shop which sells green bananas and has an experience of five years in her business. She employs one person in her business as a helper so that her business runs well. Her business starts at six in the morning and remains open until seven in the evening, every day except Sunday.

Rehema and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses for the purpose of earning more profits. With the profits, they expect to improve their businesses. Rehema, particularly, needs a fridge which will allow her to create a new business of selling cold soft drinks.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Oyunbileg

texts.en:
Oyunbileg L., 31, is married and the mother of two children. Her oldest daughter, Enhchimeg, is 13 years-old and attends a local primary school. Her youngest daughter is two years-old and stays at home. 

Oyunbileg operates an offal (meat) trade business with her husband at Huchit Shonhor, the biggest food market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They have been operating their business since 2000, and they have great experience from the last 10 years. Oyunbileg purchases her products daily because offal is made fresh daily. With her earnings, she purchased a car for her family. In addition, with last year's profit and loan money, she was able to finish building a house with her husband's siblings help. 

Oyunbileg is a very hardworking and responsible person. She says, “I have been planning to own my own grocery store because there are not any grocery stores around here. Therefore, we expect to earn great profits from this business.”  She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to build a grocery store.

loans.use: To build a grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 500 ducks

loans.name: John

texts.en:
A determined and hardworking K. John is vibrant-sounding in terms of business and agriculture enterprises in Kakungu village, Ntungamo. He deals in poultry farming and supplies trays of eggs to hotels and shop vendors and also owns a banana plantation. All that generates income for his family.

John’s main drawback has been lack of funding to purchase feed for his poultry and mulches for his plantations and this has reduced his yields. Therefore, with a loan, he will be able to improve his yields of milk, eggs and bananas, thus enabling him to meet his customers’ high demand. It will also increase his sales revenue, hence making him more able to meet his family requirements such as tuition fees for his children and enable him to live a more self-sustaining life. He will use the loan to buy more poultry feeds and mulch his plantations.

loans.use: To purchasing fertilizer and more poultry feed

loans.name: Thon

texts.en: Mrs. Thon C. is 43 years old. She is a villager who lives in Daom village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns two hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Mean Ngoung, is a rice mill laborer who receives a small income to support his family. Even with both businesses, they still don't earn enough income to support the family. Thus, Mrs. Thon C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. With a new loan, she hopes to increase her income to improve the family's living conditions. This couple has three children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory and the last one is a student in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Battsengel

texts.en:
Battsengel M., 33, lives with his wife and two children in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  His oldest daughter attends a local secondary school. His youngest, a 4-year-old old daughter, attends a local kindergarten. 

Battsengel operates a clothing trading business at Narantuul, the biggest market in Mongolia. He has been operating his business since 2005 and has gained significant experience as a businessman.  Over the past years he has steadily expanded his business and built a loyal customer base. Today his working capital is 3,500,000 MNT.  His daily revenue is between 50,000 – 150,000 MNT. His profit is between 40 – 50 %.

Since he began his business, his family's standard of living has improved. With his last two year's earnings, he purchased a house for his family. Battsengel is an industrious person. The most important thing to him is being able to provide for his children's education. He says, “I have been planning to be financially able to provide higher educations for my two children after they graduate from high school.” He is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase the latest women's clothing including shirts and outerwear to resell to his many customers.

loans.use: To purchase clothing.

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en: The eight members who make up the village bank loan are located in Trapean Young village in Takeo province. Mrs. Phally H. is 36 years old and is the village bank president, selected by the members. Each member of this village loan will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Phally H. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice. She is also a silk weaver. For her silk weaving business, Mrs. Phally H. decided to ask for a loan to buy silk weaving supplies to support her silk weaving. Her husband, Mr. Teou H. is a construction worker who gets a small salary to support his family. This couple has three children who all are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy silk weaving supplies

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en:
Abraham N. is from the village of Brgy. Quezon, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 29 years old, married, and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Abraham owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Abraham has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Abraham joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be his first from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Burentugs

texts.en:
Burentugs P., 39, is married and the mother of a 17-year-old daughter. She and her family live together in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter, Lhamhuu, attends a local secondary school. Her husband, Bayrbat, operates a tailoring business from their home. He manufactures a variety of products including sheets and pillowcases. 

During the day, Burentugs operates a second hand blanket and sheet trading business at Narantuul, the biggest market in Mongolia. She has been operating her business since 2005 and has built a loyal customer base. With a lot of hard work and determination, today her working capital exceeds 8,500,000 MNT. Her profit is between 20 – 40 %. 

Burentugs has been planning to expand her business and create a sewing workshop in the future. With her and her husband's last couple of years business profits, they purchased an apartment for 18,000,000 MNT for their family. Burentugs is a very hardworking person who has a great business mind. She has been planning to provide a higher education for her daughter. Burentugs is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more blankets and sheets at wholesale prices in order to resell them at Narantuul market.

loans.use: To purchase blankets and sheets.

loans.name: Idayat

texts.en: Idayat has a hair dressing salon where she makes lovely hair styles for her customers.  She also sells hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. She is 40 years old, married with 3 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Chhauy

texts.en: Mr. S., 40, fishes in and around the river in his community. He earns his daily profit by fishing. Also, he provides the fish he catches to his wife to sell at retail at the market. By doing that, this couple is able to generate of about $7 per day to help be responsible for their family. S. wants to accrue the fishing tool and is asking for a loan to purchase bamboo to produce materials to use for his fishing. S. is hopeful that the loan will allow him to increase the quantity of fish he catches. The family has four children; three are single and the other one is now married. To help solve the family crisis, two of the children are employed in the garment factory. (S. was busy when the photo was taken so his wife is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To purchase bamboo to produce materials used for fishing.

loans.name: Odongerel

texts.en:
Odongerel B., 39, is married and the mother of three children. She and her family live together in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Odongerel operates a jean selling business with her husband at a Narantuul, the largest market in Mongolia. They have been operating their business since 2002, and have steadily expanded their business over the past eight years. 

Odongerel and her husband gained much experience in previous years and have built a loyal customer base. Her monthly revenue is 300,000 – 500,000 MNT.  Her profit is in 40 – 50%. Odongerel plans to expand her product line in the future. With her last two years' profit,  she purchased a car for her family.  She is a responsible person who has paid her loans on time in the past. Odongerel is also a very hardworking person. She plans to provide higher education for her three children in the future. 

Odongerel is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more jeans from China in order to sell them at Narantuul market.

loans.use: To purchase more jeans to sell.

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose sells clothes and wallet at retail prices to make a living. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is 45 years old, married with 2 children. Her husband is a commercial tailor and he also supports their home. She is requesting for the loan amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more clothes to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun M., 49, lives with her son and daughter-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Oyun operates a small products trade business at Narantuul, the biggest market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She mostly sells purses, slippers and other small products. Oyun has been operating her business since 2000 and she has been successful in operating her business. After years of successful operations she managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 2,000,000 MNT. Her average daily revenue is a minimum of 50,000 and maximum of 200,000.

Her 25-year-old son, Batbayr, operates a transportation business. He plans to provide his service to tourists with the experience that he has gained in previous years. 

Oyun provided money to build a house for her son with her year 2009's profit. Oyun is a very hardworking person. She plans to finish the house quickly and live there with her family. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a variety of bags in anticipation of graduation ceremonies when the demand for her products is very high. In addition, she will use some of the loan money to make the rest of the payments for the family's car.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of bags.

loans.name: C2877 Twuzuzanye Group

texts.en:
Marie Chantal was born in 1981 and is married with three children. The first born is 12 years, the next is 9 years old and the last is 5 years old. Marie Chantal is the leader of a group which is called Twuzuzanye. This group contains six people: five women and one man.

Marie Chantal owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products. Her husband is in the government staff and both they work hardly for the development of their family. Marie Chantal has an experience of four years and her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Marie Chantal and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to sort out some of the problems they face in their businesses like not being able to satisfy the demands of their customers.

Once the satisfaction of their clients is reached, Marie Chantal and her group will be able to earn more profits to be reinvested in their businesses.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Precious

texts.en:
Precious lives in Lagos, married and have five children. She is been a LAPO client for over four years now. With her loan from LAPO micro finance she was able to manage her business very well.
54 years old Precious sells biscuit in wholesale and retail to costumers in her locality and has been in this trade for over five years. She is asking for a loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more biscuit in cartons to sell, this she said will lead to reduction in price thereby increasing her profit and will also enable her meet the demand of customers. She says with the increase in profit, her family will be better cared for. Thanks to all Kiva lenders for their good work

loans.use: To purchase more biscuit in cartons to sell

loans.name: Srouy

texts.en: Mrs. Srouy S., 26, is a married mother of four small kids, all of whom are enrolled in school and under her care. Srouy S. is a local farmer who plants rice and vegetables on the land that she inherited from her parents. But with the farming season approaching, she doesn’t have enough materials to supply her field, so she is looking for a loan to buy fertilizer and crop seeds. She proposes to use the other half of the loan to buy a piece of farmland, on which she will plant a variety of crops. Srouy S.'s husband assists her in growing crops.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, crop seeds and a piece of farmland.

loans.name: Yolanda's Group

texts.en:
Yolanda D. is from the town of Raniag Ramon. She is the leader of an eight-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Yolanda D.'s group.
Yolanda is 41 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Yolanda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her third from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Heang Thea

texts.en: Mrs. Heang Thea T. is 33 years old and a villager who lives in Krang Pou village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Nov Phoung, are farmers who own two hectares of land to cultivate rice. For this farm, Mrs. Heang Thea T. decided to ask for a loan to pay a laborer to plow her farm. Aside from farming, Mrs. Heang Thea T. is a vegetable seller who earns a small income to support her family. This couple has four children; three are attending the local school and the youngest one is five years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To pay a laborer to plow her farm.

loans.name: Deji

texts.en: Deji O. is a hard working and friendly man. He loves his business because of the opportunity to interact with his customers. He sells mattresses at retail prices to his customers. He is 32 years old, single without children. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more mattresses to sell.  He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more mattresses to sell

loans.name: Lang

texts.en: Mrs. Lang T. is 56 years old and she lives in Krang Pou village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Phorn Phoung, are farmers who own 3.50 hectares of land to cultivate rice. For this farm, Mrs. Lang T. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to purchase a plowing machine to support her farm crop. Mrs. Lang T. is a mother of four children; one is a farm laborer and the other three are farmers and also help on their parent's farm. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To add to her savings to purchase a plowing machine

loans.name: Margarita's Group

texts.en:
Margarita C. is from the city of Calao West, Santiago. She is the leader of a 16-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Margarita C.'s group.
Margarita is 57 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Margarita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Margarita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Margarita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Tito's Group

texts.en: Tito C. is from the village of San Roque. He is 41 years old and is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Tito C.'s Group. Tito is married and has one school-aged child. Tito owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Tito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Tito is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This loan will be his twelfth from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand his product offering

loans.name: Ton

texts.en: Mrs. S. is 48 years old. She sells cupcakes from her store at her home. She sells to people who are her nearby neighbors and usually generates about $4 each day. She also sells the cakes in bulk to middlemen who then take them to retail. S. now has five children. Two of the children are married and live separately, and the rest are single and work as garment laborers. She has another financial earner in her husband, who grows rice. S. will be using part of her loan to buy a cow to raise for her family and the rest to accumulate capital for her cake sale trade.

loans.use: To buy a cow and to accumulate capital for cake sale trade.

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola is 34 years old and a mother of three. She sells frozen food like fish, chicken and also sells drinks e.t.c. to earn a living in Lagos.
Bola opens her shop everyday of the week from 8am to 6pm. Her joy is assisting her husband who is a driver in making sure the family needs are better meet.
Bola is requesting for the loan amount of NGN100, 000 to purchase more frozen food to sell, this she said will enable her meet the demand of her numerous customers and boost her profit margin. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen food and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Hanh's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Moeung Prachen village in Takeo province. Mrs. Hanh V. is the leader of the group, selected by its members. Each member of the group will use the loan to support her own purposes.

Mrs. Hanh V. is 59 years old and a widow who lives with two adopted children. She is a pig breeder who earns a small income to support herself and her adopted children. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets to enlarge her business activities.

loans.use: To buy more piglets.

loans.name: C2361 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Emelyne is 26 years old and is married with children: the first born is 7 years old and the last one is 4 years old.

Emelyne is the representative of a group which is called Abishyizehamwe in the local language. This group contains five members, all of them women.

Emelyne owns a small shop selling various styles of clothes. She is serious woman in her business and is organized as well. She has an experience of one year in her daily activities. Her small shop is open from eight in the morning to five in the evening, every day except Sunday.

Emelyne and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses through purchasing more products.
