With this loan Emelyne will be able to employ one person from her community as the business will be expanded. This will attract more customers which will help her to obtain more profits. With the profits she expects to earn, she will be able to save money for the future and to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Noem

texts.en:
Mrs. Noem K. is a villager in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province and she was born in 1976. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local public school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

Mrs. Noem K. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land where she grows rice and vegetables to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Phall K., is a palm juice collector who sells sugar palm juice to support the family.

Although they work hard, these jobs do not let them earn much income, so they want to start a new business. Because they do not have enough money to support the new business, Mrs. Noem K. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. With the rest of the loan she wants to buy fertilizer and rice seed to do farming this current year.

loans.use: To buy a cow, fertilizer and rice seed to do farming.

loans.name: Moul

texts.en:
Mrs. C. is a single woman, 30 years old, who lives alone in a medium house located in the capital of Phnom Penh. She earns a living by working as a sewing worker in industry for which she is paid a set salary. She has parents who currently live in the rural area of the province.

The rainy season is approaching and C. always faces a problem: her house cracks when the heavy rains fall. C. is applying for a loan to replace the broken roof of her old house.

loans.use: To repair the broken roof of her old house.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mrs. Keo P. wan born in 1952 and she lives in Angk Ta Phouk village in Takeo province. She is a widow with three children who are seamstresses in a garment factory. Mrs. Keo P. is a farmer who owns 1.5 hectares of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family living, and on the side she is a chicken breeder at her home also.

Mrs. Keo P.'s problem is that the workplace of her children is a long way from her home. So to improve the family's living conditions, she is seeking a loan to buy a new motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
38 years old Taiwo is married with three children and they live in Lagos. She is a member in LAPO micro finance and has been a faithful client for some years. Taiwo sells drinks in wholesale and retail, she also supply electrode used for welding to welders and has been in these businesses for the past three years. She is very concerned over her costumers’ satisfaction, she make sure their demand meet. She has two sales assistant that are paid monthly. With the profit from the business she could provide for the children’s education and their well being.
            .
Taiwo is asking for a loan of NGN170,000 to purchase more drinks to sell as this will enable her get better discount and more profit on each sale. She promise to pay back promptly and she says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Zinunula Omunaku, Mityana Group

texts.en:
M. Meseche is a serene, 53-year-old, happily married man with fifteen children, all above the age of 15. He also takes care of four orphans.

To shoulder the financial responsibility of taking care of these children and orphans, Miseche owns a small tea-packaging business in Miseebe, Mityana. He took root ten years ago and, with this business, he has in a way managed to provide for his family's needs.

Miseche’s dream is to expand his tea-packing business into a wholesale franchise. With this loan, he wants to buy tea-packaging bags and also pay for his own trademark logos.

loans.use: To buy tea-packaging bags and boxes and also pay for his own trademark logos

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Mrs. Som P. is a 55 year-old widow mother. She currently takes care of two kids who are teenagers and employed. To make a living, Som P. sells different types of vegetables from her rented store at the local market. She sells to people who come to buy ingredients for their cooking and usually generates about $5 each day. She is very busy at her business activity because she has many clients needing to buy her vegetables. In addition, she also grows some vegetables on the land she owns.

Som P. is taking out her loan to buy a pump to irrigate her crops. With any remaining cash from the loan, she will buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To buy a pump to irrigate her crops.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov E. and her husband, Mr. Chor KoE., live in Angk Ta Phouk village in Takeo province. They have three children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory. The third is studying in a local public school. Mrs. Pov E. is a farmer who owns a three-hectare plot of land. On the land, she cultivates rice to sell in order to support her family. Her husband is a fisherman. Although they try to work hard, they still need to earn more income. Thus, they want to start a new business, but they do not have enough money to support it. To improve their family's living situation, Mrs. Pov E. is requesting a loan to buy a piece of agricultural machinery. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy agricultural machinery

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sahiya S

texts.en: Sahiya S. A. is a married woman with two school-aged children. She runs a drink business in Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam, selling varieties of soft drinks and some food items. She purchases the goods for her business from wholesale suppliers. She has been in the business for six years. The income enables her to meet her family's daily financial needs and to add capital to the business. She needs a loan of TZS 1,200,000 to buy more goods for her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her business

loans.name: Lourdes' Group

texts.en:
Lourdes V. is from the village of Brgy. Common, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Lourdes is 57 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Lourdes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a happy woman. She is also a hard working woman. She sells crates of drinks at retail prices to make a living. She hopes to grow and expand her business. She is 45 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband is a photographer and he also supports their home. Her children are excelling in school and this makes her happy as a mother. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en:
Beatha is 46 years old and is married with five children who are between 2 and 18 years old.

Beatha struggles by selling a variety of goods in her shop. Those goods are like soap, juice, cooking oil, biscuits and foodstuffs like rice, sugar, etc. This is her fifth successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Beatha needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through adding a variety of highly-demanded goods which hopefully will increase her sales as well as her profits. With these profits, Beatha will keep reinvesting in her business and building a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more soap, juice, cooking oil, biscuits and foodstuffs like rice and sugar

loans.name: Salima

texts.en: Salima H. is an entrepreneur who lives in Tanzania. She is a married woman with three school-aged children. She runs a food shop in Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases goods for her business from the city market at Kariakoo and the Kigamboni business shopping center. She also buys direct from wholesale food suppliers. She sells to retail customers at Kigamboni. The business income helps her to meet her family's daily financial needs, as well as to expand her business. She needs a loan of TZS 1,000,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy food for her food shop

loans.name: Etienne

texts.en:
Etienne is 31 years old and is single. He is still living with his parents.

Etienne owns a small grocery business. This business is profitable in his region which is the reason why it was chosen by Etienne as his principal activity. Etienne is seasoned in his business simply because he has two years of experience. The hours of his business are from six in the morning to nine in the evening every day, even during the weekend.

Etienne is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing his business. With this loan he needs to buy a fridge which will be used in his grocery. With the extra profits, Etienne hopes to buy his own house so that he can get married in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge for his grocery store

loans.name: Bello

texts.en:
A. needs NGN70, 000 to purchase more drinks and cloths to sell and make more profit to reinvest into the business and provide for her children needs. She has been in the business for some years. With the proceeds from the business she could support and assist her husband who is a civil servant in paying their bills. 

A. is 32 years old and she is bless with 2 children and needs more money to expand her business in future. She lives with her family in Lagos. She appreciates all Kiva leaders for their initiative.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and cloths to sell.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is a hard working and friendly man. He loves his business because of the opportunity to interact with his customers. He sells medicines at retail prices to his customers. He is 43 years old, married with children.  He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more medicines to sell.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Noah

texts.en: To make a living in Ibadan, A. sells medicines. She hopes to grow her business. She is 33 years old, married with 2 children. Her husband is a carpenter and he also supports their home. She is a LAPO client. (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and else where in Africa. She is requesting for a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Suzana

texts.en: Suzana M. is a small business owner and a married woman. She runs a café (food vendor) at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells varieties of both cooked and fried food, as well as soft drinks. She purchases her supplies from the shops at Kariakoo and Buguruni food market shopping center. She has been in the business for three years, and the income generated enables her to boost up the business. She needs a loan of TZS 800,000 to expand the business by buying more goods.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Ndorogi 1 Rukundo, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
On the face of it, T. Spedita seems a hard-grinding business lady. The 35-year-old married mother of five school-going children sweats her guts out selling produce such as peas, beans, millet and maize flour in the small rural town of Kakunama, Ibanda district. She has been doing this for the last ten years.

Spedita is able to make close to 200,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. This is quite modest by any standards and, as such, she requires a loan that will help her buy more food supplies for her business.

Spedita belongs to a group of twenty-two members and they are on their 18th loan. They insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more goods like beans and maize to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 45 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband also works to support their home. She sells for long hours to make her business sustainable. She sells cassava dough popularly known as fufu or akpu in Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more cassava to cook more cassava dough to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava to cook more cassava dough to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a mother of 1 and she is 32 years of age. She lives in Lagos and she sells ice block to customers. Her husband is a civil servant and they reside in Lagos. She and her husband work hard in order to improve their living standard.  She has been in her business for 3 years and she loves the business very well. 

She hopes for business expansion and she is requesting for the loan of NGN150, 000 to purchase one freezer and generating set to more ice block to sell. This will enable her make more ice block and avoid the problem of power failure. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase one freezer and generating set to make more ice block to sell.

loans.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 38 years old and is married with three children who are 1, 6 and 14 years old.

Odette has been struggling in the business of selling women’s clothes. This is her second successful year in this business which she operates from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Odette is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional styles of clothes which, hopefully, will increase her profits. With these profits, she will keep reinvesting in her business and saving for a better living in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more women's clothes to sell

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo sells planks at retail prices. He is a hard working man and he hopes to expand in his business. He is 40 years old, married with 3 children. His wife is a teacher and she also supports their home.  He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 130,000 to purchase more planks to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Mutio

texts.en: Mutio is a 49-year-old married man, who is blessed with four children. He has a retail shop in a slum called Kwa Reuben. He has 10 years of experience in the business. He also runs a boutique to earn a living. He was previously employed before he went into business. He intends to add maize flour, cereals, cooking fat and sugar to his stock and to expand his shop. Therefore, he has requested a loan of KES 90,000 from Faulu Kenya. For him to take out this loan, he has been guaranteed by his group members under Faulu Kenya. He is a hardworking and visionary man who hopes to open a wholesale shop in the future. Mutio appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping him to educate his children, expand his business and save his money.

loans.use: To add maize flour, cereals, cooking fat and sugar to his stock and to expand his shop

loans.name: C2359 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Seraphine is 44 years old, married with three children. Her first is 10 years old, the next is  8 years old, and the last is five years old. Seraphine’s husband is a farmer. Seraphine owns a small shop where she sells foodstuffs such as beans and sorghum. Seraphine has an experience of five years in these activities.  Seraphine has chosen this business simply because is profitable in her region. Seraphine is the leader of a group which is called ABISHYIZEHAMWE in the local language. This group consists of five women. 

Seraphine and her group are now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business.Seraphine particularly hopes to earn more profits from selling large quantities of foodstuffs. With the extra money, Seraphine plans to reinvest in her business and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is a 22-year-old single man. He started tailoring three years ago after he finished high school. He makes and sells men's suits and trousers. He has membership with Sunshine self help group in Faulu Kenya. He appreciates the group members for previously guaranteeing him a loan of KES 20,000. He used this loan to boost his business, and currently he is able to pay rent for his business premises. He has requested a loan of KES 30,000 to buy fabric for making suits. He hopes to get married and be able to educate his children in the future.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Aloys

texts.en:
Aloys was born in 1978 and is still single. He owns a small business selling various products such as soap powder, cosmetic products, plastic cups and so on. Aloys has an experience of five years in his business but his profit is not enough to expand his business and sort out his personal problems. The hours of his business are from 5 in the morning to 10 in the evening every day except on Sunday.  His business is known in the region and that is the reason Aloys needs to expand it.

Aloys is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to grow his business through purchasing the other products like beans, green bananas, sugar, and other foodstuffs so that he can satisfy the demand of his customers. In this way, Aloys will be able to obtain more profits. Using this increased profit, Aloys expects to get married.

loans.use: The purchase of soap powder, cosmetic products, plastic cups and so on

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en: Lawrence loves clothing and that is why he sells new shirts at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to own a big boutique for males only in the future. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He sells 48 years old, married with 5 children. His wife also works to support their home. Lawrence’s children attend school and they are excelling. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more shirts to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shirts to sell

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont trois mariées et une veuve vivant dans des grandes familles polygames dans le quartier Koulikoro de la ville de Koutiala. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et 4 enfants. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de bon voisinage et font le commerce d’habits, de boissons et la restauration. 
Pour augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe Benkadi ont intégré le programme crédit  de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel, elles sont à leur 4er  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). 
Madame Assétou K. veut utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des habits. Elle s’approvisionne à Bobo Dioulaso au (Burkina Faso).  Elle revend ses habits, en ambulant et à la maison, au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes, et de femmes.  
Assétou espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, faire face aux dépenses familiales, participer aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles) et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Son ambition est  de diversifier  les produits à vendre.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group are three married ladies and a widow, who live in large polygamous families in the Koulikoro district of the town of Koutiala. They average 34 years of age and have an average of four children each. They met through good neighbors and have clothes, drinks and restauration businesses. In order to expand their businesses, the members of the Benkadi group have joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and are taking out their fourth group loan from the institution. Mrs. Assétou K. would like to use her loan to buy clothes. She gets her supplies in Bobo Dioulaso in Burkina Faso. She resells her clothes on a door to door basis and from home, for cash, on a retail basis, and on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. Assétou hopes to make a monthly profit of 120,000FCFA which will be used to repay her loan, cover family expenses, participate in social events (marriages, baptisms and funerals) and to expand her business. Her ambition is to diversify the products she sells.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is a 41-year-old tailor. She is married and has two children. She has been tailoring for 18 years. She saves her money with a group of entrepreneurs in Faulu Kenya, hence the members can easily guarantee her a loan. She has requested a loan of KES 20,000 to buy fabric for making clothes. She hopes to expand her business so that she can get more income. She dreams of adding stock so that she can employ people in her business.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Danaya (Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Danaya est un regroupement de 5 femmes (4 mariées et 1 veuve) de Koutiala ville qui se connaissent bien car elles  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles élargies  avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans et 3 enfants. 
Ce groupe de femme fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, le  bois de chauffe, les habillements,  les condiments, les poissons fumé et séché, les légumes etc. 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 5 ans. Elles sont à leur douzième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Rabiata Dembélé est un membre du groupe  qui vend du bois de chauffe.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des chargements de camion en  bois de chauffe auprès des producteurs. Elle se procure  du bois dans les différents coins de brousse. Son stock de bois, qui est très important, est entreposé dans un endroit devant la porte. Elle vend le bois en gros, en détail et au comptant à la maison  à une clientèle composé de femmes et d’hommes. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe Danaya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 110 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Rabiata Dembélé compte réaliser 160 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcée ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Danaya is a grouping of five women (four married and one a widow) from Koutiala Town, who know each other well because they live in extended large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They average 42 years of age and have an average of three children each. This group of women sell a variety of articles such as firewood, clothes, condiments, smoked and dried fish, vegetables etc. In order to increase the level of their activities, the members decided five years ago to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. They are now on their twelfth group loan and all the previous loans were repaid on time. Rabiata Dembélé is a member of the group and she sells firewood. She is planning to use this loan to buy lorry loads of firewood from producers. She gets her wood in different corners of the bush. Her stock of wood, which is very significant, is stored in a place in front of the door. She sells the wood on a wholesale and retail basis, and for cash, from home to a customer base made up of women and men. While the members of the Danaya group expect to make a monthly profit of 110,000FCFA each during the course of the cycle, Rabiata Dembélé expects to make 160,000FCFA. As well as paying off their loans, they use a part of their income to cover everyday family expenses. They would like to reinforce their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso so that supplies do not get too short..

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter loves business and that is why he sells office stationeries like calculator at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to grow his business in the future. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He is 34 years old, married with a child. His wife is a fashion designer and she also supports their home. Peter’s child attends school. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more office stationeries to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more office stationeries to sell

loans.name: Julietha

texts.en: Julietha M. is a small business owner and a married woman. She runs a business as a food vendor, preparing and selling fried and cooked food to customers at Buguruni Mnyamani in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her supplies from the food market shops at Buguruni and Kariakoo business shopping center. The income from this business enabled her to open another business buying and selling traditional clothes (Vitenge and Khanga) to customers. Also, her family's daily needs depend on the business income. She is requesting a loan of TZS 800,000 to buy more supplies.

loans.use: To buy more supplies

loans.name: Bénédiction Group

texts.fr:
Mapendo Nazirambula  est présidente du groupe de crédit Bénédiction, elle lève la main sur la photo devant la porte, cliente au 4e  cycle de crédit, âgée de 33 ans, mariée. Elle est mère de  7 enfants  parmi lesquels   5  vont à l’école et 2 autres sont encore gosses. Son mari est chômeur (sans emploi). 
Mapendo Nazirambula vend des braises. Elle a commencé son business avec son fond propre reçu de son mari, quand celui-ci travaillait dans une quincaillerie d’un particulier. Son capital initial était de 50$. Elle vend les braises  dans un marché public du secteur Alanine se trouvant dans la commune urbaine de Goma à 8 km du centre ville. Il ya 5 ans que Mapendo Nazirambula exerce cette activité de vente de braises. Elle s’approvisionne dans le village de Kichanga, territoire de Masisi, fief du général Nkunda,ex leader du mouvement rebelle CNDP,à l’Est de la RDCongo.
Avec  le crédit de l’IMF Hekima, Mapendo Nazirambula souhaite accroitre son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 15 sacs de braises.  Le grand defi de Mapendo Nazirambula, elle  n’est pas encore à mesure de débarquer elle seule un camion pour ses marchandises, sur ce, elle est  obligée de s’associer avec une autre personne (commerçante) pour se partager les couts transactionnels et charge de  location de véhicule transporteur.  
Dans l’avenir, elle ambitionne accroitre son business et atteindre un capital de 1500$ enfin de réaliser ses rêves notamment ouvrir un grand dépôt de braises, ouvrir une quincaillerie. En outre, le souci de Mapendo Nazirambula est de voir son mari trouver du travail.  
Mapendo Nazirambula remercie  l’IMF Hekima, pour les crédits réguliers qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle, car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux multiples besoins de sa famille, surtout durant cette période où son mari n’a pas du travail.
Le groupe Bénédiction  est composé de 13 membres, toutes femmes.
texts.en:
Mapendo Nazirambula is president of the Bénédiction loan group, and it is her raising her hand in front of the door on the photo. A customer on her fourth loan, she is 33 years old and married. She is mother to seven children, of whom five go to school, the other two being still small children. Her husband is unemployed. Mapendo sells charcoal. She began this business with her own capital, given to her by her husband when he was working in a private individual's hardware store. Her initial capital was $50. She sells the charcoal at a public market in the Alanine area of the urban municipality of Goma, eight kilometers from the centre of town. Mapendo has been carrying out this charcoal business for five years. She gets her supplies in the village of Kichanga, in the Masisi territory, which is the domain of General Nkunda, the ex-leader of the rebel movement CNDP, in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo. The problem for Mapendo is that she does not yet have the means to fill a full lorry by herself, so she is obliged to get together with another businesswoman in order to share the transactional costs and the expense of renting a vehicle to transport the goods. For the future her ambition is to grow her business, reach a capital of $1,500, and finally realise her dreams, notably of opening a large warehouse for charcoal and a hardware store. Furthermore, the main concern for Mapendo is for her husband to find work. Mapendo is grateful to IMF Hekima for the regular loans she receives without having to provide any material guarantee. Thanks to these loans she is able to provide for the multiple needs of her family, above all during this period when her husband is out of work. The Bénédiction group is made up of 13 members, all of whom are women.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 15 bags of charcoal

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Massar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Massar S., jeune marié âgé de 34 ans,  gère sa propre boutique au niveau de la gare routière de Thiès depuis 3 ans. Il vend des téléphones portables et accessoires téléphones.  C’est avec ce business que  Monsieur S. aide sa famille (femme, parents, frère et soueurs) surtout pour les charges quotidiennes de la maison familiale où il vit avec sa femme. Cependant pour augmenter les revenus familiaux, Monsieur S. décida de financer son jeune frère pour une activité d’alimentation générale. En fait il lui a ouvert une boutique au niveau de leur quartier Cité Lamy de Thiès.
 Ainsi, il sollicite un prêt de 400 000 FCFA pour le renforcement  de cette activité afin d'appuyer son jeune frère qui par défaut de compte au niveau de U-IMCEC ne peut pas bénéficier d’un prêt.
texts.en:
M. Massar S., a married man of 34, has had his own store at the truck and bus depot in Thiès for three years. He sells cell phones and accessories. Through his business M. S. helps his family (wife, parents, brother and sisters), mostly by paying the day-to-day expenses of the house where he lives wife. However, to increase household earnings, he has decided to finance his younger brother to open a food business in a store in their Cité Lamy neighborhood in Thiès. He is thus asking for a loan of 400,000 FCr to build up this business to support his younger brother who cannot get a loan from U-IMCEC because he has no account with the organization.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To finance his younger brother

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a mother of 5 and she is a widow. She is 39 years of age and she lives in Lagos. She operates a beauty salon and also sells hair extension, cosmetics and clothes in her shop for more income. She has been in the business for the past 9 years and she has more customers that patronize her due to relationship with them. With the profit from this business could provide for her fatherless children's education and well being.

Ruth would like her business to grow in future by buying more hair extension directly from the manufacturers at a more reduce price, this she said will increase her productivity and profitability. She hopes for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more hair extension and cosmetics to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for this privilege.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extension and cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a 34-year-old married woman with two children. She owns a stationery shop, which she opened three years ago. She is a member of Vision Mlolongo group in Faulu Kenya whose members guarantee each other's loans. She wants to take out her first loan of KES 20,000 from Faulu Kenya and hopes that the loan will make a difference in her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more books and copy paper. She hopes to be the main supplier of stationery in her area. In 10 years, she wants to register her business as a company so that she can supply stationery to other institutions.

loans.use: To buy books and copy paper

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Claude

texts.en:
Claude is 25 years old and he is still single.   Claude owns a small business selling traditional drinks made of sorghum. This drink is called IGIPENDE in the local language. His business is well-known in the region and organized as well. Claude employs 3 people in his business so that it runs smoothly. This is his 3rd year of success in his business. The hours of his daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day.

Claude is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing his business through purchasing more sorghum to make the IGIPENDE. This loan will be important to Claude simply because will help him to satisfy his demand. With extra profits Claude expects to build his own house, which he has to do before he can get married.

loans.use: sorghum to make IGIPENDE for sale

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a married man who has five children. He started operating his retail shop eight months ago and has two employees. He also does farming to earn extra income. He is a member of Galaxy group in Faulu Kenya, where he saves KES 100 on a weekly basis. He uses his savings to boost his business. He has requested a loan of KES 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy maize flour and sugar. For him to take this loan, he has been guaranteed by the group members. He hopes to open up a supermarket in the future. He dreams of opening other business outlets.

loans.use: To buy sugar and maize flour

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alou Sangaré est un homme marié de 34 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier N’tentou de Ouelessebougou.
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités économiques notamment la vente de céréales qu’il a appris auprès de son oncle. Avec une expérience de 7 ans, il maîtrise son activité.
 Dans le cadre du renforcement de ses activités, il décide de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des sacs de céréales auprès des producteurs à Ouelessebougou et dans ses villages environnants. Sa clientèle est composée de consommateurs et de revendeurs.Il vend en détail au comptant et souvent à crédit
 Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 32.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  acheter une maison.
texts.en:
Mr. Alou Sangaré is married, 34 years old, and the father of three children. He lives with his wife and children in the the neighborhood of N’tentou in Ouelessebougou. Not having attended much formal schooling, very early on he began business ventures, notably the sale of grains, which he learned from his uncle. With seven years of experience, he has mastered his trade. In order to strengthen his business, he has decided to rejoin Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he had his first individual loan. He intends to use his loan to buy bags of grain from producers in Ouelessebougou and the surrounding villages. His clientele is made up of consumers and resellers. He sells smaller quantities to individuals for cash or often credit. With this loan, he hopes to earn a monthly profit of 32,500 FCFA which he will use to buy a house.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various commodities for resale

loans.name: Bamiro

texts.en: Bamiro S. A. loves business and that is why he sells hair extensions at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to grow his business in the future. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He sells 37 years old, married with 3 children. His wife sells groceries and she also supports their home. His children attend school. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Tom

texts.en: Tom is 40 years old and married with four children. He is a tailor and uses his income to educate his children and provide other basic needs. His business is located in Kenyatta open air market. He has been in this business for the last 20 years. He also does farming to earn extra income. He is a member of Faulu Kenya under a group of young entrepreneurs whose aim is to guarantee each other's loans. He has requested a loan of KES 20,000 to buy fabric. He hopes to expand his business and employ more people in the future.

loans.use: To buy fabric

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bakary

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bakary Diakité est un homme marié de 44 ans et père de 5 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants à Dangassa, un village de la commune rurale de Ouelessebougou.
Il a vite abandonné l’école coranique pour s’intéresser aux  activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et à la vente de céréales auprès de son père.  Avec plus de 10 ans d’expériences, Monsieur Bakary Diakité maîtrise son activité.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il décide de collaborer avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, des sacs de céréales auprès des producteurs  à Dangassa et  environs. Il effectue sa vente  à Bamako,  Dangassa et à Sanankoroba à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Bakary Diakité is married, 44 years old, and the father of five children. He lives with his wife and children in Dangassa, a village in the rural area of Ouelessebougou. He quickly left Koranic school to pursue his interest in business, specifically the buying and selling of grain, which he did alongside his father. With more than ten years of experience, Mr. Bakary Diakité has mastered his trade. In his research of supplemental financial resources, he has decided to collaborate with the loan program at the microfinance institution of Soro Yiriwaso. This is his first individual loan and intends to use it to buy bags of grain from producers in Dangassa and its surrounding areas. He does his selling in Bamako, Dangassa and Sanankoroba to a clientele made up of men and women. With this loan, he intends to earn a monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA. With this profit he plans to expand his business.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grain

loans.name: Kezia

texts.en:
Kezia is 32 years old, married with five children, aged between 5 month and 12 years old. Kezia owns a small shop, which sells tomatoes, water, cooking oil, rice, and so on.  Kezia’s husband is a farmer and they both work hard for their family. This is her 10th year of success in her business. The hours of her shop are from 8 AM to 6 PM every day except Sunday. 

Kezia is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through adding other products such as  clothes and cosmetic products which can help her to attract more customers for her shop. This will be one way to obtain more profits, which will allow her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: adding other products such as  clothes and cosmetic products

loans.name: Brahima

texts.fr:
Monsieur Brahima Samaké est un homme de 35 et père de 5 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le village de Morodiambougou, situé à quelques  kilomètres de  la ville de Ouelessebougou.
Ayant vite abandonné l’école, il commença les activités génératrices de revenus dès son jeune âge auprès de son père.
Après plusieurs activités telles la vente de bœufs et cela sans réussite, il décida de mener l’activité d’achat et de vente de céréales. Avec une expérience de 2 ans, il maîtrise son activité. Il mène cette activité au marché de Ouelessebougou les jours de foires.
Afin d’agrandir son entreprise, il décide de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter des sacs de céréales.
Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants  Ouelessebougou. Il est à son premier prêt individuel. 
La vente de ses produits se fait au marché de Ouelessebougou et dans les villages environnants.
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de  50 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses de la famille  et agrandir davantage son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Brahima Samaké is a 35-year-old man and a father of five children who lives with his wife and children in the village of Morodiambougou, located a few kilometers from the city of Ouelessebougou.  Having dropped out of school early, he started income-generating businesses at a young age along side his father.  After several businesses, such as selling steers although unsuccessfully, he decided to run a business buying and selling grains.  With two years of experience, he has a command of his business, and he operates it at the market of Ouelessebougou on market days.  In order to expand his enterprise, Brahima decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to buy sacks of grain.  He is on his first individual loan.  He stocks up in villages surrounding Ouelessebougou.  Sales of his goods are made at the Ouelessebougou market and in surrounding villages.  With this loan, he plans on making a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA that will be used to provide for his family and to expand his enterprise further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying grain

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent was born in 1981 and is married with two children, the first-born is 8 years old and the younger is 3 years old.  Vincent’s wife is a teacher and they both work hard for the development of their family. Vincent sells chicken in his region; this is his 3rd year successful year of operation in this business. The hours of his business are from 6 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day except Sunday.

Vincent is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more chicken which will allow him to be efficient and effective and more successful. With this loan Vincent hopes to satisfy the demand of his clientele and hopefully earn more profit in the process which will help him to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: The purchase of a large number of chickens for sale

loans.name: James

texts.en:
Agriculture has, from time immemorial, been the backbone of Uganda’s economy. Different genres of agricultural activities have allowed many Ugandan families to have an improved lease of life. An example is this story of K. James from Ibanda district.

This married gentleman has subsisted on his banana plantation for the last ten years. Though adverse weather conditions have constantly affected his gardens, James has managed to consolidate the gains he has made. As a result, his family of five children has enjoyed the benefits: principally, his children all now attend good institutions of learning.

James gleefully reveals that he makes, in a month, close to or even more than 200,000 Ugandan shillings from selling bananas. He is very upbeat that, with this loan, he will be in position to improve the mulching and gardening aspects of his business.

loans.use: To purchase stakes and other farm tools including fertilizer.

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Monsieur Daouda Traoré est un homme marié de 44 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants  à Keleya, un village, chef lieu d’une commune rurale, située à 25 kilomètres de Ouelessebougou.
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus.
De la vente de bétails pendant des années, il mène il ya maintenant  5 ans  le  métier  de boucher qui lui réussi mieux. Il a appris cette activité auprès d’un de ses amis.
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers un autre client Soro Yiriwaso, il décide de collaborer avec l’institution.
Il est à  son premier prêt individuel qu’il compte  utiliser pour acheter, des animaux sur pieds pour les abattre.                                                                                                        Il s’approvisionne à Keleya et dans les villages environnants auprès des éleveurs. Il effectue sa vente au marché Keleya aux abords la route internationale Bamako Abidjan. Il a une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Monsieur Daouda Traoré compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice il ambitionne construire une maison à Ouelessebougou  pour son avenir et ceux de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. Daouda Traoré is a 44-year-old married man who is the father of three living with his wife and children in Keleya, a village that is the seat of a rural community located 25 km from Ouelessebougou.  Not having had modern schooling, he started income-generating businesses at a young age.  From selling cattle for years, he has been a butcher by trade for five years now.  This has been more successful for him.  He learned this business from one of his friends.  Having become familiar with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso through another Soro Yiriwaso client, Daouda decided to collaborate with the institution. He is now on his first individual loan, which he intends to use for buying some livestock for slaughter. He supplies himself in and around the village of Keleya from livestock farmers. He makes his sales at the Keleya market on the side of the international road leading from Bamako to Abidjan. He has a varied and diverse customer base. Douda plans on making a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA. With this profit, he has the ambition of building a house in Ouelessebougou for his future and his children's future.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying steers

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam Traoré est une femme mariée de 35 ans et mère de 6 enfants. Elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants dans le village de N’tentou  à Ouelessebougou. 
Suite à la pauvreté de ses parents, elle décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente d’animaux. Elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une parente. Avant cela, elle avait tenté pendant des années différentes activités sans succès. Avec une expérience de 6 ans elle maîtrise son activité d’achat et de vente d’animaux qui lui réussie bien.
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle, elle décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après des prêts solidaires avec une association de son quartier, qui ont été tous correctement remboursés, elle est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter, des animaux sur pieds. Elle s’approvisionne à Ouelessebougou et dans les villages environnants. La vente de ses animaux se fait au marché de Ouelessebougou et N’tentou à domicile, à une clientèle constituée essentiellement de bouchers.
Elle  espère réaliser ainsi un bénéfice mensuel de 55 000FCFA.
Avec se bénéfice elle compte payer les intérêts du prêt et  agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam Traoré is a 35-year-old woman and the mother of six children.  She lives with her husband and their children in the village of N’tentou in Ouelessebougou.  As a result of her parents' poverty, she decided to work and earn an income, notably in the buying and selling of animals.  She learned this business from her mother.  In the past, she had tried unsuccessfully for years doing various kinds of work.  With six years of experience, she has a command of her business trading in animals, and it is really successful.  In order to satisfy her customers, she decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  After a few solidarity loans with an association in her district that were all correctly repaid, she is now on her first individual loan.  With this loan, she intends to buy livestock.  She gets her stock in and around the village of Ouelessebougou.  Sales of these animals are made at the Ouelessebougou market and out of her home in N’tentou.  Her customer base is essentially composed of butchers.  Thus, she hopes to make a monthly profit of 55,000 francs CFA.  With these profits, she plans to cover the loan interest and to expand her enterprise. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying animals

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en:
Evariste is 38 years old, married with 5 children.  Evariste is a hard-working businessman who is well-known in the business of selling foodstuffs, mainly beans.  He has been in this business for about 9 years and the hours of his business are from 6 am to 8 pm every day.

Evariste has an idea of expanding his business through adding other types of goods such as rice, sugar, and sorghum. He needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase those goods, which will increase his sales as well as his profits.  With these profits, Evariste will keep reinvesting for a better future for his business as well as for his family.

loans.use: The purchase of some other types of goods such as rice, sugar, sorghum, etc.

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Moussa Samaké est un homme marié de 24 et père de 2 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le village de Morodiambougou   à  Ouelessebougou.
Il a fréquenté l’école coranique pendant des années mais l’abandonna tôt pour des raisons économiques.
Il a tenté plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus telles la vente de tissus, de chaussures mais sans succès. Il décida alors d’accompagner son père dans la vente de céréales. Avec une expérience de 2 ans, il maîtrise  cette activité qui lui réussi et qu’il mène dans le marché de Ouelessebougou et dans son village. 
Afin d’agrandir son entreprise, il décide de collaborer  avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel, et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, des sacs de différentes  variétés de céréales (haricot, petit mil, arachide, maïs etc). 
Il s’approvisionne à Ouelessebougou et dans les villages  environnants et effectue sa vente dans le marché de Ouelessebougou et une partie est vendue dans les différents villages les jours de foire.
Il  espère  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 45 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement  pour  agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
24-year-old Moussa Samaké is married with 2 children. He lives with his family in the village of Morodiambougou in Ouelessebougou.
He attended Koranic school for several years but had to quit early for economic reasons.
He tried out various revenue generating activities like selling cloth and shoes, but with little success. He then decided to join his father in selling grain. With 2 years experience, he now runs a successful business at the market in Ouelessebougou and in his village.
In order to expand his business, he decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso. This is his first individual loan, which he plans to use to buy bags of various grains (beans, millet, peanuts, corn, etc.).
He buys his stock in Ouelessebougou and in the surrounding villages. He makes his sales at the market in Ouelessebougou and in different villages on market fair days.
He hopes to make a monthly profit of 45,000 XOF, which he will use to expand his business.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 25 years old, married with two children, the first-born is 5 years old and the younger is 3 years old. Judith owns a small shop selling clothing. Judith’s business is well-known in her region. This is her 7th year of successful operation in her business. The hours of her shop are from 8 AM to 4 PM every day except Saturday. 

Judith is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase bales of clothing which will allow her to satisfy more customers. Judith needs this loan because her monthly profit was too low to sort out her business problems. With this loan Judith hopes to increase her profits and save money for the future.

loans.use: Different styles of clothing for sale

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou B. est un homme marié de 41 ans et père de 6 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants à Banankoro, un village situé 8 kilomètres de Ouelessebougou.
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités économiques notamment l’achat et la vente de céréales qu’il a appris auprès de son oncle.  Avec une expérience de 4 ans, il maîtrise bien son activité.
 Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse,  il décide de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso, pour acheter des tonnes de céréales. Il est à son premier prêt individuel.
 Il s’approvisionne à Banankoro, à Ouelessebougou et dans les villages environnants. La vente se fait à Banankoro et à Ouelessebougou les jours de foires, à une clientèle diverse et variée.
 Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65 500FCFA qui,sera utilisé pour  acheter un lot à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou B. is a 41-year-old married man and the father of six children. He lives with his wife and children in Banankoro, a village located 8 km from Ouelessebougou.  Not having attended school, he soon started in commercial work, especially buying and selling of grains, that he learned from his uncle.  With four years of experience, he has mastered his business. Concerned about satisfying his more and more numerous customers, he decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to buy tonnes of grain.  He is now on his first individual loan.  He stocks up in Banankoro, in Ouelessebougou, and in the surrounding villages.  Sales are made in Banankoro and in Ouelessebougou on market days to a diverse and varied customer base.  With this loan, he plans on making a monthly profit of 65,000 francs CFA that will be used for buying a residential lot.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying grains

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en: Idowu loves shoes and that is why he sells shoes at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to own a shoe company and also to grow his business in the future. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He is 47 years old, married with 4 children. His wife is a civil servant and she also supports their home. His children attend school. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more shoes to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou D. est un homme marié de 43 ans et père de 6 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le  quartier Bamanankin de Ouelessebougou.
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités économiques notamment les travaux journaliers auprès des maçons, quelques années à l’aventure et il revient au pays faire le commerce d’articles divers avec la vente de pièces détachées apprise  auprès de son oncle.
Avec une expérience de 4 ans, Monsieur Seydou D. maîtrise  bien son activité dans laquelle il est très sollicité.
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle il décide d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce  prêt il  compte acheter, des pièces détachées  pour sa boutique sise au grand marché de Ouelessebougou.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali).Sa clientèle est composée de plusieurs catégories sociales.
 Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Seydou D. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000 FCFA  qui servira à  agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou D. is a 43-year-old married man and the father of six children.  He lives with his wife and children in the Bamanankin district of Ouelessebougou.  Not having attended school, he soon got started in commercial work, especially daywork with masons, abroad for a few years.  He returned to his home country to work with his uncle doing commerce in a variety of spare parts.  With four years of experience, Seydou has mastered his business and is in high demand.  In order to satisfy his customers, he decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan.  With this loan, he intends to buy some spare parts for his shop located in the big market of Ouelessebougou.  He stocks up in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali).  His customer base is composed of several slices of society. With this loan, Seydou plans on making a monthly profit of 65,000 francs CFA that will be used to expand his shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying spare parts

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en: Leticia buys condemned plastic and sells to a recycling company. She does this to earn her living in Lagos. She has been in the business for the past 4 years. She is happily married and she is 38 years of age. Her husband is a transporter and they lives together. She needs the loan of NGN150, 000 to purchase more condemned plastic to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more condemned plastic to sell.

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Siaka Samaké est un homme marié de 41 ans et père de 5 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le village de  N'tentoukoro, un village situé à 15 kilomètres de Ouelessebougou (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Très tôt Siaka abandonna les études pour les activités génératrices de revenus auprès d’un de ses ami. Il opta pour le créneau de l’alimentaire avec l’achat et la vente de céréales de différentes sortes.
Avec une expérience de 3 ans, Monsieur Siaka Samaké maîtrise bien son activité.
Afin d’obtenir un fonds de roulement considérable, il décida de rejoindre  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son troisième prêt individuel, pour acheter différentes variétés de céréales.
 Il s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants  Ouelessebougou et effectue sa vente à Bamako (capitale du Mali),  à Ouelessebougou et à N'tentoukoro à domicile à une clientèle diverse et variée.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Siaka Samaké is a 41-year-old married man and the father of five children.  He lives with his wife and children in the village of N'tentoukoro, located 15 km from Ouelessebougou (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Early on, he dropped out of school in favor of income-generating work with one of his friends.  He opted for a niche in foodstuffs, the buying and selling of grains of various kinds.  With three years of experience, he a good command of his business.  In order to obtain considerable working capital, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his third individual loan for buying differently varieties of grain.   He gets his supplies from the villages surrounding Ouelessebougou.  And he sells in Bamako (capital of Mali), in Ouelessebougou, and in N'tentoukoro out of his home.  His customer base is diverse and varied.  With this loan, he plans on making a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to expand his enterprise. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Zeleba

texts.fr:
Madame Zeleba D. est une femme mariée de 39 ans et mère de 6 enfants qui vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Morodiambougou, un village situé à 6 kilomètres de Ouelessebougou.
Madame Zeleba D. n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école moderne, très vite elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente de fruits et légumes.  Elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une amie. Avec 10 ans d’expérience, elle maîtrise son activité.
Afin d’améliorer son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Après 1 prêt  solidaire bien remboursé, elle décide d’aller en prêt  individuel.
Il compte acheter avec ce prêt individuel, des chargements de charrettes en fruits et légumes suivant les périodes.
Elle s’approvisionne à Morodiambougou et dans les villages environnants. Ses légumes sont vendus à Bamako et à Ouelessebougou, au comptant et souvent à crédit aux revendeurs. 
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA qui  lui permettra  d’améliorer davantage son entreprise et à payer les intérêts du prêt.
texts.en:
Ms. Zeleba D. is a 39-year-old married woman and the mother of six children.  She lives with her husband and their children in Morodiambougou, a village located 16 km from Ouelessebougou.  She did not have the opportunity to attend modern schools.  Zeleba soon got started in income-generating work, notably in buying and selling fruit and vegetables.  She learned this business from a friend of hers.  With ten years of experience, she has a command of her business.  In order to improve her business and to satisfy her customers, who are more and more numerous, Zeleba decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  After one solildairy loan, which was repaid, she decided to take out an individual loan.  She intends to use this loan to buy cart loads of fruit and vegetables in season.  She gets her supplies in Morodiambougou and from surrounding villages.  Her vegetables are sold in Bamako and in Ouelessebougou.  She accepts cash and often credit from retailers.  With this loan, Zeleba plans on making a monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will enable her to improve her enterprise further and to cover the loan interest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying vegetables

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing loves business and that is why he sells eye glasses at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to grow his business in the future. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He is 35 years old, married with 2 children. His wife works and she also supports their home. His children attend school. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more eye glasses to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more eye glasses to sell

loans.name: Alou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alou Diakité est un homme marié de 25 ans et père de 1 enfant qui vit avec sa femme et son enfant dans une famille élargie à Ouelessebougou (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Il a abandonné l’école pour des raisons sociales et très tôt  s’intéressa  aux  activités génératrices de revenus notamment  à l’achat et à la vente d’appareils électroniques.
 Avec plus  de 5 ans d’expériences, Monsieur Alou Diakité maîtrise son activité dans laquelle il est très sollicité et apprécié.
Dans le souci d’étoffer son fonds de roulement, il décide de rejoindre  Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Il  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des appareils électroniques  à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) et effectue sa vente à Ouelessebougou  à une clientèle composée de toutes les catégories sociales.
 Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Alou Diakité is a 25-year-old married man, the father of one child. He lives with his wife and child in an extended family in Ouelessebougou (second administrative region in the Republic of Mali). He left school for social reasons and very early on became interested in income-generating activities, notably buying and selling electronic equipment. With more than five years of experience, Mr. Alou Diakité is proficient in his business and is very much in demand and appreciated. In order to increase his working capital, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his first individual loan. He plans to use his loan to buy electronic equipment in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). He sells in Ouelessebougou to customers from all social categories. With this loan, he plans to make a monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA. He would like to expand his business with these profits.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purcahse of electronic equipment

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
If you subsist on agriculture, like N. Immaculate has found out, you need enormous reserves of patience to succeed. That particular attribute has manifestly worked in Immaculate’s favor. She speaks with pride of how her four children can all attain an education in institutions of learning.

Immaculate’s proficiency in attending to her banana plantation for the last sixteen years in Ruyonza, Ibanda District, has borne her fruits of economic development. In a month, she makes profits to the tune of 300,000 Ugandan shillings. The only major drawn out problem that has plagued her business has been the persistent low banana market prices in villages and the fact that she has no ready means of transporting her produce to bigger markets.

It’s Immaculate’s reckoning that this loan will come in handy in helping her enhance her banana plantations on a large scale through mulching and buying fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase mulches and fertilizer and to research available markets for her produce

loans.name: Chalet

texts.en:
Chalet is a 46-year-old widow, living with her youngest son.  Her eldest daughter is married. 

Chalet's business involves making handicrafts, and she has a lot of experience with this type of business. Ten years ago,  she started this  business.  Currently, she makes cane chairs and tables. There is strong competition in her area for selling handicrafts, because Hikkaduwa is a popular tourist destination. There is a strong demand from foreign tourists for 'Sri Lankan handicrafts.' Even Sri Lankan hotel owners are providing high demand  for her products.  Chalet is also doing another business making rugs. She has experience and practice in this type of business.

Chalet's  youngest son  helps her by  selling her goods to customers, which greatly helps the business.

Chalet has requested a 40,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka which she will use to buy cane and timber to make into products. 

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy cane and timber for handicrafts

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet owns a restaurant where she sells cooked food and drinks to customers. She has been managing the business for more than 1 year. Her husband sells phones and its accessories and they reside in Lagos. She is 30 years of age and she has 2 children. 
She is determine and want her business to grow from this level now to a better level that will improve their living standard. She hopes for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more drinks and food stuffs to cook and sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and food stuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Composé de quatre femmes, les membres du groupe Danaya sont toutes des femmes mariées qui vivent en majorité dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, co-épouses, frères, sœurs et enfants. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 25 ans et 4 enfants. Ces femmes résident dans le village de Kangaré, région de Sikasso république du Mali. 
Par des relations  professionnelle et de mariage ces femmes se sont connues et font le commerce de céréales (telle le riz), de condiments alimentaires, de cosmétiques, de chaussures, de pagnes wax, brodés etc. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire et mieux satisfaire la clientèle, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe. Les précédents n’ont pas l’objet de mauvais remboursement. 
Madame Salimata D., qui est la présidente du groupe et qui est dans l’alimentaire veut acheter avec son prêt,  200kg de graine de dah, 150kg de graine de Néré, 100kg de graine d’arachide et 200kg de maïs. Tous ces produits sont achetés auprès des fournisseurs dans le village de Kangaré pour être revendus ensuite dans le grand marché hebdomadaire de Dalabala et journalier de Sélingué, en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle compte obtenir un bénéfice de 30.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé selon elle dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The Danaya group is composed of four women, all of them married, who live mainly in traditional extended polygamous families, with their husbands, other wives, brothers, sisters, and children. On the average, they are 25 years old and have for children. They live in the village of Kangaré, in the Sikasso region of Mali. They know each other through family and business ties. They sell cereals (such as rice), food condiments, cosmetics, wax and embroidered "pagnes" [traditional fabrics for wrap clothing] etc. With the goal of increasing their income and better meeting customer demand in mind, they have joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are now on their fifth group loan. All previous loans were repaid without any issues. Mrs. Salimata D., who is the group leader and who is in the food business, would like to purchase with this loan 200kg [440 lbs] of "dah" [the local variety of hibiscus] grain, 150 kg [330 lbs] of the "néré" seeds [a West African plant whose seeds are used in a condiment], 100 kg [220 lbs] of peanuts and 200kg [440 lbs] of corn. All these products are purchased from the producers in the village of Kangaré and then resold at the big weekly market in Dalabala and the daily market in Sélingué, at the retail level, for cash, to a customer base composed essentially of women. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 30,000 West African Francs, which, according to her, will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cereals [for resale]

loans.name: Afde N°47 Group

texts.fr:
L’Association des Femmes pour le Développement de l’Entreprise (AFDE) est une organisation de femmes commerçantes de petite échelle travaillant dans Thiès, une ville située à 70 Kms de Dakar. L'association a été fondée en 1993 par vingt femmes entrepreneurs pour augmenter leur pouvoir d'achat par le biais d’une tontine (système de financement tournant dans lequel chaque membre cotise périodiquement une somme convenue et qu’on verse à tour de rôle aux différents membres). 
Cette politique ne permettant pas de financer au même jour tous les membres, elles décidèrent d’adhérer à l’IMCEC afin de s’octroyer du crédit sans des demandes de garanties. C’est ainsi que les membres sont divisés en sous groupe de 5, avec une présidente désignée et une trésorière pour chaque sous groupe. Ces sous-groupes, au nombre de 52 en ce moment, peuvent être le même pendant de nombreuses années, mais changent souvent de membres selon le financement des besoins et d'autres considérations.
L'AFDE organise des réunions de membre mensuellement où tous les sous groupes sont conviés et dirige une coopération pour ses membres, en leur permettant d'acheter du riz et d'autres produits à de meilleurs prix.
L'AFDE est dirigée par une Présidente du nom de Madame Mame Diarra MAR et une trésorière Madame Ndeye Ndella Diouf toutes habitantes de Thiès. 
L’AFDE N° 47 est gérée par Madame Ndèye Aïssatou F., une femme mariée âgée de 40 ans. Cette femme mère de 4 enfants fait du commerce depuis 3 ans. Elle vend des tissus, produits cosmétiques à travers la ville de Thiès. Elle a été influencée par son mari qui est un commerçant très connu de Thiès. Avec sa part du crédit, elle compte s’approvisionner en tissus du genre Khartoum pour préparer l’été. Elle partage avec ce sous avec :
-Madame Maréme N. vendeuse de pain et de diner depuis deux ans.
-Madame Anta N. qui vend des tissus au marché de Thiès
-Madame Awa F. qui gère une table de légumes dans son quartier, elle vend toutes sortes de légumes et de poissons séchés depuis 15 ans.
-Madame Aminata Traoré, commerçante ambulante depuis 3 ans, elle vend des produits cosmétiques et greffages
texts.en:
Association des Femmes pour le Développement de l’Entreprise (AFDE) is an organization of women who are small-scale merchants working in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar.  AFDE was founded in 1993 by twenty women entrepreneurs to increase their purchasing power by way of a tontine (a revolving financing system in which each member makes periodic deposits as agreed and which lends to a different member by turns).  Since this policy does not allow financing to all the members on the same day, the members decided to join IMCEC in order to be granted loans without the need for collateral.  And so, the members are divided into sub-groups of five, with a designated president and a treasurer for each sub-group.  These sub-groups, now numbering 52, can remain the same for a number of years, but they often change their members according to the need for financing and other needs.  AFDE organizes member meetings each month where all the sub-groups are invited. It manages cooperation for its members by enabling them to buy rice and other goods at better prices.  AFDE is lead by a president by the name of Ms. Mame Diarra MAR and by a treasurer, Ms. Ndeye Ndella Diouf, both residents of Thiès. AFDE N° 47  is managed by Ms. Ndèye Aïssatou F., a 40-year-old married woman.  This mother of four children has been working in commerce for three years.  She sells cloth and cosmetics all across the city of Thiès.  She was influenced by her husband, who is a well-known merchant in Thiès.  With her share of the loan, she intends to stock up on Khartoum-type cloth to get ready for summer.  She shares in this sub-group with: - Ms. Maréme N., a seller of bread and dinner, for two years. - Ms. Anta N., who sells cloth at the Thiès market. - Ms. Awa F., who runs a vegetables table in her district.  She has been selling all sorts of vegetables and dried fish for fifteen years. - Ms. Aminata Traoré, a itinerant merchant for three years.  She sells cosmetics and hair weaves. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of merchandise

loans.name: Dancilla

texts.en:
Dancilla is 40 years old, married with 8 children, aged between 7 and 18. Dancilla’s husband owns a small business selling various products such as water, cooking oil, public phone service and so on. Dancilla is now a businesswoman, but before she was a farmer and she could not get all the basic needs for her family. Dancilla’s business is organized and important as well for her neighbors. The hours of her business are from 8 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except Sunday.

Dancilla is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business through purchasing attractive goods. Dancilla hopes that this will allow her to earn more profit. After earning those profits Dancilla will be able to provide for all the needs of her family.

loans.use: purchasing attractive goods to re-sell

loans.name: Yamuna

texts.en:
Yamuna is a 40-year-old woman who is married and living with her three children, one son and two daughters, in the town of Hikkaduwa in the Galle district of southern Sri Lanka.

Yamuna runs a condiment  business independently, while her husband is abroad. He is a retired army officer.  She started this venture eight years ago, and has since seen success. She works very hard and also attributes her success to being a very honest woman.

With this loan of 60,000 rupees (LKR), Yamuna hopes to buy a new grinder for her condiment  business to supply advanced service to her customers.
 
Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy a new grinder  for the condiment  business

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Composé de huit femmes, les membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont toutes des femmes mariées vivant en majorité dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, co-épouses, frères, sœurs et enfants. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  5 enfants. Ces femmes résident dans le village de Kangaré, région de Sikasso  république du Mali. 
Par des relations de voisinage et de mariage, ces femmes se sont connues et font le commerce d’articles divers tels, les céréales, les vêtements, les condiments alimentaires etc.
Afin d’augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire et mieux satisfaire la  clientèle, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe. Les précédents n’ont pas l’objet de mauvais remboursement. Madame Kany S. qui excelle dans l’habillement, veut avec  ce prêt acheter, 10 pièces de pagnes qu’elle va  d’abord coudre avant la vente. Sa production est revendue ensuite au marché de Sélingué, au comptant à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elles comptent obtenir un bénéfice de 40 000 FCFA par mois qui sera réutilisé  dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The Sabougnouma group is composed of eight married women, who live mainly in extended traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, brothers, sisters, and children. They average 35 years of age and 5 children. These women live in Kangaré, a village in the Sikasso Region, Republic of Mali, and got acquainted through links of neighborhood and marriage.
