Their businesses consist in selling various items such as cereals, clothing, food condiments, etc. In order to bolster their revenue and better meet customer demand, they joined Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are now seeking their second group loan. Previous loans were repaid without problems. Mrs. Kany S., who excels in selling clothing, wants to use this loan to buy 10 lengths of pagne (colorful African cloth) that she will sew and then sell. She sells her production at the Selingué market, for cash or on credit, to a clientele comprising mostly women. These women intend to turn a monthly profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 80), to be reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 lengths of pagne (colorful African cloth)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Assoumpta

texts.en:
Assoumpta was born in 1975 and is married with five children, aged between 6 and 15. She has a small shop, which sells various products such as cooking oil, soap, and so on. Her business is open from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Assoumpta is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business through purchasing additional products such as: rice, sugar and so forth. This loan will be very important for her and her community simply because Assoumpta will be able to help satisfy the community's needs and employ some of them

loans.use: The purchase of a large quantity of goods such as rice, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Lagwai B2 Alimo Janat Group

texts.en: A. Janat, 31 years old, is married with five children, three of them in school. She also has three dependents. She has been operating a grocery business for over a year. She is using the loan to purchase grocery items such as tomatoes, onions, silver fish, and so forth. The loan is improving her business and her dream is to prosper.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items such as tomatoes, onions, silver fish, and so forth

loans.name: Sensa

texts.en: Sensa M. is an entrepreneur and a married woman with four school children. She runs a business as a food vendor at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. She prepares and sells both cooked and fried food to customers, as well as soft drinks such as soda and juice. She purchases her goods from the food shops at Buguruni and from wholesale food crop product suppliers. She managed to employ one worker and meets the family's daily needs, including paying her children's school fees, with the business income. She is requesting a loan of TZS 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more supplies

loans.name: Lwala Ajok Margaret Group

texts.en: A. Margaret is a hardworking businesswoman of 40, widowed with seven children, three of whom are in school. She also has two dependents. She deals in stone quarrying and has been in this business for over five years. She is using the loan to purchase firewood for burning rocks and to pay wages. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase firewood for burning rocks and to pay wages

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en: Jamila M. is a small business owner and married woman. She runs a business as a food vendor (café) in the Ilala district of Dar es Salaam. She sells different kinds of cooked food, fried food and soft drinks. She purchases the food items from the food shops and food market at the Buguruni food market shopping center. She has been in the business for five years. She is requesting a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more business goods so as to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods to expand the business

loans.name: Lwala Aciro Tereja Group

texts.en: A. Tereja is a hardworking businesswoman of 32, married with six children, five of whom are in school. She also has two dependents. She deals in rock mining (stone quarrying), having run her business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase firewood for burning the rocks before hitting them, to pay wages and so forth. She is a courageous businesswoman whose dream is to prosper and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase firewood for burning rocks, to pay wages, etc.

loans.name: Mwanamvua

texts.en: Mwanamvua P. is a married businesswoman.  This entrepreneur runs a food shop in Buguruni ward, Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods from the food market, shopping center and wholesale food shops. She also purchases goods from the food crop product suppliers in wholesale. Her business income enabled her to open another business, selling jewelry, at Kariakoo. She is requesting a loan of 1,600,000 TZS to boost her businesses.

loans.use: To buy more business goods to expand her businesses

loans.name: John

texts.en: John loves business and that is why he sells male clothes at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to grow his business in the future. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He is 42 years old, widower with 4 children. His children attend school. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more male clothes to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more male clothes to sell

loans.name: Juba B Odong Karla Group

texts.en: O. Karla is a businesswoman of 41, married with six children, three of whom are in school. She also looks after one sibling. She has a retail shop selling items such as sugar, salt, soap, flour, and so forth, which she has been operating for over three years.  She is using the loan to purchase retail items and bags of sorghum in bulk. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dreams are to obtain livestock such as cows and goats to help her children in the future.

loans.use: To purchase retail items and bags of sorghum

loans.name: Daud

texts.en: Daud M. is a married businessman with two school-aged children. This entrepreneur runs a butcher shop in Vingunguti ward, Dar es Salaam. He purchases meat wholesale from meat suppliers and sells to customers in retail for domestic use. Meat demand in Dar es Salaam is very high therefore the meat business is good. Daud is requesting a loan of 800,000 TZS to expand his business by buying more business goods.

loans.use: To purchase more business goods

loans.name: Dammika

texts.en:
Dammika  is a 33-year-old married woman living in Hikkaduwa, Galle with four children (ages sixteen to five) and her husband. All her children are still studying. She works hard, together with her husband, to uplift their lives. Dammika's husband has a carpentry business for which they are seeking a loan to expand their venture. They build chairs, tables, cupboards, beds and other items.

She has asked for a loan of 55,000 rupees (LKR) from BRAC in order to purchase some wood. They have been in this business for ten years and they want to buy new machines for carpentry eventually. She hopes to open a new carpentry shop in the near future as well. This will be Dammika's third loan.  She paid her first and second loans off without any problems.  

Thank you for considering supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy  wood for carpentry

loans.name: Juba B Abalo Irene Group

texts.en: A. Irene is a hardworking businesswoman of 38, married and blessed with five children, three of whom are in school. She also has one dependent. She sells produce and has been in this business for over seven years. Due to a resettling program, Irene has inadequate capital for her business. She is using the loan to purchase produce to stock and sell. Her hope for the future is to progress from a poor to a better standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase produce to stock and sell

loans.name: Tosin

texts.en: Tosin has a hair dressing salon where she makes lovely hair styles for her customers.  She also sells hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. She is 31 years old, married with a child. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Laminyim East Auma Doreen Group

texts.en: A. Doreen is a fifty-year-old, hardworking business woman; she is married with three children, and she has three siblings in school too. She has a silverfish business, which she has been operating for over two years. She is using the loan to purchase silverfish, that is to say she will buy more than eight bags for sale. She is an encouraging businesswoman whose dream is to obtain land and livestock.

loans.use: To purchase silverfish; she will buy more than eight bags for sale.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa A. is thirty-six years old and married to Isaac Bundotich, who is a forty-two-year-old policeman. They live in Kapkokwon and have four children, who are between five and fourteen years old. 

Teresa is a charcoal dealer; she started this business two years ago. This business has been earning her a monthly profit of 8,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), along with 5,000 KES from other sources. She does her business in Kabarnet Town next to Kobil Petrol Station. Her customers are residents of Kabarnet Town.

Teresa has no previous credit history. She was introduced to KADET by an already existing customer. She has borrowed a loan of 10,000 KES, which she will use to purchase charcoal stock worth 10,000 KES. If this loan boosts her business, she will use the extra profit to invest in a retail shop.

Teresa hopes to open a wholesale depot for charcoal. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more chacoal stock for sale

loans.name: Mgeri

texts.en: Mgeri E. is a married man with a small business selling animals (goats and sheep) in Vingunguti ward, Dar es Salaam. He purchases animals from wholesale animal suppliers. Animals are transported from various Tanzanian regions to Dar es Salaam where the big market exists. Mgeri is requesting a loan of 700,000 TZS to buy more animals for his business.

loans.use: To buy more animals

loans.name: Risper

texts.en: Risper K. N. is 25 years old. Her husband is a teacher and they have one child who is eighteen months old to whom they hope to give a quality education. Risper's business is located in Kakamega town by the the roadside and it is well known by the name 'Ro-Safi Traders'. She sells clothes, cosmetics, shoes and even computer accessories to local people. She has been in this business for the last three years and she says that business is good although she does face a lot of competition. Risper hopes to expand her business and stock other items such as umbrellas and suitcases. She also hopes that her business will grow and provide employment to other people. She says that she is hardworking and never gives up on her goals.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Laminyim East Lalam Sylivia Group

texts.en: L. Sylivia is a forty-year-old businesswoman. She is married and has seven children, three of whom are going to school. She also has three dependents. She deals with produce (sorghum, simsim [sesame]), and she has been in her business for over twelve years. She is using the loan to purchase produce such as sorghum and simsim for sale. She is managing to pay fees and her dream is to obtain at least two bulls for cultivation and one cow just for milk.

loans.use: To purchase produce, such as sorghum and simsim (sesame), for sale.

loans.name: Lamin Nyim East Abalo Alice Group

texts.en: A. Alice is a thirty-five-year-old, hardworking business woman; she is married and blessed with seven children, of whom six are going to school, and she has one dependent. She has a produce business, which she has been operating for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase produce such as sorghum, peas, simsim, and so forth for sale. She is an encouraging businesswoman whose dream is to obtain goats for livestock.

loans.use: To purchase produces such as sorghum, peas, simsim, and so forth for sale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma B. is a married businesswoman. This entrepreneur runs a café business in Vingunguti ward, Dar es Salaam. She prepares and sells a variety of cooked and fried food as well as soft drinks. She purchases her business goods from the food shops and market at Buguruni and Kariakoo city market business center. She is able to provide for her family's daily needs from her business income, including paying her children's school fees. Fatuma is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 TZS to buy more business goods to meet customer demand.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Foluke

texts.en: Foluke A. A. is a widow with 4 children. Life as a widow has been so challenging to her and she hopes to overcome the challenge. She is 50 years old.  She sells planks at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for long. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She say thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Babatunde

texts.en: Babatunde sells drinks at retail prices to make a living. He hopes to expand his business.  He is 40 years old, married with 2 children. He is requesting for a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell.  He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru M. is a small-business married woman. She runs a business selling stoves to customers at Vingunguti ward in Dar es Salaam. Cooking with these stoves uses very little charcoal, reducing the rate of environmental destruction through air pollution.

Nuru meets her daily family needs from the income the business generates. She is requesting a loan of Tsh 1,000,000 to buy more business goods to expand her business.

loans.use: To boost her business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blocking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not disclosing his/her location and name, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

This borrower from Lebanon is a 36-year-old married man with two children, both of whom are attending school. He is the sole income provider for his household.

He has been running his construction business since 2001 and has thirteen years of experience in the field. In his work, he prepares the wood shuttering that is used to make a wall before applying concrete. He takes projects on an individual basis and works independently.

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,000 to invest in new tools for his business. These tools will enable him to take on more projects and improve the quality of his work. This loan will be his first loan with Kiva partner, Ameen.

loans.use: To invest in new tools for his construction business

loans.name: Lamin Nyim East Okello Beatrice Group

texts.en: O. Beatrice is a forty-year-old, hardworking businesswoman; she is married and has nine children, four of whom are going to school. She has a grocery business and she has been operating in it for over ten years. She is using the loan to purchase grocery items such as silverfish, tomatoes, onions, and so forth. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items such as silverfish, tomatoes, onions, and so forth.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
Note: Based on the politicA. and sociA. challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blocking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not disclosing his/her location and name, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

This borrower from Lebanon is a 31-year-old married man with one child who is attending school. The borrower is the main income provider for his family.

He has ten years of experience working as a farmer. He uses plastic tents to improve the quality of his agriculturA. products. These tents also allow him to grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business.

Today he is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase needed supplies for his agriculturA. work. He is a first-time Kiva borrower and also a first-time Ameen client. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Ayobami

texts.en: Ayobami loves business and she is happy in business. She sells drinks at retail prices. She hopes to grow her business in the future. She is 45 years old married, with 3 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of N80, 000 to purchase more drinks to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blocking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not disclosing his/her location and name, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

This borrower from Lebanon is a 34-year-old single man who has ten years of experience working as a farmer. He has owned his own farm since 2003. He works independently on his farm and he lives on his own.

This will be the borrower’s second loan from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. He used his previous loan to invest in supplies for his work. Throughout his previous loan, he consistently completed his repayments on time and his loan officer notes that he is a reliable borrower.

With your help, this borrower will be able to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work. He is requesting a loan of $1,200 and estimates that his profit has the potential to increase by 18% after taking this Kiva loan.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Jean Claude

texts.en:
Jean Claude is 32 years old, married with three children. Jean Claude has been a businessman since 2008. Jean Claude owns a small business selling office supplies. This business is very fruitful in his region simply because there are many schools where they need those kinds of products. Jean Claude's  business is open from 7 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except Saturday. He employs one person from his community as a helper so that his business runs well.

Jean Claude is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to increase his business through purchasing more products which will allow him to obtain more profits. The increased profit Jean Claude expects to earn will be reinvested in his business. With extra profits Jean Claude plans to build his own business venue.

loans.use: Expanding his own shop

loans.name: Jumanne

texts.en:
Jumanne S. is a small-business owner. He lives in Vingunguti, Dar es Salaam.

Jumanne runs a business selling animals (goats and sheep) to customers at Vingunguti animal market. He purchases the animals from the wholesale and retail animal suppliers. Vingunguti animal market is the center for animal sales in Dar es Salaam.

Jumanne meets his family’s daily needs from his business income. His business plan is to become a wholesale animal supplier as his business income grows.

loans.use: To buy more animals to sell

loans.name: Lamin Nyim East 2 Akot Lucy Group

texts.en: A. Lucy is a forty-four-year-old, hardworking businesswoman; she is married and has six children, three of whom are going to school. She also has three dependents. She has a fish business, which she has been operating for one year. She is using the loan to purchase fish for sale. She is encouraging and her future dream is to obtain bulls for cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase fish for sale.
